fields.title: Bronze and silver for Sophie in Sydney
fields.summary: A bemedalled Sophie Coleman will be returning home from Australia following some brilliant performances in the â€œAustralian Youth Olympic Festivalâ€ at Sydney.

fields.content:
Sophie Coleman has just returned from Australia where she competed for GB in the Australian Youth Olympic Festival in January, picking up a silver medal in the indiv. See Sophie's full report in the winter newsletter.

Sophie Coleman then ran a brilliant race for the Great Britain junior team in Lisbon on 2 February. Sophie placed second with the team taking the first four places to whitewash the opposition.

Sophie will be donning the Sussex vest in Inter-counties and World Championship Trials at Nottingham next month with the intention of gaining selection for the World Championships.

fields.title: Tim Bayley runs 4:01 indoor mile
fields.summary: Wearing Phoenix colours, Tim Bayley, who lives and works in the States, ran a magnificent 4:01 mile in the New Balance indoor games at the Armoury in New York last weekend.

fields.content:
Tim Bayley is aiming for a sub 4mins mile this indoor season. Based in the States. Tim still wears his Phoenix vest on every outing and we couldnâ€™t be prouder of him. So far he has run 4:10.69, coming 3rd in Seattle behind Us Olympian Galen Rupp. Then he moved to the famous Armoury track in New York for a 4.01.83 clocking and a 5th place. The next weekend he was back in Seattle for a 4:01.59 in 4th place.This is a time only seven Sussex athletes have ever bettered.

Tim Bayley won a 1km race in 2:26 and then swiftly followed it with a 49.1 win over 400m in California in the second week of February. His last indoor race is a mile in Seattle as we go to press.

The club indoor record for the mile is 3.58 held by Johan Boakes, a former world junior record holder for 1km and world junior silver medalist over 1500m. The outdoor record is still held by Steve Ovett and used to be the world record.

fields.title: Sophie, Charlie, Liz and Pat shine at National XC champs
fields.summary: Superb performances again by our young stars. Sophie Coleman came 6th in the junior womens’ race which does no harm to her immediate goal of making the GB team for the World cross country champs in March.

fields.content:
Superb performances again by our young stars. Sophie Coleman came 6th in the junior womens’ race which does no harm to her immediate goal of making the GB team for the World cross country champs in March.

Charlie Grice scored an impressive 16th in the under 15 boys race. For the seniors Liz Durman will be well pleased with her 137th placing in the women’s race as will Pat Davoren with166th in the men’s. Malcolm Hughes (800th) and Ian Moss (1101) completed the Phoenix line-up.

fields.title: Phoenix feature large at the Inter Counties XC
fields.summary: There was Phoenix representation across the board in Sussex vests for the Inter-county championships in Nottingham on 7 March. Stars of the day were Charlie Grice who was 6th in the U15 boys and Sophie Coleman 10th in

fields.content:
There was Phoenix representation across the board in Sussex vests for the Inter-county championships In Nottingham on 7 March. Star of the day was Charlie Grice who was 6th in the U15 boys. Sophie Coleman suffered cramp problems in the early part of her race and will be disappointed with her, otherwise impressive, 10th spot in the under 20 women’s race. She was hoping for a top 5 position to cement her claim for a GB place in the World Championships.

Other Phoenix placings: James Miles 256th SM, Finn MacNally 114th U17B, Robbie Fitzgibbon 46th and Billy White 64th U13B, Liz Durman 209th SW, Beth K.

Results

fields.title: Men's teams announced for South Downs Relay
fields.summary: Men's manager Andy Bone has announced his selection this week for the 100 mile South Downs Way relay on Saturday 6th June.

fields.content:
The 100 mile South Downs relay takes place in early June. Its an unforgettable day of high drama and emotion as each athlete runs three 5M plus legs during the course of the day. The word has got around and there has been a degree of pressure on places for both men's and women's teams. We haven't had the women' team confirmed yet but men's manager Andy Bone announced his selection this week:

A Team
Mike Townley, John Marinko, Jim Whitelegg, Andy Bone, Mike Greenwood, Malcolm Hughes. Reserve: Andy George

B Team
Malcolm Kemp, Brian Friend, Tony Holborn, Phil Hampshire, Colin Simpson, Ian Moss, Reserve: Ray Matthews

fields.title: Moss on the Fells
fields.summary: Ian Moss ran his first fell race of the season on March 7 – Black Combe in the South-West Lake District.

fields.content: Ian Moss ran his first fell race of the season – Black Combe in the South-West Lake District. Dense mist and freezing rain made navigation problematic over the eight-mile route with 3,400ft of ascent so the Phoenix vet was happy with his 88th place out of 118 starters (2:05). "Actually, I was just pleased to find may way to finish," he sa. Borrowdale's Andrew Schofield won in 1:24!!

fields.title: English Schools Cross Country Champs
fields.summary: Phoenix athletes were in action at the English Schools Cross country Championships at Stanford Hall on Saturday 21st March. Charlie Grice came 28th in the Inter Boys race and Max Pickard (pictured) came 98th. In the Inter Girls race Beth K

fields.content: Phoenix athletes were in action at the English Schools Cross country Championships at Stanford Hall on Saturday 21st March. Charlie Grice came 28th in the Inter Boys race and Max Pickard (pictured) came 98th. In the Inter Girls race Beth K. The Senior Boys were 4th in the team event and Phoenix athletes Finn McNally and Sam Wade helped them along with 41st and 70th placings.

fields.title: Josh and Matt lay down some markers at Hove 5k
fields.summary: A record 172 ran the Hove Park 5K timetrial on 21 March and Phoenix athletes Josh Guilmant and Matt Barrie lit the event up on their debuts.

fields.content:
A record 172 ran the Hove Park 5K timetrial on 21 March and Phoenix athletes lit the event up.
Josh Guilmant running his first event won in a sensational 15:22 which puts him second to Ben Warren in the all-time listings but first in the 25-29 age group. Matt Barrie, also on a debut was second on the day, is fifth in the all-time listings and goes straight to the head of the JM 15-19 rankings with a time of 15:40. We now have 6 of the age-group records. Gary Thayre ran 17:30 having knocked 4 seconds of his pb for this event. Andy Bone knocked an extraordinary 36 seconds off his to record 18:07. The analytical data base for this will keep you happy for hours – go to http://www.parkrun.com/bhtt_home.aspx

fields.title: JG and JM PB at Reading Half
fields.summary: The Reading Half Marathon has become very popular with Phoenix Athletes in recent years. It's reasonably flat well-organised and perfect for pbs. This year's hopefuls were not disappointed.

fields.content: The Reading Half Marathon has become very popular with Phoenix Athletes in recent years. It's reasonably flat, well-organised and perfect for pbs. This year's hopefuls were not disappointed. Josh Guilmant ran a stormer coming fifteenth in a field of 12,000. His time of 1:08:55 was a pb by roughly 2 minutes! James Miles carved a similar margin off his previous best to record 1:14:31 for 61st place. Dave Carter missed his pb by an agonising 10 seconds finishing 25th in 1:11:22. All our other athletes had impressive runs – Tom Coates 1:19:52, Garry Judd 1:22:53, Erica Martin 1:24:45, Dave Gifford 1:26:13 and head coach Malcolm Kemp recording 1:43:02 despite struggling to throw off a cold.

fields.title: Mike Murphy shows the way
fields.summary: Mike Murphy broke the three hour barrier with a splend. This should spur on the others in Malcolm's training group who are eyeing the same target in London.

fields.content:
Mike Murphy broke the three hour barrier with a splend. This should spur on the others in Malcolm's training group who are eyeing the same target in London.

Like Mike, Andy Bone, John Marinko, James Miles and Erica Martin have all been following Malcolm Kemp's sessions and all have their eyes on that magic three hour mark. It’s perhaps slightly more difficult in the larger event but all are going well and expectation is high. Also in the group is Dave Carter whose ambition will be to break 2:30. Good luck to them and all the other Phoenix athletes competing in London.

fields.title: Nigel Herron Qualifies for Euro Du Champs
fields.summary: At the British Duathlon Champs in Milton-Keynes on Sun 5th April Nigel Herron qualified to go to the ETU Duathlon European Championships in Budapest on 24 May. See the forum for his race report. Well done Nigel!

fields.title: Steyning Duathlon news
fields.summary: Well done to John Marinko, I think that he has qualified to go&

fields.content:
Well done to John, I think that he has qualified to go to Budapest for the European Du Champs in May.

Provisional results;

19. Malcolm Hughes (27:48/49:39/20:26) 1:37:56 AG1st

31. Nigel Herron (28:24/51:50/20:52) 1:41:10 AG3rd

35. John Marinko (27:50/52:32/21:28) 1:41:54 AG7th (qualifies for Euro’s)

There was a serious motorbike acc(completely unconnected to the event), which meant that the bike course had to be closed down, shortly after the athletes from wave one had left on the bike after completing the first run... meaning the race had to be stopped and the athletes return to T2. After some hurried course re-arrangement, the race was then re-started but with the athletes set off in time-trial , and then having their times from the first run added back to their 'second' race...

fields.title: Senior men take bronze in Sussex relays
fields.summary: The senior men were defending champions at the Sussex Road Relay Championships at Christ Hospital on 11 April. This time it was bronze for the team with Josh Guilmant running a storming leg for indiv.

fields.content:
The senior men were defending champions at the Sussex Road Relay Championships at Christ Hospital on 11 April. With a weakened team the task was to stay within the medals and bronze was duly achieved with some sensational running notably by Josh Guilmant (9:55), Matt Barrie (10:05) and Dave Carter (10:29). Josh’s time won him indiv. In the two-man B team young Jonas Wienecke showed his potential by running a brave 11:14 ending the first lap slightly ahead of the A team. The juniors were scuttled by incomplete teams but there were some great indiv– Robbie Fitzgibbon ran fourth fastes lap, U13 girls – Jodie Mann ran 7th fastest and the K, with Beth running two legs finished in a time that would have won them the event. Beth, however was rewarded with indiv. The senior women managed three teams on the day. The A team came an excellent 4th am(12:55) and Liz Durman (12:24). In the B team Sundai Boulton ran an excellent 12:30. The over 40 (5th) and over 50 (7th) vet men’s teams put in sol’s best run in 11:09 giving him 7th spot in the indiv.

Full results can be found here

Saturday 25th April 2009
Lizzy Brama wins the British Universities Colleges and Sport 10 Mile Time Trial Championships in Oxford in a time of 24 min 25 sec.

fields.title: Nigel Herron doing well in Duathlon Rankings

fields.content: This is a 5 race series with the best 3 races to count. The final race is at Oulton Park in October!

fields.title: Gold for Sophie Coleman
fields.summary: World Junior Champion Sophie Coleman added the National Junior Duathlon Championship at Loughborough on Sunday 26 April. Her winning time was 1:03:22 almost 1 minute ahead of 2nd.

fields.title: Malcolm Hughes 3rd at Steyning Triathlon
fields.summary: Malcolm Hughes got his first podium finishat theSteyning Long Triathlonon Sunday 3rd May. Finishing third behind

fields.content: Malcolm Hughes got his first podium finishat theSteyning Long Triathlonon Sunday 3rd May. Finishing third in 1:40:59behind Gary Pearce of Team REP 1:37:25 and Jonathan Streeter from Crawley Tri 1:39:56. Other Phoenix results include Rachel Bibby winning her age group. And in the sprint race Tim Woodman broke the Hour 59:18 to also win his age group.

fields.title: Phoenix Athletes Qualify for Age Group World Triathlon Champs
fields.summary: Tim Woodman and Debbie Evers qualify for the GB team going to Australia in September.

fields.content:
At this weekends Grendon Triathlon in Northamptonshire Tim Woodman and Debbie Evers successfully qualified to be part of the GB team at the World Age Group Sprint Trithlon Champs.

The venue for the World's this year are taking place is The Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia. They will be held on 12th September.

fields.title: Another Phoenix Triathlete Qualifies for Australia
fields.summary: Saturday's Little Beaver Triathlon saw Malcolm Hughes qualify for GB Team.

fields.content:
The first qualifying race for places in the GB Age GroupTeamto go to the ITU Standard Triathlon World Championships wasat Saturday's Little Beaver Triathlon. This washeld at the picturesque Belvoir Castle in Liecestershire.Malcolm Hughes came 3rd in his age group and 92nd overall in a time of 2h16m45s. This was good enough to claim one of the 4 places in each age groupup for grabs.

The Triathlon World Championships are being held on Australia's Gold Coast in September.

fields.title: Charlie Grice outpaces Steve Ovett at Brighton Schools
fields.summary: Charlie Grice has had an amazing week. On Wednesday 20 May at the Brighton Schools Championship he set a new record time of 1:58 for the intermediate boys 800m. To put this in perspective this eclipses the time set by Steve Ovett at the same age and su

fields.content:
Charlie Grice has had an amazing week. On Wednesday 20 May at the Brighton Schools Championship he set a new record time of 1:58 for the intermediate boys 800m. To put this in perspective this eclipses the time set by Steve Ovett at the same age and subsequently Phoenix’s Russel Pittam who set the previous record back in the 90s.

Charlie then competed in the South of England U17 Champs at Ashford on 24 May and (new to the age group) came second in the 1500 metres in a time of 3:58:35. This propels him to fourth spot in the national rankings and is the third fastest time of any Sussex Runner this season.

fields.title: Club Record For Sophie
fields.summary: At the Sussex Track and Field Championships in May Sophie Coleman broke Br's U20 Club and Sussex record for 3000m when she won the County Champs in 9.27.9. This time is a qualifying time for this years European Junior Championships and curre

fields.content:
At the Sussex Track and Field Championships in May Sophie Coleman broke Br's U20 Club and Sussex record for 3000m when she won the County Champs in 9.27.9. This time is a qualifying time for this years European Junior Championships and currently ranks her 3rd U20 in the UK. More interestingly it puts her 50th on the UK U20 all time lists.

Br's time of 9:28.9 remains the Club U17 record and good enough to rank her 9th on the UK U17 all time lists. When she set the time on the old Crawley track back in 1984 it put her no 1 in the world for her age that year. She is still the UK U17 record holder at 1500m with 4:15.20 set in Norway in 1984. Amongst her English Schools and National age group titles on and off the track Br. Her pbs for the following are the club records.

800m 2:04.30 Sen/ U20 - 2.07.0 U17

1000m 2:42.8 Sen/ U20

1500m 4:11.12Sen/ U20 -4:15.20 U17

the Mile 4:37.88 Sen/ U20 - 4:47.43 U17

3kms 9:00.3 Sen - 9.28.9 U17

fields.title: Phive K Phoenix
fields.summary: There must have been something in the air at the Hove Park 5k time trial on Saturday 20 June. No fewer than 5 Phoenix runners recorded pbs by substantial margins. For the icing on the cake Dave Carter won the event, which had a record

fields.content:
There must have been something in the air at the Hove Park 5k time trial on Saturday 20 June. No fewer than 5 Phoenix runners recorded pbs by substantial margins. For the icing on the cake Dave Carter won the event, which had a record turnout of 204, with Phoenix athletes scoring 1, 4, 5, 7. The pb stars were: Paul Thomas 34:34 (71 seconds improvement), Deb Friis 22:49 (9 seconds), Andrew Neighbour 21:07 (44 seconds), Jim Whiteleg 19:59 (14 seconds) and Miles Dav 17:40 (21 seconds). Phil Hampshire equalled his pb of 17:43 and Andy Bone ran an excellent 18:22.
Full result here

fields.title: Southern U20 & Senior Champs
fields.summary: At last weekends South Of England track and Field Champs Phoenix had a small group of athletes who on the whole performed very well. Top of the bunch was Pat Davoren ( pictured in his race ) who

fields.content: At last weekends South Of England track and Field Champs Phoenix had a small group of athletes who on the whole performed very well. Top of the bunch was Pat Davoren ( pictured in his race ) who won the 3kms steeplechase in a Season's Best time of 9:33:87. Pat has been covering 100 miles a week and is feeling good and looking strong off it. Flo Ray also posted a season's best when coming 6th in the Senior Women's 1500m with a time of 4:37.81. Personal bests where recorded by Josh Guilmant in the Senior Men's 5kms when he came 8th in 14:58:04 and Savannah Echel Thompson when she came 6th in the U20 Women's 400m final in a time of 56:43. Sarah Tomlins was 5th in the Senior Women's 400m final with 55:52 and Crawley's Joel K. Sundai Boulton went out in the U20 Women's 800m heats.

fields.title: Record turnout for the Blackcap Handicap
fields.summary: The annual Phoenix Blackcap handicap was held on the most perfect of Downland evenings (see attached photos) and attracted a record 35 athletes for this 5mile run. Thanks are due to Liz Hall

fields.content: The annual Phoenix Blackcap handicap was held on the most perfect of Downland evenings (see attached photos) and attracted a record 35 athletes for this 5mile run. Thanks are due to Liz Hall, Dave Howe, Phil Savage and Sue Hudson for marshalling and timekeeping duties. Ace handicapper Colin Simpson got it so right that everyone finished within a five minute window. The full results are here but the award winners were Daren Elliot (first to cross the line) 33:38, Dave Carter (fastest male) 28:32, and Anita Jones (fastest female-Phoenix) 39:08. Abbey Regan was fastest (non-Phoenix) female runner 34:49.

fields.title: Josh consolidates lead in Sussex 5k rankings
fields.summary: Josh Guilmant travelled all the way to Stretford track Manchester on Saturday 25 July to compete in a paced 5k race and recorded a massive pb which keeps him firmly at the top of this year's Sussex rankings.

fields.content: Josh Guilmant travelled all the way to Stretford track Manchester on Saturdayf 25 July to compete in a paced 5k race. Second in the B race, and just 4 seconds behind the winner, his time of 14:46.8 knocked an impressive 12 seconds off of his previous best time of 14:58.0. This fantastic run consol at the top of the Sussex 5k rankings.

fields.summary:
Faye won the T4 event at the Hyde Park Paratriathlon on Saturday 15th August which is a showcase event for the 2012 ParaOlympics with the largest ever field for a ParaTriathlon in Europe.
Fayes time of 41.38 was the fastest of the womens catego

fields.content:
Faye won the T4 event at the Hyde Park Paratriathlon on Saturday 15th August which is a showcase event for the 2012 ParaOlympics with the largest ever field for a ParaTriathlon in Europe.

Fayes time of 41.38 was the fastest of the womens category winners over this supersprint race of 300m swim 10k cycle and 3k run .

fields.title: Josh Guilmant takes 5K time trial record
fields.summary: On Saturday 29th August, Josh ran 15:08 to take the top spot in the all-time Hove Park 5K time trial records. This eclipses Ben Warren’s long-standing time by 4 seconds and knocks 14 seconds off Josh’s pb on this course. What made

fields.content: On Saturday 29th August, Josh ran 15:08 to take the top spot in the all-time Hove Park 5K time trial records. This eclipses Ben Warren’s long-standing time by 4 seconds and knocks 14 seconds off Josh’s previous best on this course. What made this all the more remarkable was the solo nature of the run (second and third were a full three minutes behind). Phoenix now has an enviable record in the time trials with three athletes in the top 10 times. Josh is first, Matt Barrie is fifth and Dave Carter is ninth. In addition a glance at the age-group lists show Josh (25-29), Matt Barrie (15-19) and Andrew Haig (60-64) in first place with Flo Ray (20-24), Max Pickard (JM14), Dave Carter (30-34), Phil Hampshire (50-54) and Bob Novis (55-59) in second place. Full result

fields.title: Tim Bayley Breaks 4 mins for the Mile
fields.summary: On Saturday 26th September Tim Bayley broke 4 mins for the first time

fields.content: On Saturday 26th September Tim Bayley broke 4 mins for the first time when he ran 3:58.3 to finish 12th out of 22 in the Elite Men's Race in the prestigious 5th Avenue Mile. The race is run straight down 5th Avenue in New York. The race was won by Britain's Andy Baddley with World Championship multiple Gold medallist Bernard Lagat in 4th place. Tim now heads to San Francisco for another road mile.

fields.title: Senior Men excel at South of England Road Relay Champs
fields.summary: The senior men put together pretty much their best team for this prestigious event A devastating first leg by Pat Davoren (18:58) and an equally impressive last leg (19:10) by Josh Guilmant bookended fine runs by the rest of the team. They were rewarde

fields.content:
The senior men put together pretty much their best team for this prestigious event A devastating first leg by Pat Davoren (18:58) and an equally impressive last leg (19:10) by Josh Guilmant bookended fine runs by the rest of the team. They were rewarded with fourteenth place out of the 78 completing teams. This is the third best result of all time for us. It gives us a qualification place for the National Championships on 17th October and the word is that the team are keen to take up the opportunity.

The other Phoenix team on the day was the over 40 men's team. Twenty-first out of 39 completing teams is also an excellent result in this context, From start to finish our runners just got faster with newcomer Ray Mattews on third leg taking us from 28th to 21st and Gary Thayre holding that place with the fastest leg of 22:21.

This year we were unable to field teams in the women's, juniors' and older vets' categories.

The photos by Lance Bellers show Pat Davoren kicking off for the seniors and the over 40s in action. The team shot of the seniors was taken by a Brighton and Hove runner and is hence out of focus.

fields.title: Sophie Coleman â€“ World Junior Duathlon Champion
fields.summary: Sophie Coleman and Vicky Graves have continued British Triathlon’s summer of success winning gold and silver respectively at the Junior Women’s 2009 Concord ITU Duathlon World Championships held in Concord, North Carolina on 26 September</p

fields.content: The win in Concord, delivered a double victory for Coleman, successfully defending her World Junior Duathlon title won last year in Rimini. In 2009 Coleman also finished second in the Australian Youth Olympic Festival and fifth in the Junior ETU Triathlon European Championships. The Eastbourne youngster has also had domestic success with victories in the British Junior Duathlon Championship and British Junior Triathlon Championships

fields.title: Phoenix Women win Cross Country Relay Champs
fields.summary: Phoenix women entered an unprecedented four teams for the Sussex Cross Country Relay Championships and were rewarded with victory for the A team. Erica Martin came home in the lead after leg 1 only for Horsham Blue Stars to take over the lead on the se

fields.content:
Phoenix women entered an unprecedented four teams for the Sussex Cross Country Relay Championships and were rewarded with victory for the A team. Erica Martin came home in the lead after leg 1 only for Horsham Blue Stars to take over the lead on the second leg despite a brave run from Sundai Boulton. Liz Durman, though, was in uncompromising mood and moved back into a 20 second lead on the third lap running second fastest time of the day. The senior men also performed well for second place and the under 13 boys (though incomplete) and Under 15 boys (fourth place) also performed well. Unusually the masters were unable to complete their team though there were decent runs by Paul Collicutt and Malcolm Hughes.

Full results and round up of all races at http://www.sussexathletics.org.uk/index.php

fields.title: Phoenix Ladies go Long....
fields.summary: October has seen two of our ladies taking on the challenge of ironman racing. Rachel Bibby was in action in Barcelona on the 4th while Lizzy Brama was in Hawaii for the World Championships on the 10th.

fields.content:
This was Rachel's first attempt at the ironman distance. Her swim went well and the bike was going OK until coming off whilst trying to grab a water bottle at one of the feed stations. However she was soon helped on her way again, a bit grazed on the shoulder and handle-bars on the bike not quite in line. Determined to finish Rachel started the run feeling good. All was going well till 32km on the marathon when a right knee problem meant that Rachel was doing the ironman shuffle.

Rachel finished in 12 hours 3 mins 25sec.A geart effort. Well Done!

And here are a few of Rachel's thoughts."To say I felt great when I finished would be a lie - I felt TERRIBLE!!!!! So I am now an Ironwoman! I had an amazing day and now it all feels rather surreal. I would totally recommend the race to anyone. I felt great after (after the drip!).
Will I do another one.....?
I think so. Well now I have finished, next I need to go faster!!!!"

Meanwhile in Hawaii....

Lizzy was in Kona, having qualified with her AG win at the Monaco 70.3 in 2008, preparing for the big day.

3.30 am for race morning breakfast!

According to Lizzy the swim was a "washing machine". A 63min swim and still in one piece saw her in 13th for AG.

On the bike it was not too windy "Overall I found the bike r, and despite 5:47 being quite a bit longer than what I had hoped for, it went by really quickly. In restrospect I probably could have gotten away with pushing a bit harder, but better to be safe than sorry."writes Lizzy. She is up to 12th

On to the run. Due to an injury Lizzy has not done as much run training as she would have liked and so started out conservatively. Recalling the finish, Lizzy wrote"I came down Alii Drive when the sun was a huge orange ball over the pier. The atmosphere was amazing and I just took it all in, clapped people's hands, and crossed the line with a huge smile on my face. Run time was 3:52:55 and pretty evenly paced which given the course, conditions, and shocking training stats is incredible and a marathon PB"

Post race
Pizza, pizza, ice cream, pizza

Race time 10 hours 51min 04 sec. 8th in age. How's that for a swimmer that says they can't run!

fields.title: Nigel Herron 2nd in Duathlon Rankings
fields.summary: Well done to Nigel Herron for his 2nd

fields.content:
Well done to Nigel Herron for his 2nd place inI age group (45-49)

Back in April Nigel raced at the National Championships in Emberton Park, Olney as well as the Steyning and Cambr. He has had the long wait till now for the season to end and the results to be finalized to see if he would hang on to his place

fields.title: Phoenix triumph at Preston Park Races
fields.summary: The weather may have been appalling, leading to reduced numbers on the day but the racing was good and Phoenix notched up cons. Josh Guilmant took the men's race with a thrilling finish against Chichester's James Baker. Erica Martin led

fields.content:
The weather may have been appalling, leading to reduced numbers on the day but the racing was good and Phoenix notched up cons. Josh Guilmant took the men's race with a thrilling finish against Chichester's James Baker. Erica Martin led the women's race from start to finish, Dan Stepney and Sundai Boulton won convincing victories in the inaugural Fr, Archie Davis won his race (U11 boys), Beth K, Charlie Grice was first (U17 boys) and Billy White broke the course record for U13 boys. Phoenix won both mens team and B team awards and U13 boys took silver. All in all a pretty successful day for the club. The event was generally cons. Thanks to the Phoenix athletes (61 competed) and everyone who gave their time and energy as marshalls, registrars, timekeepers and organisers especially Chairman Paul and Andy Bone who orchestrated the event brilliantly.

Suussex Sports Photography covered the race and can be seen here

Lance Bellers has posted additional shots here

Andrew Haig and Reg Richardson have also contributed some of these images.

Full results available soon

fields.title: Phoenix Success in Paratriathlon Ranking Series
fields.summary: Congratulations to Faye McClelland for winning her category an

fields.content:
Congratulations to Faye McClelland for winning her category and Paul Thomas for his second place in the inaugural British Paratriathlon Ranking series .

2009 was the first year British Triathlon has organised and run a ranking series for paratriathletes in the UK. Faye and Paul travelled the country to take part in the Rother Valley, Bedford Classic and Mazda London Triathlons.

fields.title: 'Silver Foxes' retain gold at Masters XC Champs
fields.summary: The over 60s men's team (aka Silver Foxes) were defending champions at the Sussex Masters XC Champs at Denne Park on Sunday 6 December. That they d

fields.content:
The over 60s men's team (aka Silver Foxes) were defending champions at the Sussex Masters XC Champs at Denne Park on Sunday 6 December. That they d, backed up by Andrew Haig (4th) and Pat Kearney (10th). Pat qualified by a whisker for this age group – it was his birthday on the day of the event. What a way to celebrate!

Otherwise Phoenix were handsomely represented by the vet men (we had no vet women's teams) and in soggy conditions (just look at the photographs) performed well for 4th team placings in the over 50 and over 40 categories. Andy Bone and Nigel Herron ran sub 40 minute for the over 40s (12th and 17th respectively), Brian Friend and Colin Simpson ran sub 44s (11th and 12th) in the over 50s.

See results page

fields.title: James wins the Hove Park 5K
fields.summary: James Miles has come second on three occasions in the Hove Park 5K time trials, but on Saturday 5 December he ran a hugely commited race to win the event. Martin Bean and Howard Bristow from Brighton and Hove AC pushed him all the way, with Martin taki

fields.content: James Miles has come second on three occasions in the Hove Park 5K time trials, but on Saturday 5 December he ran a hugely commited race to win the event. Martin Bean and Howard Bristow from Brighton and Hove AC pushed him all the way, with Martin taking the lead at the top of the hill on the last lap. James was having none of it however and stormed through in a thrilling sprint finish to open up a three second lead. His time of 16:24 was a pb by a whopping 18 seconds. James' partner, Liz Durman, also had a good run battling hard for second place in the women's race, eventually beating 3rd placed Jane Harrop by 2 seconds.

fields.title: Finn McNally wins Boxing Day race
fields.summary: Finn McNallywho is only in his first year as an Under 20 athlete, became one of the youngest ever winners of the annual Boxing Day race inBrighton's Preston Park.

fields.content:
Finn McNallywho is only in his first year as an Under 20 athlete, became one of the youngest ever winners of the annual Boxing Day race inBrighton's Preston Park.

Finnhad kept pace with established seniors Brighton & Hove's Matt Bristow and Chris Thomson but managed to outrun them on the final lap clocking 29:29 to beat Thomson, who clocked 29:33 by twenty yards with Bristow a further fifty yards adrift in 29:42

The race format invites you to complete 1,2,3 or 4 laps and Phoenix were also prominent in the shorter events with Max Pickard four minutes ahead of second placed Gary Thayre in the three lap event and Charlie Grice winning the two lap event. There were fourteen Phoenix athletes in total.

Full results here

fields.title: Sussex XC champs: Gold sun, silver frost, bronze medals
fields.summary: The turn out of seniors was terrific, with A and B teams scoring for both the men's and women's races. In brilliantly sunny but freezing conditions we d.

fields.content:
The turn out of seniors was terrific, with A and B teams scoring for both the men's and women's races. In brilliantly sunny but freezing conditions we d.

Josh Guilmant (5th) and Pat Davoren (6th) were top scorers for the men with James Miles (26th), Tom Coates (27th), Max-Patrick Lippert (30th) and Bruce Faulkner (36th) completing the A team. Sophie Coleman (2nd), Erica Martin (12th), Liz Durman (20th) and Anita Jones (46th) made up the women's A team. Katie KIdger, who has transferred to Phoenix, was 19th but is not yet eligible to score for us. Looks like she is going to be a great asset for the women's team.

The junior age groups were represented thinly with no entries at all for U13 and U15 girls and complete teams only for U15 boys (silver team medal – William Dukin indiv) and U17 boys (bronze team medal – Charlie Grice indiv). Beth K. Sophie Coleman (second in the senior women's race) took gold for U20 women.

Full results here

fields.title: Club Awards Night
fields.summary: Having been postponed a few times because of winter weather, the Club Annual Rewards Ceremony took place on Wednesday 3 February at a rainswept Withdean Stadium. It was good to see quite a few newer faces among the winners.

fields.content:
Having been postponed a few times because of winter weather, the Club Annual Rewards Ceremony took place on Wednesday 3 February at a rainswept Withdean Stadium. It was good to see quite a few newer faces among the winners.

Burchell Award for Boys Matt Berr, Burchell Award for Girls Jess Bone, Most consistent U13 Boy Jack Foster, Most Consistent U13 Girl Jody Mann, Most Consistent U15/U17 Boy Robbie Fitzgibbon, Most Consistent U15/U17 Girl Beth K, Best Performance T & F - Male Charlie Grice, Best Performance T & F - Female Sophie Coleman, Best Performance XC / Road - Male Josh Guilmant, Best Performance XC / Road - Female Sophie Coleman, Outstanding Team U13 Boys Team, Tough of the Track Max Pickard, Shield for Commitment & Enthusiasm Paul Thomas, Volunteers Award Andy Bone, Come-Back of the Year Award Pat Davoren, Vet Over 40 Men Daren Elliot, Vet Over 50 Men Brian Friend, Vet Over 35 Women Anita Jones, Vet Over 50 Women Sue Hudson, Multisport award Men Nigel Herron, Multisport Award Women Ananda Mello-Costa, Tri Club Champion Men Malcolm Hughes, Tri Club Champion Women Rachel Bibby, Chairman's Award Joel K. Malcolm Hughes was the winner of the multi sport outstanding acheivement award which is sponsored by Tri Sport Coaching (TSC).

fields.title: Phoenix Athletes Indoors
fields.summary: The weekend of 6th and 7th of February proved a good one for two of Phoenix's indoor stars.

fields.content:
The weekend of 6th and 7th of February proved a good one for two of Phoenix's indoor stars.

In Boston Tim Bayley ran under 4 mins for the mile at the Reebok Boston Indoor Games. His time of 3:59.75 placed him sixth behind Olympic Silver medallist Nick Willis ( 3:55.26 ). More importantly for Tim he also achieved the A standard qualifying time for the world indoor championships...getting it safely out of the way before the UK trials on 13th/ 14th Feb.

A few weeks back on 16th Jan Tim broke 4mins at the Seattle inddor meeting with a time of 3:59.58....just inches behind Alistair Cragg of Ireland ( one of the few Europeans to ever beat Kinese Bekele! ). An hour and a half later Tim followed the mile up with a 1:51.77 victory in the 800m.

On 30th Jan he also came 2nd over 800m at seattle with a 1:49.47. This race can be seen on Flotrack. Go to www.flotrack.org and type Tim Bayley into the search box.

Tim is now officially Phoenix's 5th sub 4min miler behind Steve Ovett, Mark Rowland, Johan Boakes and Mark Howard.

Meanwhile back in sunny Britain Dan Stepney has been getting himself back in form after missing the last two years of track racing due to injuries. He started the season with a 4:04.10 1500m in his heat at the Southern Indoors. On 30th Jan he came 5th in the London Indoor Games in 1:53.6 over 800m. On 6th/7th Feb Dan won the Birmingham Games 800m...winning his heat (1:55), his semi 1:54.8 ) and the final ( 1:55 ).

Both Tim and Dan are heading up to the UK trials next weekend.

fields.title: Sussex Grand Prix Results announced
fields.summary: The Sussex Grand Prix results for 2009 have just been published. Given a somewhat patchy involvement by Phoenix athletes we haven't done too badly. In the team competition we came 8th out of the twenty Sussex teams involved. In category terms this was<

fields.content:
The Sussex Grand Prix results for 2009 have just been published. Given a somewhat patchy involvement by Phoenix athletes we haven't done too badly. In the team competition we came 8th out of the twenty Sussex teams involved. In category terms this was aggregated from the men 8th and the women 9th. Vet men made 6th spot and vet women 11th.

Standout indivAnanda Mello-Costa with an excellent 4th place for senior women. Also in the top twenty Erica Martin 9th and Faye McClelland 15th. Liz Hall was 7th in the V3 category and Carolyn Austen 4th in V5.

In the men's competition Andy Bone made 12th in the V1s, Lance Bellers was 5th in the V2s, Terry Avey was 3rd in the V4s and Andrew Haig 1st in the V5s (for the fourth year running).

The full results can be seen here

Wednesday 24th March at Jack and the Jill pub, Clayton

fields.title: Success at Frosty Aquathlon
fields.summary: At this year's Frosty Aquathlon held on a

fields.content:
At this year's Frosty Aquathlon held on a chilly but sunny Sunday 7th March morning Brighton Phoenix Tri managed to regain the team title. The race is an 800m swim followed by a 10km run and the Phoenix Phlyers of 3. Liam McNally (11:53/37:50) 49:43, 6. Malcolm Hughes (13:03/:37:52) 50:55, 15. Dr James Hayward (13:23/41:18) 54:41 and 19.Erica Martin (15:27/40:35) 56:02 beat off the challenge of the Tuff-Fitty team to win by 10 minutes in an aggregate time of 03:31:21.

Liam was 2nd senior male and Erica was 3rd lady.

Debbie Evers was the 1st female senior vet in a time of 1:06:27

We also had a second team, in fact there were only 3 teams entered, the Phoenix Phavourites were Andrew Seivewright, Elisabeth Brama, Rachel Bibby and Ananda MelloCosta

Also being run was the Frostbite over half the distance of the Frosty. In which Faye McClelland came 10th and was 5th lady

full results

fields.title: Mike Whyte posts sub-3 at Barcelona
fields.summary: Vet, Mike Whyte has set the pace for all those in the club hoping to run under three hours in the spring marathons. Coming off the back of 1:23 at the Beacon Half in February, he knocked an extraordinary 11 minutes off his marathon pb to record 2:57:11

fields.content:
Vet, Mike Whyte has set the pace for all those in the club hoping to run under three hours in the spring marathons. Coming off the back of 1:23 at the Beacon Half in February, he knocked an extraordinary 11 minutes off his marathon pb to record 2:57:11. at the Barcelona Marathon on Sunday 7 March. This for an excellent 423rd placing.
Mike writes "I was very pleasedthat I rannearly even splitsbecausestartingout too fast has beena problem for me on previous occasions, 1st half approx 1.28.30 and 2nd half approx 1.28.45. Weather conditions were perfect and the crowd support was great. This was one of my favourite marathons and very well organised. I´m running Edinburgh in May and will definitely be shooting for a sub 2.55."

fields.title: Tim Bayley makes the British team for Doha
fields.summary: Tim Bayley had to wait for an agonising 48 hours after his amazing run at the Aviva Grand Prix meeting in Birmingham for comfirmation of his place in the 1500 metres in the World Indoor Championships in Doha on 11/14 March.

fields.content:
Tim Bayley makes the British team at Doha

Tim Bayley had to wait for an agonising 48 hours after his amazing run at the Aviva Grand Prix meeting in Birmingham for comfirmation of his place in the 1500 metres in the World Indoor Championships in Doha on 11/14 March. He needed this race to prove his point having come second the week before at the British trials in a slow tactical time. This time there was no mistake. Although placing seventh in the race, He posted a substantial pb of 3:40:16 and that was enough to impress the selectors and give Phoenix its first representation at a major international championship since Pat Davoren ran in the Commonwealth Games. Tim becomes the club indoor 1500 metre record holder.

You can watch live online here Heats on Fr

Tim has also twice broken the 4 minute indoor Mile barrier before his departure from the states. His best of 3:59:53 was in Seattle on January 16. This makes him 5th on the club all-time list behind Steve Ovett, Mark Rowland, Johann Boakes and Mark Howard. Tim must surely be eyeing the 2012 Olympics as an achievable ambition.

fields.title: County Kids
fields.summary: Phoenix is well represented in the Sussex teams running at the inter-county Cross country championships in Birmingham on the 13th March and at the English schools championships in Manchester the following weekend.

fields.content:
Phoenix is well represented in the Sussex teams running at the inter-county Cross country championships in Birmingham on the 13th March and at the English schools championships in Manchester the following weekend. At the inter-counties, Billy White runs for U13 boys, Robbie Fitzgibbon U17, and Finn McNally and Sam Wade for U20. Beth K, Megan K. Unfortunately, Sophie Coleman has withdrawn from the senior women's team because of injury.

The English schools event features Robbie Fitgibbon in the Junior boys squad with Billy White in reserve, Charlie Grice and Will Durkin Intermediate boys and Finn McNally and Sam Wade running for senior boys with Max Pickard in reserve. Beth K.

Good luck everybody.

fields.title: Brighton Marathon a success.
fields.summary: Great weather, great organisation, great support. The inaugural Brighton Marathon was a success beyond most people's expectation. And Phoenix featured large on the day. Second claim member, Tom Naylor was, with Tim Hutchins, the event organiser –

fields.content:
Great weather, great organisation, great support. The inaugural Brighton Marathon was a success beyond most people's expectation. And Phoenix featured large on the day. Second claim member, Tom Naylor was, with Tim Hutchins, the event organiser – so hearty congratulations to him. Olympic Champion and club founder Steve Ovett started the race. Mike Whyte and Tim Woodman fulfilled their pacing roles to perfection and, of course, 30+ of you took part and came up with some quality performances. We had four runners under three hours led by returning member Neil Boniface (7th in 2:41:23). Mike Greenwood ran the best judged race of all finishing 18th in a time of 2:50:13 which shaves his previous best by some 25 minutes!. Good to see Daryl Hards back in shape and although he slipped back in the closing miles managed an impressive 2:54:36. Max-Patrick Lippert was supposed to be running the Boston Marathon but his plans fell to ash (of the Icelandic variety) but he was offered a last minute place in the race and responded with an even-paced 2:59:42 for 90th position. As you can see from the list here, a further 18 Phoenix athletes finished under four hours with everyone safely home by five. As if that weren't enough, Charlie Grice won the mini mile event. Last year Charlie broke Steve Ovett's 800m Brighton schoolboy record, taking it down to 1:55.80. On Sunday he got to meet the great man in person. Archie Davis was first U13 boy in the mini mile.

fields.title: Faye McClelland wins in Uckfield
fields.summary: In an excellent start to the season, Faye McClelland, one of the the 2010 Paratriathlon Performance squad competed in and won her first Triathlon of 2010

fields.content:
In an excellent start to the season, Faye McClelland, one of the the 2010 Paratriathlon Performance squad competed in and won her first Triathlon of 2010 at the Uckfield Super Sprint Triathlon. Faye clocked a time of 56min 32sec to finish over 30seconds ahead of the next competitor, over a distance of 200mtr swim, 16km bike and 3.5km run.

Faye commented on her victory:

"I am very pleased to havewon my first Triathlon race of the season!A great testament to beingback ontrack with my training, after what seemed like a longwinterrecovering from aninjury"

Results here

fields.title: New Manager for U13 boys
fields.summary: Quenton Davis, father of Archie Davis (pictured) has taken over as manager of the U13 boys. This team has been pretty successful in recent years so a big thank you goes to Ian Reynolds, the previous incumbant. Quenton is very keen to raise the profile<

fields.content:
Quenton Davis, father of Archie Davis (pictured) has taken over as manager of the U13 boys. This team has been pretty successful in recent years so a big thank you goes to Ian Reynolds, the previous incumbant. Quenton is very keen to raise the profile of junior athletes on the website and elsewhere with fixtures and results regularly posted which will, hopefully, encourage more competitiveness.

Son, Archie is having a particularly successful season already, as year 6 Sussex schools (6 Feb) and Brighton Schools (13 Mar) XC champion, 1st U13 1200m (Crawley pre-season open 28 Mar) 4:00, 1st U13 boy (Brighton Marathon mini mile 8 April) 5:46 and 3rd U13 boy 600m (Haywards Heath Harriers Open 22 April) 1:50.

Quenton says:…I am a reasonably quiet person but was involved in senior football for a long time & would describe myself as very competitive. However, I appreciate that not everyone is & I shall remain diplomatic in my approach; Archie ran in the recent XC league, where he & Billy White made up the Phoenix team effort. If we could have got 1 more runner we would have done quite well in the team events

fields.title: PBs at Hendon
fields.summary: On Saturday 24th April a Phoenix squad travelled up to Hendon for some BMC 1500m races. PBs were recorded by Charlie Grice, Max Pickard, finn McNally and Will Durkin. Josh Guilmant and Flo Ray were both about 5 secs off their pbs.

fields.content: On Saturday 24th April a Phoenix squad travelled up to Hendon for some BMC 1500m races. PBs were recorded by Charlie Grice, Max Pickard, finn McNally and Will Durkin. Josh Guilmant and Flo Ray were both about 5 secs off their pbs. Max Pickard won the B 1500m knocking a massive 11 secs off his best with 4:07:5. Charlie Grice won the A race in 3:53:31 and moves to the top of the UK U17 rankings. He also moves to 22nd on the UK all time list for U17s. His time is within the qualifying mark for the GB Youth Olympics team. The race was perfectly set up for him due to a brilliant bit of pace making from Joel K.

fields.title: Andy and Tom go sub-three in London
fields.summary: Phoenix fielded just four runners this year (Brighton Marathon having  attracted a good few). Andy Bone has been just outs(3:02 in 2009) but having  trained with single-minded

fields.content:
Phoenix fielded just four runners this year (Brighton Marathon having attracted a good few). Andy Bone has been just outs(3:02 in 2009) but having trained with single-minded dedication was rewarded with a magnificent 2:54:58 for 715th place. Tom Fars also smashed decisively through the barrier with a pb by 3:40 to record 2:57:23 (858th). Daren Elliot knocked about 37 minutes from his 2009 time to record 3:19:00 2948th and Lance Bellers running his first marathon, and with training interrupted by injury, managed an impressive 3:27:35 (3954th). Well done everybody.

Full results

fields.title: Millfield BMC PB Classic
fields.summary: Phoenix took 4 athletes down to the BMC PB Classic at Millfield near Glastonbury on Bank Hol. They all performed well with two PBs and two other sol.

fields.content: Phoenix took 4 athletes down to the BMC PB Classic at Millfield near Glastonbury on Bank Hol. They all performed well with two PBs and two other sol. Will Durkin ran 4:13:87 for a 1500m pb coming 4th in the C race. Max Pickard ran his second quickest time with 4:10:87 for 8th in the B race and Charlie Grice also ran his second quickest time with 3:54:36 for 3rd in the A race. Finn McNally smashed over 10 secs off his 3kms pb with 8:46:34 for 4th in a close B race.

fields.title: Our Man In Moscow
fields.summary: This current generation of Phoenix Athletes is leading the charge for new standards in the club. Charlie Grice has just been selected for his first International vest.

fields.content: This current generation of Phoenix Athletes is leading the charge for new standards in the club. Charlie Grice has just been selected for his first International vest. Following his 1500ms in Hendon and Millfield he has been selected to represent Great Britain over 1km in the European selection zone for the Youth Olympics. He will travel to Moscow later this month. If he finishes in the top 3 in his event he goes on to run in the Youth Olympics in Singapore later on in the year. Congratulations Charlie!

fields.title: Reuben blazes a trail at Hove Park
fields.summary: At the 5k park run in Hove Park on Saturday 1 May, newly registered junior Reuben Hoyte knocked 9 seconds off his PB to finish in a time of 19.59, an outstanding run cons. Reuben is the son of

fields.content:
At the 5k park run in Hove Park on Saturday 1 May, newly registered junior Reuben Hoyte knocked 9 seconds off his PB to finish in a time of 19.59, an outstanding run cons. Reuben is the son of Kurt & Caroline Hoyte, both wel-known Sussex athletes.Caroline holds the women's record at Hove Park.

Archie Davisran a PB of 20.01in only his second park run and Will Russell ran aPB of 22.41.
Vet, Jon Pike also ran a 19:15 pb at the same event.

Phoenix have a strong record at the time trials with Josh Guilmant still the overall record holder (and first in the M25-29 band) and Matt Barrie (M15-19), Dave Carter (M35-39) and Andrew Haig (VM 60-64) all leading their age groups.

STP PRESS: At the trials 8 May Andy Bone (VM 40–44) ran himself into second place with a magnificant 17:59 PB. Meanwhile Will Russell lowered his PB yet again to 22:26.

Results

fields.title: Charlie in Moscow
fields.summary: Charlie Grice completed part one of his job on Fr.24.56.

fields.content: Charlie Grice completed part one of his job on Fr.24.56. He goes into Sunday's final as the fastest qualifier. If he gets a top 3 placing in the final he goes on to represent the UK again but later on in the year in August at the Youth Olympics in Singapore.

fields.title: Silver For Charlie
fields.summary: Charlie Grice came 2nd in the 1000m final of the European Youth Olympics Selection meeting in Moscow and now qualifies to go forward to Singapore in August for the Youth Olympics.

fields.content:
Charlie Grice came 2nd in the 1000m final of the European Youth Olympics Selection meeting in Moscow and now qualifies to go forward to Singapore in August for the Youth Olympics. He clocked 2:25.27 behind Ireland's Mark English who ran 2.24.53. Charlie now goes 2nd on the UK U17 All Time ( with his heat time of 2.24.56 ) list for that event...ahead of people like Steve Ovett! Unfortunately for Charlie it is not a club record as he is 2nd on that list to Johan Boakes. Phoenix athletes 1 and 2 on the all time list...maybe we do know what we're doing after all!

Race vhttp://www.youtube.com/user/pvcamera#p/u/2/86AQSg_hw60

fields.title: Friis – a jolly good fellow!
fields.summary: Congratulations to Deb Friis and Dave Carter on the safe delivery of their son, Otis Frank Friis Carter. He was born 2 weeks early on Fr. Deb was still running well into the pregnancy (as was Dave!)

fields.content: Congratulations to Deb and Dave on the safe delivery of their son, Otis Frank Friis Carter. He was born 2 weeks early on Fr. Deb was still running well into the pregnancy (so was Dave come to think of it) and in her words 'It was a very short labour at just over an hour! We had to stay in overnight as he was so small, but he's at home now and feeding well, and we even went for a trip to the park today. So far he's very chilled! We've already had a number of Phoenix people commenting on the speediness of his delivery being a sign of things to come! Lets hope so!'

fields.title: Vets win Silver in South Downs Way Relay
fields.summary: Phoenix had three teams entered in the 100 mile relay from Eastbourne to Winchester. The Vets team managed an excellent second place to Stubbington Vets by seven and a half minutes - 11 hours 28 minutes and 31 seconds (fifth place out of 57 teams).

fields.content:
On an extremely hot Saturday, the Phoenix teams ran very well cons, Phoenix records and leg PBs where always going to be difficult. Saying that Anita Jones managed a new PHX record on Leg 15 and Lenka Sobotkova got the record for Leg 9. The Ladies Team finished in 13 hours 50 mins and 58 seconds.

Andy Bone ran a new Phoenix Vets record on the long Leg 17, knocking almost a minute off the previous time, 35 seconds over the hour.

The A Team finished ninth which is a great result as five of the runners were vets (three over 50!) in a time of 12:14:06.

Interestingly four teams got lost on early legs and withdrew and one team got disqualified. This just goes to show what a tough race this is. Not getting lost or injured over the 100 mile course is all part of the fun! Also thanks to the drivers and navigators, Jim Whitelegg, Ray Matthews, Andy George and Sue Hudson, we couldn’t have done it without you guys.

The Cooper Cup (Age graded results) PHX Vets finished 2nd with 90.93% (Chichester Vets 1st - 91.63%). PHX A Team 85.46% (17th) and PHX Ladies 77.12% (39th).

fields.title: Darryl Hards wins Seaford Half Marathon
fields.summary: Daryll has been on the comeback trail for some time now and, after terrific runs at the Brighton half and full marathons this year, this win is well-deserved. It was a hot day and this hilly off-road course offers quite a challenge.

fields.content: Daryll has been on the comeback trail for some time now and, after terrific runs at the Brighton half and full marathons this year, this win is well-deserved. It was a hot day and this hilly off-road course offers quite a challenge. Darryll won by a convincing 1 minute and 24 seconds from second-placed Mats Gedin of Arena in a time of 1:24:39. As so often Daryll was accompanied by brother Lewis (31st 1:39:59) and father Kim (72nd 1:47:26). Other Phoenix competitors Daren Elliot, Terry Avey and Ivan Lyons also put in impressive performances. Results

fields.title: Mike Collins takes Silver
fields.summary: Mike Collins won the Silver medal in the M70 Long Jump category at the British Masters meet at Cardiff on 3rd July with a jump of 3m 46cm.

fields.content:
Mike - one of the most "senior" competing athletes in Phoenix was hoping to do the double with the triple jump as well but a slight calf injury meant he could only participate in the long jump and would probably have got gold if not for the injury.

This follows Mike's successs at Ashford in the Southern Counties Vets where he was 1st in the Triple Jump ( 7m 43cm) and 2nd in the Long Jump ( 3m 34cm)

Well done Mike .

fields.title: Blackcap Handicap
fields.summary: Andrew Neighbour wins the Handicap, Finn McNally fastest Male and Aimee Billinton fastest female

fields.content:
results http://www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results

Brief report from the handicapper ( Colin)...

On a beautiful warm summers evening the annual Black Cap 5 took place well organised by Liz Hall. We had 3 volunteer timekeepers (better than some road races!!) and an unfit looking turn round marshall. The race runs along the top of the Sussex Downs from Ditchling Beacon to the Black Cap trig point and back.

19 athletes took part which is a little down on previous years but all were very keen and ran well. The handicapping worked quite well apart from a few obvious exceptions and most finished within a 3-4 mins time period. The ’t appreciate that !

Conditions were (I will swop yours with mine please). Next home and posting the fastest time of the evening and just 3 seconds outs. Finn started last so managed to pass everyone else bar Andrew. 6th home in the handicap and fastest lady was Aimee Billington who posted the third best womens time ever. It was good to see almost half the field were ladies showing our new found strength or perhaps all the men were making dinner?

Special award should go to Dav.

Please pencil this in your diaries for next year

fields.title: English Schools Champion!
fields.summary: Charlie Grice fell off his bike the tuesday before the English schools Championships and injured his knee and shoulder.

fields.content:
Despite injuring his knee and shoulder just before the English Schools Championships Charlie Grice proceeded to dominate the Inter Boys 1500m winning his heat and racing to victory in the final. After a slow first lap he took up the lead with 900m to go and gently upped the pace on each lap until no one could stay with him. His time of 3:52:25 is his 2nd best so far and also broke the championship record which had been held since the 1980s by Phoenix Old Boy Johan Boakes.

Next weekend Charlie will represent English Schools in Glasgow in the Home Countries Schools International, an event that Savannah Echel Thomson represented England and Phoenix at a few years ago.

A week and a half before the champs Charlie had won the BMC B 1500m at Watford in 3:48:7 to go 3rd on the UK all time U17 list behind Steve Cram and Johan Boakes.

At that same Watford meeting Will Durkin and Max Pickard ran pbs in the 1500m and 3000m respectively.

fields.title: Club record for 800m!!!
fields.summary: Running at Eltham in a BMC 800m Charlie Grice ran 1:50:6 for a win in windy conditions.

fields.content: Running at Eltham in a BMC 800m Charlie Grice ran 1:50:6 for a win in windy conditions. Joel K. Charlie is now 7th on the UK U17 all time lists for 800m...one place ahead of Peter Elliot and almost 2 secs ahead of Club Senior record holder and Olympic Champion at the distance..Steve Ovett.

fields.title: Fun and Games at the Phoenix Picnic
fields.summary: The Phoenix picnic on Sunday afternoon saw a revival of the mighty 'Tug of war.'. The magnificent girls' team beat the boys' team 2-1 and lost only narrowly to a fiercely competitive 'ladies' team.

fields.content: The Phoenix picnic on Sunday afternoon saw a revival of the mighty 'Tug of war.'. The magnificent girls' team beat the boys' team 2-1 and lost only narrowly to a fiercely competitive 'ladies' team. (For some reason the gentlemen were left in peace dozing in the sunshine.) Rounders was played, footballs were kicked and the cricket stumps came out. Meanwhile delicious cakes and sweets were being passed round while the weather smiled on us. All in all a lovely summer afternoon and one that hopefully will become an annual fixture. Thanks to Andy Bone and John Marinko for organising it and to Tom Fars've ever eaten! AH

fields.title: Grice takes Bronze in Singapore
fields.summary: Charlie Grice ran a storming PB 2:21.85 in the 1000m Final in the Youth Olympic Games in Singapore for the GB team.

fields.content:
22 August Singapore

In a fierce race, Charlie left it late finishing fourth only to find that the third placed Moroccan Abdelhadi Labali had been disqualified. The race was won by Mohammed Geleto (Ethopia) in 2:19.54 (PB), second was Hamza Driouch (Qatar) 2:21.25. A magnificent achievement in very hum, Charlie had qualified for Sunday’s final by winning his heat on 18 August in 2:24.74.

Well done Charlie. We can’t wait to see the medal.

fields.content:
Amber Anning, aged just 9, won three Gold medals at the Crawley AC Tom Lintern Medal meet on 30th August.

Competing in the U11 Girls events, Amber ran PB’s of 11.07 in the 75m and 22.16 in the 150m before rounding the day off with a PB of 3.93 in the Long Jump. She is presently the fastest 9 year old in the UK over 75m.

Well done Amber.

fields.title: Mike excels at the Ultra
fields.summary: Mike Townley ran the 22nd London to Brighton trail run on Sunday 5 September, coming a magnificent seventh out of 106 finishers. (The event was won in 8:32). His time for the 56-mile distance was 9 hours 50 minutes – well within his target. He se

fields.content:
Mike Townley ran the 22nd London to Brighton trail run on Sunday 5 September, coming a magnificent seventh out of 106 finishers. (The event was won in 8:32). His time for the 56-mile distance was 9 hours 50 minutes – well within his target. He seems to have enjoyed the experience enormously with just one moment of doubt at 36 miles when an anxious marshal asked if he was feeling all right. That was enough to spur him on his way.

In the next newsletter, we hope to explore the world of ultra-running a little further with a full story from Mike and, hopefully, contributions from others of you about past experiences or future plans in this area.

Results

On the same day in a slightly less major city Mike Whyte chalked up yet another sub three run with 2:58:24 at Abingdon.

fields.title: Paul defeats discrimination
fields.summary: Paul Thomashas defeated opposition and won the right to take part in more cross country in Sussex.Paul's determination to race has caused England Athletics to re-think their inclusion policy.

fields.content:
Paul Thomashas defeated opposition and won the right to take part in more cross country in Sussex.Paul's determination to race has caused England Athletics to re-think their inclusion policy.

Paul suffers from Clauda Equina Syndrome and uses poles to a.In the past organisers have claimed that his poles may become a health and safety risk.

Last year he was banned from three races and disqualified from another for using ‘technical a.’ This year Paul has faced further issues but has continued to fight for the recognition of disabled athletes.

Paul sa, organisers should be looking at ability not disability.”

Nigel Herron added: "Paul poses no more risk to himself or others than I, or any other athlete."

Paul has fought fiercely for the right to race in and has already completed two races which he was initially banned from this year.

Organisers of the Goodwood Relays and Haywards Heath Open Cross Country races told Paul he could not take part in their events upon his first request but his tenacity won them over.

Paul sa. Organisers have to prove that I am more of a danger than anyone else to prevent me from running."

Paul has been in contact with England Athletics who are now working to improve their inclusion policy. Elspeth Turner, Club and Coach Support Officer at England Athletics sa“We have developed an Inclusion Policy and a Gu.”

England Athletics will now “seek to ensure that we comply with the Equality Act 2010 and that we encourage our affiliated members to do so.”

The documents are currently being drafted but the overall aim is to ensure that “athletes with disabilities can participate as fully as possible within athletics events.”

Paul’s achievements were recognised by England Athletics when he was awarded the South East Region Services to Disability Athletics Award. He is now due to be cons. Paul’s website can be found at www.disabledathlete.co.uk.

fields.title: New boy Ian third at Barns Green
fields.summary: Phoenix has a new star runner. Ian Leitch ran a superb race for third place in the Barns Green Half Marathon on Sunday 31 October. The race was won in record time by Kenyan Edwin Kipyego (1:04:28). Ian's time was 1:10:27 beating previ&

fields.content:
Phoenix has a new star runner. Ian Leitch ran a superb race for third place in the Barnes Green Half Marathon on Sunday 31 October. The race was won in record time by Kenyan Edwin Kipyego (1:04:28). Ian's time was 1:10:27 beating previous winner James Baker by 96 seconds. Ian is also the record holder at the Hove Park 5k TT and recently broke the course record for the Hove Prom 10k. Welcome to Phoenix Ian!

There were 1700 starters and a healthy turnout by Phoenix. We are waiting for final county placings and team awards but with Joe Francis running an excellent 1:20:27 (27th) and Bruce Faulkner1:21:55 (40th) as our scorers, we should be close to the medals.

Results

fields.title: Phoenix dominates at Hove Park third anniversary run
fields.summary: We put out a call to help celebrate the third anniversary running of the estimable Hove Park 5K time trials and boy d! Josh and Finn raced to the line for first and second place with just one second separating them. Josh's time 15:24. Fin

fields.content:
We put out a call to help celebrate the third anniversary running of the estimable Hove Park 5K time trials and boy d! Josh and Finn raced to the line for first and second place with just one second separating them. Josh's time 15:24. Finn's 15:25 was a PB just one of eight for Phoenix on the day. Dave Carter came 4th and Robbie Fitgibbon (JM14) 8th also with a PB (18:41).

From then on Phoenix kept rolling in - 23 completed the run with a 24th withdrawing with hamstring problems (yes me!). Further PBs were achieved by Chris Mills (10th 18:24), Reuben Hoyte (22nd 19:11), Archie Davis (30th 19:38), Ro Harrington (41st 20:31), Matt Berr(49th 20:41) and Will Russel (67th. 21:40).

In the top twenty fastest runs Phoenix are now 1st, 2nd, 5th, 8th, 13th, and 19th and hold six of the age-category records. We seem to have taken to this event big time.

Full results

fields.title: Phoenix at the British Triathlon Awards
fields.summary: Phoenix Triathletes' Lizzy Brama and Faye McClelland were invited to attend the British Triathlon Awards ceremony in honour of their last seasons phenominal performances.

fields.content:
Phoenix Triathletes Lizzy Brama and Faye McClelland were invited to attend the British Triathlon Awards ceremony in honour of their last season's phenomenal performances.

The ceremony, held in Hinckley, Leicestershire on Saturday 13th November wasattended by some ofthe countries greatest athletes, elites and age-groupers alike.

Lizzy Brama was honoured for her achievements havingranked third in the country after a string of good results in Olympic distance races in 2010.

She sa."

The 'bit of a change' seems to have pa, and she sa, and I'm really pleased with this result."

World Paratriathlete Champion, Faye McClelland was nominated for both the 'Paratriathlete of the Year' award and the 'Peter Holmes' award which honours inspirational performances in international competition.

Faye was the only female on an exclusive list of six athletes, which included World Champion Alistair Brownlee, who eventually took the award.

Faye sa'm so pleased with how my season has gone, so to be invited to the awards, and receive two nominations has made the year even better. Both athletes that won the awards were absolutely inspirationaland thoroughly deserved them."

The evening gave our star athletes a chance to step back and recognise their achievements. Lizzy sa's always nice to get recognition for all the hard work that we put in. It was a great evening, and a good chance to catch up with everyone out of the competitive environment."

Faye sa, very simply: "Triathlon is such an amazing sport, and I love being part of it."

fields.title: Phoenix Annual Races go ahead come rain or shine
fields.summary: The Phoenix annual races attracted well over three-hundred hopeful runners to Preston Park on Saturday despitean endless stream of drizzle and some chilly winds.

fields.content:
The Phoenix annual races attracted well over three-hundred hopeful runners to Preston Park on Saturday despitean endless stream of drizzle and some chilly winds.

There were twelve races in all, with juniors competing on a variety of increasing distances and seniors given a choice between the Fr, and a four lap 5 mile course.

Stealing the day were the17's boys, with Charlie Grice, William Durkin and Jake Elliot taking the threetop places.

This was the first year both men and woman took on a new 5 mile route. There wasa noticeable, but not deadly incline each lap,followed bya steady downhill section to prepare them for the next.

Finn McNally made yet another fantastic performance, coming second in the 5-mile race in 25.40, beaten only by Jon Pepper of Enfield and Haringey.

The women's results were somewhat dominated by Arena 80 ladies, led by Caroline Hoyte in a competitive 28.07. The first Phoenix female to cross the line was Liz Hall, followed by Gina McGeever who completed her race just half a minute after our leading lady.

The battle for first place between John Marinko and Nigel Herronin the one mile race prov, with John crossing the line just three seconds before Nigel, in 5.30.

Phoenix juniors put on a great show, takingtop positions in the races despite some tough competition with Samual Betts winning the under 11s boys race.

Teenagers from all the local clubs,it seemed, had alternative plans on a wet and windy Saturday, and there were fewer runners in the under 15s and under 17s races.

Despite low attendance, the Phoenix teens put on a great show, with Jody Mann in third, and Bethan K, and Billy White third in the under 15s boys.

The races could not have gone ahead without dedicated leadership from Andy Bone, who was busy organising willing helpers at 8am. Registration leader, Jackie Tucknott and marshal-marshaler Paul Caldicott also made a huge contribution, as well as marshalls Mariette Jackson, Suzanne Romney, Andrew Seivewright, Jane Edmands, Liz Hal, Dave Howe and Phil Savage.

Race officials from Sussex CAA also helped the day run smoothly, whilst sponsorship from Geneva Investment Group, Saucony, Fr.

Once again, a successful event organised by our club membersand a great opportunity for intermingling within the local running community.

Thanks to SussexSport Photography for the use of the images here. For your own momento of the day, click the link below.

Full Results

fields.title: Phoenix in Brussels (A Winter's Tale)
fields.summary: The club outing to Brussels on the weekend of 18-20 December was a great success, not just for the Phoenix athletes but also for the friends from Hastings, Crawley and Brighton and Hove who travelled with us. Those of you keeping an eye on the weather&

fields.content:
The club outing to Brussels on the weekend of 18-20 December was a great success, not just for the Phoenix athletes but also for the friends from Hastings, Crawley and Brighton and Hove who travelled with us. Those of you keeping an eye on the weather may be surprised to hear that we got there and back with relative ease, apart from a small group who missed the scheduled return Eurostar train. (No names, no pack drill)

We arrived just four hours late on Saturday evening, to find that Chairman Paul had managed to book us into four star luxury in the m. Time for a quick meal and just the one glass of beer before an early night (we are athletes after all).

The format for Sunday is that the Iris Lotto CrossCup, an IAAF Permit meeting takes place throughout the day with races for all age groups run on a 1KM course. At 12:30 there is also a two lap 5K/10k event involving 1200+ runners. Both courses were effected by compacted and falling snow and, in the circumstances, everyone ran exceptionally well. These races feature high quality European fields and we fitted right in. In fact, there are a few people who've put themselves in line for England cons. We were especially pleased to have Tim Bayley AND Priscilla Bayley running for us.

Running in the Minimes Filles category (1500m) Sian Bishop (Crawley) ran well for16th in 7:00

Kicking off for Phoenix were Billy White and Robbie Fitzgibbon running in the Cadets Garcons category (2,500m). Both were in fine form with Billy coming 8th in 8:52 and Robbie 11th in 9:03.

In the Scolaires Garcons category (4000m) Jake Elliot came an excellent 7th in 14:15.

The junior women (4000m) featured Crawley athlete Abigail Ashbee-Simmonds 10th in 16:14.

All eyes were then on the junior men (6000m) with the performance of the day coming from Hasting's Adam Clarke. He came third in a time of 19:38 beating most of the runners selected for England. Next up was our own Finn McNally in imperious form for a 20:15 9th placing. His was the best Phoenix run of the day. Having come back from dropping out in Liverpool he rebuilt himself to finish just behind the England team. He was followed in quick succession by Charlie Grice 14th 20:33, James McCarthy (B&H) 16th 20:49 and Max Pickard 20th 20:59. Jonas Wieneke running for his German club was 26th in 22:14.

The senior men's race was won by nine-times European Cross-Country champion Sergiy Leb (31:27) with just 3 seconds covering the first three finishers on the 10,500m course. For Phoenix Tim Bayley was our lead runner 39th in 34:33 with Josh Guilmant coming 49th in 35:27.

While all this was happening, the mass participation 10K and 5K races were taking place around outskirts of the park. Unfortunately we were unable to find our numbers and microchips so we won't appear in the results but they would have read something like this:

10K James Miles 13th 34:26, Andrew Haig 233rd 43:03. Both James and Andrew fell heavily in the icy conditions, so well done to them.

We can't quite locate the 5K results yet but Liz Durman ran an excellent 20+ (second woman), and Priscilla Bayley ran 22+.

Throughout we had great support from the other members of our party especially the Pickards, the Grices, the Fitzgibbons, Sarah Davey and Josh's girlfriend Elin who had lived in Brussels for several years and was able to help out with local knowledge.

That night, athletic circumspection was off and a good time was had by all. The town was looking fantastic with Christmas lights reflecting in the snow and the streets thronged with people. The night's celebration d't stop a group of younger athletes taking a run on the final morning. Most of those who made the first train back were then upgraded to a first . Travel chaos – what travel chaos?

Finally a big thank you to Chairman Paul, who organised the whole thing. What with the disrupted travel and the missing numbers, he had his work cut out and even had to miss out on his own race as dRobin Fitzgibbon as he helped to sort out the numbers fiasco.

The trip was a huge success and almost certain to be repeated next year – so watch this space.

fields.title: Sussex XC Champs – the lads done good.
fields.summary: With 39 Phoenix athletes competing across the board, the turnout was reasonable but it was the boys and young men that made most impact. Team of the day was the U17 men who with Charlie Grice 1st, Jake Elliot 2nd and &

fields.content:
With 39 Phoenix athletes competing across the board, the turnout was reasonable but it was the boys and young men that made most impact. Team of the day was the U17 men who with Charlie Grice 1st, Jake Elliot 2nd and Will Durkin 5th took team gold in . The U13 boys (Reuben Hoyte 6th, Matt Berr 9th and Isaac Wright 19th) won bronze just 1 pt away from silver. Joe Lillie, Will Russell and Joshua White in just his second ever race prov. Archie Davis would normally have been a scorer in this amazing team but, not feelig so good had to drop out on this occasion. The U15 boys boasted indivBilly White and with Robbie Fitgibbon 10th and Sam Kitchen 17th were bronze medal team (the results show them, inaccurately, in fourth position). Luke Reynolds ran strongly for 24th. Finally the junior men with Max Pickard 2nd, Finn McNally 3rd and Sam Wade 8th, picked up team silver.

No medals for the girls but there were good committed runs from Charlotte Matthews and Maria Andrews (U13); Jodie Mann, Amber Murr and Eve Tree (U15); Megan Lillie (U17).

Eleven runners lined up for the senior men but with vets accounting for two of the scorers, we were just adrift of the medals. Dave Carter was 9th, Josh Guilmant 11th, James Miles 18th with Bruce Warren 34th, Dav 39th and Chris Mills 43rd making up the team for fourth spot.

Good to see a full women's team competing and making fifth place.
The scorers were Liz Durman 15th, Erica Martin 16th, Faye McClelland 39th and Anita Jones 42nd. Liz Hall 48th and Deb Friis 54th prov.

Full results
