fields.title: Success at the Sussex Road Relays -Update U13’s Girls
fields.summary: Despite the cold wind and flurries of snow Phoenix was out in force for the Sussex Road Relays at Christ's Hospital School, held Sunday March 30th.

fields.content:
Despite the cold wind and flurries of snow Phoenix was out in force for the Sussex Road Relays at Christ’s Hospital School, held Sunday March 30th.


Phoenix entered 2 teams for the Senior Women races, 3 for the Under 13 Girls and 1 Under 15 girls. Phoenix led from the start in the Under 13 Girls race with Naomi Fonteyn recording the fastest lap of 6.43 with her team mate Almi Nerurkar a close second with 6.50.


The men’s teams were out in force with 2 teams entered for the Masters Men, Over 50 and Under 13 Boys races and 1 team for the Over 60 Men & Under 15 Boys.
In the Under 15s Archie Davis ran the fastest time in 5:39 to place Phoenix 5th.
3rd places were achieved in the Over 40 and 60 races with Bruce Warren running the fastest lap time of 11.23 for Over 50 Men.

The day ended in another high with the Senior Men storming to the lead to defend their title, winning in 59.08 with fastest laps from Charlie Grice (9:37) and Jon Pepper (9:41).


See Results Page for full results.


Well done to everyone who ran – you have earned your Easter Eggs!

Roy Hayward - U13’s Girls report


After a fantastic cross country season with the under 13’s team winning the Brooks Cross Cross Country League Championships, with Almi winning indiv.
Almi then went ok to win the indiv.
The girls followed this up last weekend with a brilliant win in the Sussex Road Relay, the U13’s team consisted of Almi, Naomi and Chloe who won the title with the B team taking a fantastic Bronze this consisted of Charlotte Matthews, Ateya Marshall and Louisa Saunders who had never run together as a team.
We turn our thoughts to track and field season with a lot of our younger team members moving up to Under 15’s. So who knows what we can achieve this summer with both age groups being represented at U13’s and U15’s girls.
Let’s hope the boys can step up this summer as well.

Roy

fields.title: Monster Mini Miles
fields.summary: The Iconiq Shlurp! Mini Mile Races, held April 12th saw over 2,200 children and young people battled it out in U18, U15, U13 and U11 Boys and Girls races....

fields.content:
Monster Mini Miles


Following on from their Cross Country success the Phoenix Girls showed the rest how it's done in the The Iconiq Shlurp! Mini Mile Races, held April 12th. Run on the final mile of the marathon course, over 2,200 children and young people battled it out in U18, U15, U13 and U11 Boys and Girls races.


Phoenix proudly saw around 50 entrants and results are still coming in.

Well done to Olivia Harding who came 1st position in her U11 Girls race with U13 runners Almi Nerurkar & Louisa Saunders placed 2nd & 3rd respectively in their races.
Not to be outdone by the Girls Alex Brothwell came 3rd in his U11 race.

Follow this link for more results

fields.title: Right on Brighton!
fields.summary: April 12th saw Brighton Phoenix member Jon Pepper run the 4th Brighton Marathon in a blistering 2 hours 20 minutes. Ensuring a new club record....

fields.content:
Right On Brighton!

April 12th saw Brighton Phoenix member Jon Pepper run the 4th Brighton Marathon in a blistering 2 hours 20 minutes. Ensuring a new club record, Jon was the first British runner to finish, coming eighth overall.His time broke Matt Patterson's time of 2:23:53 set way back in the early 1980s. Both Matt and Steve Ovett had been following the outcome of Jon's run and they sent their congratulations this week.

Further cause for celebration followed shortly after with Bruce Warren finishing 20th with a time of 2:52:15 and Liz Durman, making her marathon debut, coming 32nd in the women's race (3:26:28).

With 18,000 runners the marathon is now one of the top 12 events in the UK with televised race coverage and huge local support.

Keep watching Phoenix news as the Marathon record could well be under threat again this weekend as Iain Leitch is looking to challenge it. Could we have two club records in one week?

See results page for full results

fields.title: Euro Bronze for Erica !
fields.summary: Bronze medal in European Sprint Duathlon Champs

fields.content:
Erica Martin travelled to Horst in the Netherlands last weekend to represent Great Britain in the European Sprint Duathlon Champs and came away with a bronze medal in her age group . The winter training in cold wet conditions and braving the qualifier races has pa.

Well done Erica

Hi Brighton Phoenix Members

This is just a quick reminder that when entering races whether it is a track, road, cross country or triathlon please use the name Brighton Phoenix there is no need to add the AC or Tri on the end we all run under the same banner.

Happy racing

fields.title: Phoenix Plan For Steyning Triathlon: UPDATE!
fields.summary: On May 5th the Steyning triathlon was held, a pool based triathlon, offering a sprint and a standard course. The sprint is a 400m swim, followed by a 18.5km r.6km run. The standard course is 800m in the pool 35.1km bike and&

fields.content:
On May 5th the Steyning triathlon was held, a pool based triathlon, offering a sprint and a standard course. The sprint is a 400m swim, followed by a 18.5km r.6km run. The standard course is 800m in the pool 35.1km bike and 8km run to glory! Last year’s standard distance was won by our own Tom Hopkins who successfully defended his title this year.

The weather was cons’s near arctic conditions and Phoenix put in a strong field of athletes. Sean Scott, after qualifying for the World Duathlon Championships in Canada, had his eye on beating Tom this year and had been training hard at the Fr.

Additionally to the friendly rivalry we had a large field this year, keen, eager and ready to represent Phoenix in the triathlon of the year.

In the standard distance race we have:

• Tom Hopkins 1:35:45 (1)
• Sean Scott 1:38:45 (5)
• John Tindell 1:39:02 (7)
• Malcolm Hughes 1:44:15 (13)
• Emma Hughes 2:01:24 (63)
• Deborah Evers 2:13:03 (93)


And in the sprint distance we have:


• Wes Mechen 54:18 (4)
• Dav(16)
• Will Flewett 59:49 (19)
• Mark Walker 1:06:29 (62)
• Sophie Barton 1:09:59 (99)

Well done to all our members!

http://racetimingsystems.net/Results/Indiv.aspx?Id=1388

fields.title: Preston Park: Phoenix runners hold course records
fields.summary: Continuing her blistering start to the season, Almi Nerurkar broke the women's course record in the 3rd Preston Park Run held on May 4th.

fields.content:
Preston Park: Phoenix runners hold course records

Continuing her blistering start to the season, Almi Nerurkar broke the women's course record in the 3rd Preston Park Run held on May 4th.
Almi, who is not yet 13, ran the 5km course in 19mins20 to beat the women's record and score the highest age grade percentage (84.22%).

This means Phoenix are dominating the local run as both she and Ben Tickner hold the course records for Phoenix, with Ben taking the men's record in the first run (15mins40).

http://www.parkrun.org.uk/prestonpark/news/

On the same day Almi's friend Naomi Fonteyn was running at Hove Park where she finished third woman in 19:24, breaking Almi's week old JW14 record in the process. In the same event Bruce Warren ran a great pb to win the men's race in a time of 17:22 which puts him third in the VM50 rankings.

http://www.parkrun.org.uk/brighton/news/

fields.title: Sam Wade continues success at BUCS tri with Silver!

fields.content:
Sam Wade (Cardiff Metropolitan University) entered the British Universities Sprint Distance Championships last Sunday at St Mary's School, Calne, Wiltshire. With the belief that another medal maybe on the cards and he showed that all the hard graft he has been putting in over the winter has pa. A fantastic indiv.


Competing in the sprint event which is based on a 750m pool swim. 25k bike around the local area, followed by an out and back 5k run which appears to be closer to 6k. With entries apparently an all time high for the event (in excess of 500), the competition was going to be tough.

In fine sunny weather Sam took a progressive approach to the race exiting the swim in 9.16 for 8th place before moving up to 4th and just outs.12 and then on the run he made his move for the medals with the 3rd fastest of the day 18.30 but this only told half the story as he was locked in a three way battle for the win. Sam managed to out dip third by just over 1 second, in what must have been a very enjoyable race.

Well done Sam for bringing the boom!

Results hear

fields.title: See your name up in lights on the Brighton Phoenix website!!!!

fields.content:
See your name up in lights on the Brighton Phoenix website!!!!

Have you ever wondered how we get information on to the club website? Results, fixtures a breaking news story, or a great picture.

Well we need your help and it could not be simpler, if you think would look pretty good on the home page or know someone who’s results are going unnoticed all you need to do is email a message to our new media address and one of our budding reporters will pet it into a news story. We want to hear from you this is your club!

The website team now has its own address and are just waiting to hear from you!

Please contact:

brightonphoenixmedia@gmail.com

All that we ask is that you headline your message with one of the following:

FIXTURES
RESULTS
NEWS
GENERAL

It’s that simple,

fields.title: Phoenix fly at the Open
fields.summary: Some fantastic competing was seen at the Phoenix Open Track Meeting at Withdean Stadium, May 8th. Athletes of all ages competed in events ....

fields.content:
Some fantastic competing was seen at the Phoenix Open Track Meeting at Withdean Stadium, May 8th. Athletes of all ages competed in events from 100 metres, 800 metres, 1500 metres, 3 km and steeplechase runs to standing long jump and long jump.

Phoenix was out in force with record numbers of runners in the junior races.
In the closed 100m Sophia Warner narrowly missed the qualifying time for the World Para Athletics Championships with what was still a great run.
In the very competitive 800 metre BMCA race Matt Favers showed great ability to accelerate at pace in the last 50 metres to win.

Yet further success, in the form of personal bests, was seen for Billy White in the A race and Spencer Thomas looking good to win the B. And there was yet another outstanding front run by Almi Nerurkar in the under 13 girls 800 metres.

fields.title: Bigg News!
fields.summary:
This Sunday the first of the Outdoor Track Internationals of the season take place at Loughborough University.
We are also very pleased to announce that Brighton Phoenix coach Jon Bigg has been selected...

fields.content:
Bigg News!

This Sunday the first of the Outdoor Track Internationals of the season take place at Loughborough University.

We are also very pleased to announce that Brighton Phoenix coach Jon Bigg has been selected as one of the two Endurance Coaches for the England Senior Team. He will be partnered by Jeremy Freeman who just also happens to be a former Brighton Phoenix athlete. Congratulations and good luck to them both. In his running career Jon represented England at Junior and Senior Level including tours to Australia and China.

But it doesn't stop there as in July Jon Bigg has been selected as Endurance Coach for the GB team for the European Under 23 Championships in Finland.

fields.content:
Grice tipped as one to watch

Check out June’s edition of Runner’s World for a feature on our own Charlie Grice, tipped to be “one of the 50 best things in running” (p.48)
Coached by Jon Bigg you can find more info on Charlie's page:


http://charliegrice.com/

fields.title: Spring in their step!
fields.summary: The spring bank holPhoenix athletes were out in force throughout the Country and further afield....

fields.content:
Spring in their step!

The spring bank hol.

Saturday 25th May saw Sophie Barton come 5th in her category in the Dorney Super Sprint whilst Arundel Triathlon on 26th had 3 Phoenix entrants; for the Standard distance Steven Johnson & Liz Hall (hot from her first win last week in her new age category!) & in the Sprint Bob Novis, finishing a respectable 7th.

The Grendon Sprint Tri, Northamptonshire, is the open water swim qualifier race for the European Triathlon series. Our own Debs Evers finished in a storming 1:33:26.

Further afield, Paule Kremer & Ben Tickner came 1st & 2nd respectively in Paule's local 10k in Berdorfer, Luxemburg.

Back at home Charlie Grice again showed us he's "the one to watch" finishing 1st in the British Athletics One Mile Road Championships in Westminster in a time of 4:02. Terry Avey came 3rd (6:07) and Liam Chessell 34th (6:03) in their age categories and Robbie Fitzgibbon was second in the junior men's race in a time of 4:16.

And last, but by no means least, the Rye 10 Mile, which is part of the Sussex Grand Prix & boasts the only 10 mile road race in Sussex, saw Bruce Warren take another win in his age category with Tom Fars finishing 16th. Not to be out done, Andrew Haig also finished first in his category, one up from his second place at the Horsham 10k.

http://www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results

fields.title: Gold in them there hills
fields.summary: Phoenix battled it out on the South Downs Way relay on Saturday 1st June to win two golds, a silver and a bronze.  The annual event sees teams of 6 running

fields.content:
Gold in them there hills!

Phoenix battled it out on the South Downs Way relay on Saturday 1st June, to win two golds, a silver and a bronze. The annual event sees teams of 6 running 3 gruelling legs each of between 4 and 8 miles. Covering a total of 95 miles from Beachy Head, near Eastbourne, to Chilcomb, Winchester this race tests even the toughest resolve.

The race has separate categories for A teams, B teams, Vets teams and Women's teams. The Phoenix A team (seniors) and B team both won gold and the men's vets team won silver. The women were in bronze position.The reports below are sent from the runners:

It was another good SDW relay day good conditions although the NNW wind made some bits quite hard, particularly on the early legs. This being an odd numbered year, 2013, the course was over the tougher Seven Sisters route. The team achieved its best time to date over this harder of the two routes. Two new Brighton Phoenix Ladies records were achieved, these were by Liz Durman on leg 1 and Paule Kremer on leg12. All ran close to or better than the predicted times I had set and we finished 5:11 quicker than our total predicted time.
Our overall time was 13:39:49 - 3rd overall.
Our senior men made an A team in all respects that produced fast running and a fast driver to win the overall and the A team competition - very impressive and next year they'll go for the record.

Our B team also took gold in the B Team competition.
Our vet men won silver the Vet Team competition.
A great turnout with a very good showing from our club - well done all.
Best wishes and Happy Running to all
Liz Hall

Malcolm has raced well over a dozen South Downs Way relays but his hunger for it never seems to diminish. We had a sweepstake in our van based on estimates for each leg and Malcolm walked away with the thirty qu, beating us all by (literally) a country mile. Not bad for a sixty-something. Jim gave us a good start on the stunning but murderous ups and downs of the Seven Sisters and completed a tough trio with legs 7 and 13. He also had to contend with the realisation that he would be sharing his third leg with Ben and Don! Andrew had an even tougher set, including the long 17, and held the team together superbly. John enjoyed a fine debut and Phil was reliable as ever, wrapping up with a strong leg 18 (and definitely finished with the cleanest teeth). I struggled through most of the day but was pleased to see off Butser hill and make it to the end of my three legs. We were naturally delighted to discover that we had won gold in the B team category. Arena 80 were our main rivals and it turned out we had pipped them by three minutes, even though we had not seen them at all as they had set off an hour after us. It would have been great to have raced them for 100 miles, something to ponder next year perhaps. Big thanks to Alan for somehow squeezing past vans coming the other way on lanes one-and-a-half vans wDave for sterling work on the timing and navigating.
Lance Bellers, B Team Captain

For a great perspective on the event, see Jon Pike's excellent Guardian blog

fields.title: The Phoenix Has Risen
fields.summary: Just months after being overlooked for the UK team for the European Indoor Championships Charlie Grice has been picked for the 1500m spot in the UK team for the European Team Champiosnhips.

fields.content:
Just months after being overlooked for the UK team for the European Indoor Championships Charlie Grice has been picked for the 1500m spot in the UK team for the European Team Championships.

This comes a week after he ran a pb of 3:38:13 in the IAAF match at Hengelow in Holland putting him 2nd on this years UK rankings, 50th on the UK all time lists for seniors, 3rd on the Phoenix all time lists and 7th on uk all time U23 list

At just 19 years old Charlie is now the UK's number 1 choice for 1500m.

This is a significant moment in our club's history and represents a lot of hard work from not just Charlie but also a major input from his coach Jon Bigg and all those others at the club who have supported Charlie – specifically Dave Howe, Paul Collicutt, Joel K and Tim Bayley.

The Phoenix has risen!


http://www.britishathletics.org.uk/media/news/12-06-13-european-athletics-team-championships/

fields.title: Team Phoenix brutally efficient at the Sussex Road Relays
fields.summary: A late review of the Senior Men’s Sussex Road Relays and a look back over the past years results

fields.content:
A late review of the Senior Men’s Sussex Road Relays and a look back over the past years results

If anyone thought that the senior men’s team would become complacent after decimating the Sussex Road relays 16 year old record last year they were in for a shock even without Senior Honey Badger and indiv.
The great thing about the Sussex Road Relays is it brings together all Team Phoenix’s athletes whether you’re an track star, marathon man or gearing up for the tri season, you are treated to just over 2 miles of speed induced pain fortunately the only real pain going to be experienced was by anyone wanting to take the title away.

You may have missed the significances of how good a result this was if you had read the Sussex Athletics report so hear is the blow by blow account.
Leading into this race it was obvious that the main threat was going to come from the talented Hastings team and that we would be in for a good race, but with several withdraws of their key members it became clear that it was going to be Phoenix vs Brighton show down for the gold.

With the rumour that Hastings big gun Adam Clark would be on first leg Phoenix chose to blood there latest super talented U17 Robbie Fitzgibbon who has been a revelation over the last year. After not looking too happy at having to run C team last year Robbie jumped up about 10 levels in performance and produced what must be an U17 record of 9.52 chancing down the inform Sam Bennett of Lewes AC with Brighton’s Ian Crowe-Wright coming in a strong third. Darryl Hards who just missed out on a spot in the A team after having a fantastic first proper winter back running since his junior days. Darryl suffered a little in the first mile not being used to the speed of a fast start just coming off cross country training but still came home in 10.13 for 5th place. With Jon Tindell (C Team) having his first taste of a Sussex relays championship off the back of a very heavy training session running 12.19

Dan Stepney after being given the nod for the final spot in the A team showed he was going to give it everything and by far had the best run of any race outs. Dan went off in hunt of the Lewes athlete Josh Burgess and it was not long before he was out in front and pushing hard, by the end of his leg he looked white as a sheet, although this had far more to do with his willingness to push himself to the max than the light snow showers we were experiencing.

At this point Sam Kitchen (U17) was making good progress for the B team and was secretly locked in a battle with club mentor Joel K.49, a good run for Sam. Joel’s course PB of 9.44 will however be safe for a couple more years.

Will Durkin took over the running on leg 3 and it was much the same, pedal to the metal and with no one but himself to beat it was battle the elements and put some more time into the chasing teams, he finished in 10.00 flat a very good run!

Jon Pepper has tasted nothing but Gold in Sussex competitions was eager to keep his 100% winning record in all team events over the last couple of years and this also served to test his speed ahead of the season’s main target the Brighton Marathon going off hard it was clear Jon was in very good shape finishing in a fresh 9.41 and still with a 14mile marathon effort to do! Second fastest time of the day.

Josh Guilmant took over for the penultimate leg and although not in the form of last year still brought a 9.58 out of his locker, a run of 9 years unbroken in this event. Although with the improvement of the team a time that would rank as one of the fastest overall legs in years gone by is now only an entry requirement to the Phoenix A team.

The B Team were chopping and changing in position still trying to hang on to the bronze they won last year Finn McNally put in an impressive 10.16 off limited training with Triathlete Wes Mechen having his first taste of the relays and probably the shortest race he has ever run is a sol.49 off a long bike r. Max Pickard and Sean Scott rounded off the B team with strong performance and a credible 6th place against a much improved opposition from the other competing county teams.

Last up for the A Team was track star Charlie Grice who has been pilling in the training in the lead up to an important track season where he intends to establish himself in the senior ranks, and he took off with just that fiery intent, like a hamster denied his wheel for a week he put in the fastest time of the day 9.37 Boom! This gave the team a final clocking of 59.08 and a massive 4m.02s win over Brighton with Lewes coming in for a well deserved Bronze.

fields.summary: Phoenix's Marina Re& Field Championships....

fields.content:
Phoenix's Marina Re sprang to first place in the long jump at the Sussex Schools Track & Field Championships at the Crawly K2 Centre.

Jumping 4.95 metres in the Junior Girls section Marina added this to her County Indoor Title back in February 2013

http://www.sussexathletics.org.uk/results.php#365

fields.title: Archie Davis: breaking records
fields.summary: After breaking the Sussex Track & Field Championships Boys U15 800m record back in May, Archie Davis has continued his good form over the last few weeks.

fields.content:
Archie Davis: breaking records

After breaking the Sussex Track & Field Championships Boys U15 800m record back in May, Archie Davis has continued his good form over the last few weeks.

On Wednesday night, at the BMC races in Eltham, he ran a personal best time of 1m 59.2 to break the 27 year all time Sussex U15 Boys 800m record....faster than Steve Ovett & Charlie Grice at that age!


In July Archie will be competing in the English Schools 800m in Birmingham where he has high hopes of another good performance.

fields.title: Phoenix on fire!
fields.summary: Last week was always going to be significant for our club with 19 years old Charlie Grice representing Great Britain in the European Team Championships in Gateshead..... but his performance wasn't the only highlight.

fields.content:
Phoenix on fire!

This last week was always going to be significant for our club with 19 years old Charlie Grice representing Great Britain in the European Team Championships in Gateshead..... but his performance wasn't the only highlight.

First of all, hats off to Charlie for a stunning run to come 2nd in a field rammed full of seasoned European Stars. The youngest in the field, he showed great maturity, intelligence and courage.

Earlier in the week Almi Nerurkar ran 4:51 for 1500m in an English Schools Cup Match in Croydon. This time places her on top of the UK under 13 rankings so far this year.

In Eltham, Archie Davis broke 2mins for 800m and the Sussex County Under 15 record....so faster than Grice and faster than Ovett at that age...not bad Mr.Davies!

Also at Eltham, Robbie Fitzgibbon ran a brave 1500m race to set a new PB of 3:52 and just oh so narrowly missed out on a World Youth Games qualifying time. At the weekend he bounced back with a bronze in the 1500m at the Southern U20 Champs in Watford, in his first year in this age group.

At these same champs, in the seniors, Dan Stepney won a silver in the 800m and Team Captain Josh Guilmant ( The Mighty Gu! ) outsprinted the opposition to take the Southern 5kms Championship to add to his Sussex Title.

The Phoenix is on fire and we've only just started this season so buckle up and be prepared for more great results this year!

fields.title: Paule: a trispeed champ!
fields.summary: Fantastic news for Paule Kremer in winning the Luxembourg Trispeed challenge in the elite category...read on for her race report....

fields.content:
Luxembourg Trispeed challenge

I ran a 10 k pb on Fr.35 and came third so I thought I would die
the next two days because I pushed it too hard but I managed to be 5
minutes quicker in the triathlon than last year to finish third again (even
though my swim was horrible, I managed to get one girl on the bike and two
on the run!).

As for the duathlon, I was worried that I was just holding on for dear
life as I really felt tired. We had to cycle the triathlon loop four
times instead of two - it nearly killed me in the triathlon so I was
worried about cycling up that massive hill four times.

As I was not aware that it was also the national duathlon championships I
quickly had to find a trilux trisuit so had to drive around
Luxembourg for an hour before the race to pick one up or I would have
been disqualified. I was told before the race that I was only allowed to draft the women and Paulo pointed the women out to me I was supposed to run with. One of them
was the clear favourite - I know her as she is usually the only woman
to cycle the tour de Luxembourg (with the men!!). I was able to run with
them and even come second on the first 6 k run. I tried to catch the
first woman on the bike to work together and draft her but I could not
close the gap. Then Sandra (the favourite) joined me after half a lap on the
bike and told me to stay at her wheel. I hung on for dear life until we
caught the first woman and we cycled in a group for a while, taking turns
drafting off each other but I quickly realized that both women were way out
of my league so I had to let them go. Sandra cycled off like a maniac and
disappeared and I was able to sight the second woman for a while finishing
only 20 seconds behind her on the bike.

Now, the best news was that I had a really good last run and I can now
call myself national vice champion in the elite (senior) category as the
second woman is a master (vet here). Who would have thought that I would
ever get a title when cycling is involved?! I got a fancy medal and they
played the national anthem. Thought it was quite funny as I thought I would
not even reach the third day of the challenge! On top of that, I also won the whole challenge in the elite category!
Walking anywhere is impossible at the moment so I am just sitting in a
chair with my medal around my neck.
I also got a mention and a picture in the national newspaper, I really
like the picture as it shows the final position between the three of us
(this one was taken on the first lap of the run - featured)

http://www.tageblatt.lu/sport/story/Lieners-und-Huberty-holen-Titel-26752584

I will definitely do this one next year again! I now have a reputation for
being the girl with a beer in her hand as soon as each of the races was
finished but I attribute that to my quick recovery!

http://www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results

fields.title: Phoenix in Alanya
fields.summary: June 11th - 12th saw the ETU Triathalon Championships in Alanya Turkey in which Malcolm Hughes represented the GB Age Groupers. A massive well done to him & to Colin Simpson, Debbie Evers & Tim Woodman who also competed.

fields.content:
Below are excerpts from Malcolm's report - full report can be found on the forum.

The swim was a long rectangle out from the pontoon then back to the beach. The sea was pretty flat so sighting was not difficult and I was in a group of 7 or 8 a bit back from the leaders. 6th on the swim, but the group was pretty much together.
T1 was easy. No wetsuit, no number belt, just helmet on and grab the bike.
I came out on to the bike with a Swiss who quickly found a younger GB wheel to hang on to and he disappeared up the road. I got into a steady rhythm and the flat course and light wind helped but the road surface was not great, about half block paving and the rest patchy tarmac for four laps. After the last turn I spotted the Swiss up ahead and I was catching him, that wheel he was on earlier must have already finished. I was 6th on the bike.
Started the run with the Swiss and we were together for 3 of the 4 laps. On each lap there was a short but quite steep climb otherwise it was fairly flat route through the bazaar. There were also 2 water stations on the lap and I poured most of the water I picked up over my head in an effort to keep cool. My running shoes were cleaner at the end of the race than at the start, and wetter. A quick glance at my watch showed 31 minutes for the first 3 laps of the run, at the start of the 4th lap the Swiss kicked and I had no response. I also got passed by another Brit in the last km. I slowed by about a minute on that final lap.
Overall I was pleased with the time and I enjoyed the race. Looking back I wonder if I pushed the bike a bit too hard and so losing a bit on the run, but at the time it felt right. In any case I was never going to get close to a medal as they were all 2:01's

My splits are below
8 1315 Malcolm Hughes GBR 0:26:02( 6) 0:00:42 1:00:41( 6) 0:00:39 0:42:59( 12) 2:10:22

Full results
http://www.alanyatriathlon2013.com/results.html

fields.title: "All Time" best at Anniversary Games
fields.summary: Charlie Grice (Phoenix) and Lee Emanuel (Hastings) battled it out again in the 61st running of the Emsley Carr Mile at the Anniversary Games, held at the Olympic Stadium&

fields.content:
Charlie Grice (Phoenix) and Lee Emanuel (Hastings) battled it out again in the 61st running of the Emsley Carr Mile at the Anniversary Games, held at the Olympic Stadium on Saturday 27 July.

In a truly competitive international battle, where the first 16 runners all cracked the four-minute barrier, the two Sussex runners were again virtually neck and neck down the finishing strait. In front of a capacity crowd Charlie dug deep, finishing 13th in 3:54.61 to Lee's 14th (3:54.73), improving his PB by a massive three seconds!

Charlie and Lee are now elevated to fourth and fifth places on the Sussex "All Time" list behind Steve Ovett, Mark Rowland, and Tim Hutchings.

This is such a superb result for the Phoenix man, who raised his game to show his talent on an international stage.

fields.title: Just another Manic Sunday
fields.summary: Think one triathlon is hard? How about doing a double?! August 4th saw Phoenix athletes doing just that at the Wealdon Manic Triathlon.

fields.content:
Think one triathlon is hard? How about doing a double?! August 4th saw Phoenix athletes doing just that at the Wealdon Manic Triathlon.


Thank you to Colin Simpson for his report;


A few of us dec. The event is a double triathlon; 300m swim, 11K bike, 3K run....then do it all again... (could also be done as a relay)
The venue is a private house with a small lake and whilst numbers were limited there are always a few fast guys and girls.

The swim was done in small waves of 10-15 in a warmish lake. Wetsuits were optional and most went for the ‘naked' option mainly because for the second swim you would probably have to go without a wetsuit (although apparently a couple of people d...mmm difficult). I dec't...much to his disappointment..... as I came out ahead of him!! Unfortunately he passed me up the 200m hill run to transition as I stopped to whip the wetsuit off. Bob was long gone...

The bike was an undulating 10.5K. It was a pretty fast course despite some poor road surfaces. Both Bob and Ro had similar splits (2nd and 4th best) with me a couple of minutes down.

The run was also undulating around the grounds. 2x1.5K, off road and rutted which proved awkward in places. I dec...too busy thinking about that second swim without a wetsuit...but luckily was called back without losing too much time. Bob seemed to have a storming run (3rd fastest I believe) and Ro also ran well as we all completed our first triathlon.

Now the fun started.... another swim...shall I keep my trainers on for the 200m run down to the lake? No, better not, I will forget them...so I go barefoot and just grab hat and goggles and go for it. As I exit transition the marshal and I simultaneously notice that I still have my shades on - not great for swimming so back I go and take the opportunity to t/run later. Note I wasn't the only one to have problems of this type!!

The swim for me was much slower without a wetsuit and still in oxygen debt but Ro and Bob seemed to cope much better.

Onto the bike and I actually felt quite good and seemed to be going faster on the descent into Framfield but on the small climb to the village I got slower and that fateful bump bump happened as my rear tyre deflated... end of race for me so I walked back but dec!!
Both Bob and Ro almost matched their earlier results on Bike and Run to secure 2nd and 10th places overall.....not bad for a couple of old vets.

This was a good fun race which, with a few tweaks, would be worth doing next year.

Full Results here (Swim includes run to transition, Bike includes both other transitions)

http://www.hedgehogtri.co.uk/web/hedgehogtri/results/2013/Manic/NewplacePark_manicTris_20130804_v0.pdf

fields.title: Tank Track & Windmills
fields.summary: Thursday 22nd August saw Phoenix members run up the hill to the Jack & Jill Windmills at Clayton.

fields.content:
Tank Track & Windmills

Thursday 22nd August saw Phoenix members run up the hill to the Jack & Jill Windmills at Clayton. Rather than a pale of water they collected points then ran down again (although I felt like tumbling!). After a short recovery jog & chat it was all done again.

Equal first on points for the climbs were: Andrew Neighbour, Paule Kremer and Phil Hampshire each with 4 points.
Clear winner for the descents was Andrew Neighbour with 2 points followed by Paule Kremer with 4 points.
Combined winner was therefore Andrew Neighbour with 6 and second was Paule Kremer who was of course first woman.

Well done to all those who took part: Andrew N, Paule, Phil, Anita, Malcolm, Andrew H, Colin & Kathryn.

Grateful thanks to Liz Hall for devising & organizing and Erica Martin, Jane Edmonds and Phil's Jeanette for helping with point handing out and shepherding of the breathless runners.

fields.title: Paul Lawrence achieves new PB at Maidenhead Half Marathon
fields.summary: Paul Lawrence raced the Ma. Here is his brief account:

fields.content:
This was a well-organised race, with about 2000 runners. It is pretty much flat, and has good PB potential.There is plenty of free parking right by the start and it took me about 75 mins to drive there from Brighton. The first mile, through the town centre, is a bit twisty and at one point near the start everyone has to go under a pedestrian underpass, so make sure you're near the front at that point. The route is then two laps along the river/through countrys've time to notice. The race seemed to attract a lot of good London-based runners, especially in the V40 category, so there were always people to run against. Overall, a good alternative half to Barns Green or Chichester for those looking to race one in late summer/early autumn.

Full Results Here

fields.title: Bob Novis: World Champ!
fields.summary: September 11 - 15th saw London host the Pru Health World Triathlon Grand Final. Using an , around 5000 athletes raced.

fields.content:
Bob Novis: World Champ

September 11 - 15th saw London host the Pru Health World Triathlon Grand Final. Using an , around 5000 athletes raced.


Athletes for the world championship races qualified in order to race. Phoenix's own Bob Novis, racing in the 60-64 age category, qualified in the Nottingham Triathlon in June.

With a 750 m swim, a 20 km bicycle and a 5 km run Bob stormed to the finish in London to become World champ in 1.13.45 (splits below).

This adds to many other titles such as his gold in the 2007 ITU World Triathlon in Germany and title of British Triathlon Age Group Athlete of the year in 2002. This year alone he's won his age group in a whole string of races including the Worthing 20M race (March). He came 7th overall at Arundel Triathlon short course (May), 2nd at the Wealdon Manic Triathlon (August) and 4th overall at Ringmer Triathlon (August).... a true Champ!

fields.title: Castle Conquered!
fields.summary: 1st place for Charlotte Mathews who competed in what is believed to be the world's  largest ever Children's Triathlon at Hever Castle on Saturday 28th  September.

fields.content:
Castle Conquered!


Charlotte Matthews competed in what is believed to be the world's largest ever Children's Triathlon at Hever Castle on Saturday 28th September.


Charlotte competed in the 13-15 age group and came in 12th place overall and 1st girl with a finish time of 58:34. The setting was delightful; a lake swim (300m) followed by a woody and hilly cycle r(8km) and ending with a cross country run (4km).


Coming out of the lake Charlotte had a bit of a struggle with the wetsuit zip, but she overcame this with a fast cycle r. A fast T2 and Charlotte was off into her strongest discipline when she was able to run into first placed girl in her Wave. With a second wave of 13-15yr olds and some technical problems with the chip timing the final results were not out until Monday evening.


Splits : Swim 07:13, T1 01:53, Cycle 26:04, T2 01:12, Run 22:09

fields.title: Jon Pepper run’s Club Record 2.19.10 Marathon

fields.content:
Jon is one determined indiv!

This week the hard work and dedication to a lifelong dream pa(12th) in a new club record of 2.19.10 taking 80 seconds off the record and putting his name next to Phoenix legends Steve Ovett (800/1500m) and Mark Rowland (steeple Chase) .

fields.title: Tri Star champ honoured
fields.summary: Charlotte Matthews receives award for her commitment, sportsmanship and sporting improvement during 3 years of attendance at the Tri Star events

fields.content:
Charlotte Matthews has been competing in Triathlons since 2010 when she entered her first event with HedgehogTri at Ringmer. She has progressed through the age categories of Tri-Star 1, 2 and finally Tri-Star 3.


On 7th November Hedgehog tri group presented Charlotte with an award as a fitting way to end her period of competing in these children's events.


Charlotte attended a short presentation in Haywards Heath together along with 2 adult winners and a boy from Tri-Star 1. Charlotte was relieved that she d't have to give a speech - a smile and say thank you was sufficient!


The cup winners were voted by the Hedgehogtri Team for the commitment, sportsmanship and improvement shown during their attendance at the K. The cups are set up in memory of Vera Tigg, Aunt of the Hedger family, who passed away two years ago. This is the first year these cups have been presented and this will be an annual event, winners keep the cup for 12 months. She was presented with a mini version of the cup to keep. Charlotte was thrilled to be the first to have her name on the cup.

Phoenix salutes you Charlotte and is proud to have you as a member... here's to next season!

fields.content:
Phoenix Awards

Phoenix celebrated the success of its athletes on Saturday 7th December with a glittering awards evening. Held at the Park View in Preston Park, the packed event pa, improvement or commitment.

In the spirit of the Oscars, Phoenix would like to say a HUGE thank you to Rich Moult, Josh Guilmant and Andy Bone for organising the event, ensuring it was such a well attended success. Huge thanks also to our Club Chairman Paul Collicutt for being Master of the Ceremonies.

The Lee Valley Open is a competition for under 13/15 athletes covering disciplines such as 60m hurdles, 60m / 200m / 800m run, high jump, long jump and shot putt.

Senior athletes battled it out at the Sussex Masters Championships at Lancing, Saturday 18th. Although sunny on the day, the recent rain resulted in the runners battling some slippery, hilly terrain.

Races comprised of O50 and O60 men (5 miles), O34 & 40 women (4 miles) and O40 men (6 miles).

Bruce Warren put in another amazing performance in the O50 men to take silver by 1 second in 32.24. This places the O50 Men's A Team in bronze position with Phoenix B & C placed 9th & 10th.

Phoenix O60 Men continue their reign and are now placed in silver position in the overall rankings however it is tight at the top - there being only 1 point between them and Bronze.

Phoenix O40 Men and O35 Women have both put in sol. It is good to see Louise picking up form and the return of Anita!
O45 women - you're club needs you! A complete team next time could place you on the score board....

fields.title: Charlie on a mission
fields.summary: Charlie Grice has got off to a flying start in the indoor season coming third in the Indoor International at Glasgow last Saturday and seventh tonight at the International Athletics meeting at Dusseldorf.

fields.content:
Charlie on a mission

Charlie Grice has got off to a flying start in the indoor season coming third in the Indoor International at Glasgow last Saturday and seventh tonight at the International Athletics meeting at Dusseldorf.

Glasgow International, in which athletes from Great Britain, Scotland, USA and a Common Wealth select team compete, saw an exciting 1500m race with Charlie sticking to the leader Chris O'Hare until the final strait where he was piped at the post to third. With just seven one hundredths of a second between first, second and third you could say there was 3 golds!

Final Times:
Chris O'Hare (Scotland): 3:48.62
James Magut (commonwealth): 3:48.65
Charlie Grice (GB): 3:48.69

Dusseldorf International tonight saw Charlie compete against Athletes from all over the world , including reigning Commonwealth Champion Silas Kipligat. Charlie refused to be intim.

https://twitter.com/CharlieGrice1

Phoenix runners Almi Nerurkar and Naomi Fonteyn continue their cross county campaign.

At the South East Inter-counties cross-country event at Southampton, on Saturday, it was Naomi who finally gained the upper hand over her team mate, finishing 11th to Almi's 19th.

fields.title: Too tight to mention!
fields.summary: Another riveting weekend as Charlie Grice, coached by our own Jon Bigg, took to the track at the British Indoor Championships at Sheffield.

fields.content:
Too tight to mention!

Another riveting weekend as Charlie Grice, coached by our own Jon Bigg, took to the track at the British Indoor Championships at Sheffield. As the athletes set off they understood that winning meant qualification for the World Championships in Poland in March.

The top three British Athletes, Charlie Grice, Chris O'Hare and Lee Emanuel, showed how closely matched they were coming within one hundredth of a second apart in Glasgow last month and Sheffield proved no different......
With all three taking the lead throughout the race, Charlie was again locked in a battle at the last 600metres and was again pipped at the post within one hundredths of a second between 1st, 2nd and 3rd. It's too tight to mention!

Lee Emanuel: 3:84:15
Chris O'Hare: 3:48:68
Charlie Grice: 3:48:69

Hats off to also to Robbie Fitzgibbon, placed eighth in his heat of the 1,500m in 3:56.50.


http://www.britishathletics.org.uk/media/news/2014-news-page/february-2014/09-02-14-sheffield-report-2/

fields.content:
Peppered with success

In one of the tightest finishes ever at the Chichester 10K Jon Pepper took second place. As the first Sussex runner across the line he now becomes County Champion.

It was a three-way battle to the line at the Chichester 10K race on February 9th with Phoenix's Jon Pepper coming second to Philip Wylie (Bristol) who won in 30:23 to Jon's 30:26. Third was Paul Whittaker (Southend) in 30:27. The event doubled as the county 10K championships and although those results have not yet been announced, as first Sussex runner home Jon will be county champion.

Huge congratulations to Jon and also to Bruce Warren (35:53) who is having a great stretch of form. He won the M50 race outright and of course the county championship in that category.

fields.title: Medals in the mud
fields.summary: The final Sussex League x-country league race was held at Bexhill on Saturday 1st March and the course, which is normally very muddy, was even more challenging than normal following weeks of rain. Just staying vertical and finishing with both shoes was

fields.content:
Medals in the mud

The final Sussex League x-country league race was held at Bexhill on Saturday 1st March and the course, which is normally very muddy, was even more challenging than normal following weeks of rain. Just staying vertical and finishing with both shoes was an achievement!


Being the last race of the season, both indivU13 girls who started the day winning both indiv. On the day the race winner was Almi Nerurkar followed by Naomi Fonteyn in 2nd, Holly Luscombe 7th, Saoirse McGuinness 16th, Francesca White 23rd Connie Jankowski 24th and Leanne Battmann 25th. Almi won the indiv, Naomi and Holly. It must, however, be noted that although only three runners score in the team all runners contribute towards the team success as every Phoenix runner that finishes ahead of a competitor can assist with the team score. The girls have managed to field several runners in each race and all should be congratulated.


Unfortunately attendance hasn't been so good in all races in other categories. In the U13 boys there were only two Phoenix runners, where the ever present Joel Luscombe and Zac Elbourne finished 17th and 22nd, with the boy's team finishing 9th place in the league.


In the U15 girls race again there were only two finishers. Charlotte Matthews had a fine run to finish 2nd and the ever present Anna Berry d. Although only in the first year of this age group, Charlotte's run helped her to secure indiv, with the team finishing in 5th place.


Oliver Johnson was the only Phoenix runner in the U15 boys race and had an excellent run to finish 2nd. This helped the team secure league silver medals. Although not running, as the indiv, Reuben Hoyte won the indiv.


Another fine 2nd place on the day went to Jake Alger in the u17 Men, narrowly losing out to the indiv. The team finished 5th overall.


The ladies were led home by Erica Martin in 18th placing her silver in the indiv's medals. Despite the also valiant efforts of Anita Jones 46th, Hildi Mitchell 62nd and Amanda Mello-Costa 76th the ladies finished 8th, which will probably result in a division 2 place next year. The veteran ladies team finished 11th.


The senior's men team started the day only a few points away from silver medal position and well clear from the 4th place team, so at least a bronze medal looked guaranteed. However with no senior runners in attendance it was left to the veteran runners, not for the first time, to try and secure a senior team medal position. Unfortunately despite their efforts, with Haywards Heath fielding a strong team they just missed out on bronze by 10 points, finishing with 884 to the Haywards Heath 3rd place 874. The team were led home by Bruce Warren (V50) in 18th followed by Donald Maclellan (v40) in 34th, Nigel Herron (v40) 52nd, Jon Wright (v50) 68th, Jim Whitelehgg (v40) 70th, Andrew Neighbour (v40) 97th. The veteran's team d's league and Bruce Warren won indiv.


There were also several Phoenix runners representing Brighton District in an inter area race at the start of the day. Results have not been published yet but well done to all those Phoenix runners that took part.


For full results http://www.sussexathletics.org.uk/results.php#407


A massive thank you to Bruce Warren for this report.

fields.title: Phoenix in the Elites
fields.summary: Charlotte Matthews took part in the Youth event at the British Elite Duatlon Championships 2014 at the Rockingham Motor racing Circuit in Corby on Sunday 30 March.

fields.content:
Phoenix in the Elites

Charlotte Matthews took part in the Youth event at the British Elite Duatlon Championships 2014 at the Rockingham Motor racing Circuit in Corby on Sunday 30 March.


Charlotte was one of the youngest competitors, falling into the youth age group for the first time by only 3 months.


It was a big step up from the children's tri-star events that she has enjoyed over the last few years but she approached it with excitement, some nerves and great maturity. It was an early start at 09:00 on the line, and with the morning mists just clearing it was a little nippy.


There were 37 registered for the event although only 33 made it to the start line, with some familiar (and perhaps daunting) names from the cross country and triathlon scene.


Charlotte d(2.45km) coming into T1 in 17th place. She had a good transition; all the practicing at the cycle track with a running mount and elastic bands holding the cycle shoes in place paying off.


The cycle r. Although drafting was allowed, Charlotte d't manage to get herself in with a group of cyclists to maintain her earlier position. Still, she stuck it out there and with a good dismount she was on her way to the short 1.25km run. Her determination and enthusiasm remained to the end with a final sprint in the home straight she overtook a competitor to come in 27th overall and an overall time of 38min 20 sec.


Charlotte, and mum Jude, stayed for the rest of the day's racing to cheer on Toby Lewis (Youth male) and Paul Thomas in the Para Duathlon and later to watch the junior and senior elite events.

Phoenix Results

Toby Lewis showed his . He was disqualified, however, after missing the penalty box at dismount. He is definitely one to watch in future races.

fields.title: Full on at the marathon
fields.summary: Fantastic running by Almi Nerukar who came 1st in the U13 mini marathon in 17.05, 12 seconds clear of second place in what is reported to be a new course record.

fields.content:
Full on at the marathon

Fantastic running by Almi Nerukar who came 1st in the U13 mini marathon in 17.05, 12 seconds clear of second place in what is reported to be a new course record.

As part of the London Marathon there are mini marathon races for the
countries best junior runner, which are run over the final three miles of
the marathon course. These races are between teams selected from regions
throughout England, as well as teams from Wales and Northern Ireland.
Therefore for Almi Nerurkar to be selected to represent The South East
region in the girls U13 race was a major achievement. Lining up against her
main rivals from the nation cross country races this year Almi ran her best
race to date, although she may have been beaten on the country she showed
that she is the boss on the road to win in 17:05, which was 12 secs ahead of
second place. In winning her first national race she set a new course record
and also led the south east team to victory. Well done Almi!

Road Runners

Phoenix always does well in this fiercely fought and exciting event and this year was no exception.

The U15 boys and the senior men's A team both have claims to be team of the day. With a team and indiv, perhaps the boys edge clear.

Toby Lewis (running second fastest leg of the day) kicked of with an emphatic 5:40. Harry Swindells ran a steady 5:56 before Archie Davis set the indiv.

For the U13 girls, Maia Hardman, Louisa Saunders and Holly Luscombe would have recorded an excellent team silver and indiv.

The late entry ineligibility was the same for the U15 girls (Chloe Watson, Anna Berry and Charlotte Matthews) where their team time would have won gold by 10 seconds and Charlotte would have won indiv.

There were two under 17 women (Sophie Mansfield and Tara Bage) running in the only women's team of the day with Zena Claire completing the trio. They came a respectable 9th out of 19 senior women's teams with Sophie taking indiv.

Over 40 men and Over 50 men dBob Novis, Terry Avey and Brian Friend, ran themselves into silver place behind Chichester but ahead of arch rivals Brighton and Hove.

The senior men had some big names absent but, having won this event for the last three years were anxious to repeat the trick. This was a chance for some of our younger athletes to show their metal. Boy d. Three of the six-man squad ran under 10 minutes for a team time below one hour. This took them three minutes clear of Brighton and Hove who had led for the opening two laps. How about this for a consistent team performance over a leg distance of 2 miles and 93 yards: Billy White 10:06, Ross Skelton 9:55, Mark Dooley 9:54, Josh Guilmant 10:02, Sam Wade 10:09, Robbie Fitzgibbon 9:51. Indiv. Not forgetting Jake Alger who led out the senior B team with a scorching 10:04 to earn him indiv.

Apart from the late team entries, it would have been nice to have completed our representation with U13 boys and women's vet's teams. Maybe next time.

See results section for fuller details.

Thank you Andrew Haig for this report

Charlotte Mathews competed in another Triathlon in East Grinstead on 18th May. The event was the first in the South East England triathlon Series. Charlotte stayed true to form finishing 3rd overall in a time of 31:27. She will be hoping to at least maintain her position on the leader board as the series progresses. Next race for her in this series will be the Br.


On Saturday 31st May Charlotte competed in the Youth Aquathlon in Hyde Park London. She had a lot to do after a tough swim when she left the Serpentine in last (28th) place. A speedy transition gained her 2 places and out on the run she overtook 3 more competitors to cross the finish line in 23rd. The highlights for Charlotte were possibly diving into the Serpentine from about the same spot on the pontoon that Alistair Brownlee stood on a few hours later, and that final finish stretch on the blue carpet where she got her medal!

Photos are from the London Aquathon.

fields.title: Just A Minute
fields.summary: South Downs Way Relay June 7th is without doubt one of the highlights of the running calendar. Traversing the 100 miles South Downs Way, the race consists of 6 runners running 3 legs each and a harried driver in charge of ....

fields.content:
Just A Minute

South Downs Way Relay June 7th is without doubt one of the highlights of the running calendar. Traversing the 100 miles South Downs Way, the race consists of 6 runners running 3 legs each and a harried driver in charge of transporting the runners to each handover point & keeping a record of handover times.

This year competition was fierce with a record number of teams entering.
Runners started in waves from 6am to 9am at Beachy Head near Eastbourne with handover points at 18 locations across the South Downs Way finishing at Chilcomb Sports Ground, near Winchester.

Lizzy Miles started the only Phoenix Ladies team off at 6.30 in glorious sunshine. She handed to Liz Hall then Kathryn Harnett. A torrential down pour in leg 4 meant Caz Garrett came in soaked & handed to Erica Martin then Hildi Mitchell who again saw the sun. The Ladies worked to keep the pace up but some of us (!) who had never done this kind of endurance race before d! As the day progressed the aim was to not be passed by the any of the Phoenix men's teams who had later starts. Crossing the finish line just after 8pm Liz Hall's teams finishing just in front & behind her. Total time; 13:32:53.

Prizes are given for 1st & 2nd places however the Phoenix Ladies got a special mention as they were just under a minute behind second place (52 seconds in fact). So close yet so far - training for next year has already started!!

The Phoenix Men's B team showed the ladies how it's done finishing 2nd in their category and receiving one of the coveted medals. It was Malcolm Kemp's 17th consecutive relay and he was joined by Matt Greenall, Jon Wright, Lance Bellers, Phil Hampshire & Phil Grabsky . Starting at 8am they stormed across the line just after 8.30pm, completing the race in 12:34:18.

Finishing 4th in their category, the Phoenix Vets team of Nigel Herron, Donald Maclellan, Jim Whitelegg, Jon Pike Tom Fars& Dave Powell completed in 11:32:45. Dave Powell took 2 Phoenix records on his legs & it is understood Nigel & Tom were very late stand ins.

Phoenix Men's A Team, who started at 9am, crossed the finish in 11:02:51, 4th overall. The team consisted of Jose Luceron, Dave Carter, James Bullen, Tobias Bremer, Tom Sanderson & Andy Bone, who only stood in on Thursday when James Miles was taken ill.

A special mention needs to be made to the drivers of the teams, without whom it would not be possible. Not only do they ensure the teams reach each handover point in time they keep record of times & in the case of Ro have to listen to an awful lot of chat!
Phoenix Ladies' Patient Driver: Ro Harrington
Phoenix Men's B Team Driver: Petra Kopp
A Team Driver - James Miles
Vets Driver - John Marinko

fields.title: Simon tackles the European Cross Triathlon Champs in Sardinia
fields.summary: A year after completing his first Triathlon, Simon Taylor felt honoured to start his first race for a Great Britain Age  Group Team at. the 2014 European Cross Triathlon Championships in Sardinia on June 1.

fields.content:
Congratulations to Simon Taylor who, just a year after his first ever triathlon, represented GB in the M50-54 category and came an excellent 6th. Cross Triathlon is the equivalent of cross-country and mountain bikes are used. The swim was 1.5K, the bike r. Simon was sixth in the M50-54 category. Here is his account of the race:


One of my priorities was to keep relaxed whist also maintaining a decent pace in the 1.5km swim. The first lap went smoothly without too much grappling going on. The Sea temp was 18.5', beautiful crystal clear water, I could see the scuba diver v. I exited the water after the first 750m lap and d, the field was spread out by now. After the run it took a while to get a decent swim pace going again.

Transition 1 went ok and I soon passed a few people on the bike, before starting the first long ascent of the initial 15km bike lap. The first descent was fairly steep with gullies and various sizes of rocks to look out for. The bike section had single track, double track, steep ups/downs, trees, brambles, sand gravel, fast runs and slower technical areas, a mix of all you could expect on a good mtb course. The mtb course has two sections where you carry your bike up, one is called the 'crying wall' if it was much steeper you'd need a rope. On the second lap I was literally pouring with sweat climbing up this beast. As to be expected the second bike lap felt tougher than the first, I passed a few people and a few people passed me. I d't come a cropper and get injured on mtb course which was another priority. A few r.

No problems in T2 and off on the 10km run. About 4km of the run was on sandy beaches which was tough going for tired legs. Running over the wobbly rope br(four times) was also tricky on the legs. I passed a few people including one of the Elites who was not having a good day and looked like he may have crashed on the bike. Second lap and time to mentally dig in. My trainers were soaked with sea water and feeling heavy. I passed a few people and was passed by more people a mix of those on their first lap or faster people on the second lap.

Although I was the least experienced and one of the oldest in the team I was the second out of the 14 members of the Great Britain age group team to finish the race.
I came 6th in my category. I am fairly pleased with this.

One rule of these event that stood out - drafting is allowed on the bike but not between men and women!

My tip for anyone who hasn't done a triathlon with a 1500m swim in two laps where you exit the water and run about 150m on soft sand before re-entering the water. Don't think that will give you a breather for the second 750m swim, it can mess with your swim pace.

Great event, very well organised and an unforgettable experience.

Simon

Full results

fields.title: Brownlees inspire Phoenix athletes
fields.summary: Toby Lewis and Charlotte Matthews both competed in the Super-Sprint Youth event (15-18yrs) at the Brownlee Triathlon (South) at Petworth Park on Sunday 15th June.

fields.content:
Brownlees inspire Phoenix Athletes

Toby Lewis and Charlotte Matthews both competed in the Super-Sprint Youth event (15-18yrs) at the Brownlee Triathlon (South) at Petworth Park on Sunday 15th June.

The event was changed at very short notice (the night before) to a duathlon due to the water conditions in the lake.

There was one Youth wave for both male and female - Charlotte and Toby both managed to get in a good place on the start line

Toby set off at a great pace over the grass paths around the lake for the 2km run. Both came in to T1 in good positions, with Toby managing to slap a ‘high 5' to the Brownlee brothers who were watching the youth wave.

The 16km cycle r.

Out on the final 2.5km run there were some interesting developments with some of the athletes taking a more scenic route than necessary - a lesson to be learnt here is that studying the route maps before the event can pay off. A number of the athletes missed a turn resulting in a slightly longer run and quite a few seconds - I think Toby may have been one of these judging by his 2nd run time. Toby finished in 6th place in the Youth category (and 6th male youth).

Charlotte took the right route and came home in 8th place overall in the Youth category but more importantly first Youth female. (with a couple of hours to wait until prize giving she came to terms with the way things had turned out - there were a few female athletes who took the wrong route costing them higher placing above Charlotte)

A place on the podium with Johnnie and Alistair on either s. "Ohhhhh!"

Dame Kelly Holmes competed in one of the Super-Sprint waves only slightly beating Charlotte in the female Super-Sprint combined results (placing 1st and second)

Splits Total Run 2km T1 Bike 16km T2 Run 2.5km
Toby 49.48 6.08 28.0 27.49 35.0 14.49
Charlotte 51.39 7.15 38 32.02 37.0 11.06

http://www.brownleetri.com/south/race-details-2/race-results


http://www.brownleetri.com/south/

Thanks Judith for this report!

fields.title: Phoenix Ladies: not the weakest link
fields.summary: Phoenix Ladies proved they are not the weakest link for the second year running by finishing first ladies in this annual event.

fields.content:
Phoenix Ladies: not the weakest link

Phoenix Ladies proved they are not the weakest link for the second year running by finishing first ladies in this annual event.

The Weakest Link is an annual team event held at the Duke's Mound on the Marine Parade. Each team comprises of four runners who run a 2.5km leg each in relay, the final fifth lap is run all together. As you have to cross the line as a team you can only run as fast as your slowest member.

This year's event was especially well attended with runners competing from all over Brighton & Hove. The course is cleverly thought out making the most of the little hills there are and a long, straight against the wind. Phoenix entered 5 teams and competition amongst us was as fiercely fun as always. Although coming forth within the Phoenix teams, the all lady team of Zeina, Jane, Gill & Kathryn finished as the first all female team overall.

fields.title: South East Tri: Charlotte's update
fields.summary: Charlotte Mathews overcomes disappointment at the Br. Read on to hear how....

fields.content:
South East Tri up-date

Charlotte Mathews overcomes disappointment at the Br.

5th June - Hever Castle (1st) evening Triathlon

1st girl (4th overall) 13-15 year age group. It's an open water swim followed by a mixed terrain cycle (all off road) and a beautiful run by the lake. A lovely evening. Transitions all working well.

Swim (300m) 06:19 T1 00:59 Cycle (4km) 14:21 T2 00:21 Run (4km) 24:51

http://www.stuweb.co.uk/race/Jt/

Br, at Dartford, Kent

Charlotte was really looking forward to the event, the second in the South-East regional series.
Things began with a 400m open water swim in a relatively clean lake. With the boys and girls competing at the same time, as is usual, there was some ‘firm' positioning by some of the competitors.
Wetsuit slipped off well giving a speedy transition followed by a lightening moving jump on the bike. The bike course was on one s. Charlotte's cycling really showing some improvement both in speed and bike handling.
Another speedy transition and Charlotte was in first female place. Out on the run Charlotte made an early turn failing to complete the full run circuit and had to notify the organisers that she should be disqualified. She lost a valuable score for the regional series.

http://www.br.co.uk/race-calendar/br/

Wednesday 2nd July Hever Castle (2nd) evening Triathlon

1st girl (2nd overall) 13-15 year age group. Same route as the first event a month earlier. Another beautiful evening with the added excitement (or embarrassment) of Charlotte's mum Judith having a go at her first open water Tri!

http://www.stuweb.co.uk/race/LD/

Sunday 6th July Human Race SuperTri at Eton Dorney 15-16 (Youth) High Performance event

This was the 4th race in the SE regional series. With Charlotte having been disqualified from the 2nd event and missed the third it was crucial for her to complete this event and perform well if she was to regain some lost ground on the regional table. Weather conditions were pretty .
Charlotte had a reasonable swim leaving the lake in 8th place, just in the first half of the field. Transition went well and with 3 girls ahead Charlotte got herself into a small pack of girls hoping to work together to pull in the leaders. This wasn't to be but with another fine transition in T2 Charlotte set out on the run in 5th place. The run is Charlotte's strongest discipline but she just couldn't catch the girl ahead. Charlotte held onto her 5th place overall, really pleased with her result.

Charlotte is getting to meet some familiar and friendly faces at these events with the series in the SE region prov. With the 4 leading girls in this event Charlotte was really pleased to have secured a first place in the SE series.

Swim(400m) 06:49 T1 58.0 Cycle (10.6km) 20:23 T2 41.0 Run (2.5km) 09:46

http://humanrace.co.uk/results-archive/2014/supertri/all-results

A huge effort - the Girl's on fire!

fields.title: Phoenix at the Commonwealth Games
fields.summary: The Commonwealth Games is now on and we are lucky enough to have Charlie Grice in the England team over 1500m. His heat is today Fr.

fields.content:
Phoenix at the Commonwealth Games

The Commonwealth Games is now on and we are lucky enough to have Charlie Grice in the England team over 1500m. Surprisingly he is the first Phoenix runner to run the 1500m in the Commonwealth Games.His heat is today Fr.

The Commonwealths have been quite a good championships for our club. Back in 1986 Steve Ovett won the 5000m, not bad for an Olympic 800m Champion! In 1990 Mark Rowland came 7th in the 5000m. In 2002 Pat Davoren came 9th in the 3000m Steeplechase. But our most successful athlete was a Phoenix second claim member. Sally Gunnell won gold and silver over the 100m hurdles in 1986 and 1990, she also won gold over 400m hurdles in 1990 and 1994 as well as two 4 x 400m relay golds in 1990 and 1994.

One of the most significant Phoenix performances at the Commonwealths came back in 2002 from Honorary Phoenix Member Joel K. Competing for England Joel made the semi finals of the 800m. It is no exaggeration to say that the experiences Joel picked up in his International career have boosted the performances of our Phoenix M. One of the people who has really benefitted from Joel's help and input is none other than Charlie Grice.


Now back to training for the rest of you so that I may write your names up as well!

Cheers

Paul

(Chairman of Phoenix)

fields.title: Blackcap Handicap
fields.summary: Thanks to our roving reporter Elsie for her piece on the annual Blackcap Handicap.

fields.content:
Blackcap Handicap

On Thursday 31st July I went with my mum to Ditchling Beacon for the Black Cap Handicap.

My job was calling the runners and ticking them off the list.

Paul Thomas went off first. There was fifteen runners. Rick won.

By Elsie Mitchell (aged 7)

Liz Hall


Thank you to runners & supporter for turning out to enjoy our annual Blackcap Handicap event. It was good to have some guest runners too.

First home and winner in the handicap itself was Rik Taub in 47:30 (beating the handicapper by a whole 4 minutes!).
Second Home and winning the fastest woman award was Kate Gorman in 35:16
Nigel Herron was third home in 32:48 but Matt Greenall paced well to just pip Nigel for fastest man in 32:41.

Finally my particular thanks to Sue who was left to do all the event publicity whilst I was away on holElsie Mitchell for calling the runners to order and handing them place numbers at the end; to Bruce Warren who turned out with family to help with time keeping; at to Matt Greenall's family who prov.

A lovely evening and I had the joy of watching the sun sink as a large red orb as I ran home - the joys of running!

Best wishes
Liz

fields.title: European Champion..? UPDATE!
fields.summary: Charlie Grice ran a well executed, tactical run in his heat to finish second in 3: 39.1 ensuring he runs in the Final today (Sunday).

fields.content:
European Champion...?

Charlie Grice ran a well executed, tactical run in his heat to finish second in 3: 39.1 ensuring he runs in the Final today (Sunday).

Phoenix athletes have done well at the European Championships in the past. Steve Ovett, in the years before he formed Phoenix won two silvers at 800m and gold at 1500m. Second claim member Sally Gunnell won a relay bronze and gold over the 400m hurdles. Mark Rowland won silver in a titanic race over 3000m steeplechase against Italian Francesco Panetta. In that race Mark ran his second fastest time ever clocking 8:13.27 a time which would see him nearly ten seconds clear of todays UK fastest chaser.

Good luck to Charlie Grice in the European Championships this week. He will be live on the BBC this afternoon!

fields.summary: Commiserations & Congratulations to Charlie Grice for surviving the European Championship final!

fields.content:
Trials & Tribulations at the Euro Champs

Commiserations & Congratulations to Charlie Grice for surviving the European Championship final!

In what was a messy & controversial final, Charlie bumped with another athlete. With 500 metres to the finish, he fell to the ground only to be hit again when getting up. He showed true grit by finishing the race in 4:04:81. Charlie's , slower than Charlie's pb of 3:35:59.

Congratulations to Chris O'hare for staying out of trouble to finish in bronze position in 3:46:18.

Charlie on Twitter says: ‘Typical messy championship race. Unfortunately I was on the wrong end of it today. Hungry for more'. So are we.....!

fields.title: They've got The Power!
fields.summary: Almi Nerurkar & Naomi Fonteyn's hard work is paying off as they achieve the Power of 10 UK top 100 mark, with Almi placed 3rd in the UK.

fields.content:
They've got The Power

Almi Nerurkar & Naomi Fonteyn achieve the Power of 10 UK top 100 mark.

The Power of 10 is a set of targets that should be attainable by at least 10 athletes during the season. They are set to help athletes focus & improve their performance in any track & field event within the UK. The standards are set each year and relate to long term goals rather than indiv.

After a storming year, Phoenix is proud to announce both Almi Nerurkar and Naomi Fonteyn have achieved the Power of Ten UK top 100 mark, with Almi placed 3rd in the UK.

What a wonderful result for all their hard work!

http://www.thepowerof10.info/aboutpowerof10/

fields.title: Senior Men Triumph at Southern Road Relays
fields.summary: Held at the 'Rushmore' Stadium in Aldershot on Sunday 21 September, the senior men took the venue name to heart and improved on their 2013 time by five minutes gaining a covetted top ten position as they d.

fields.content:
The South of England Road Relay Championships attract competition from all the top clubs in the area. Run around a natural basin (The Rushmore Arena) in Aldershot, the two circuits add up to 6K for each of the six-man teams in the senior event. We've done pretty well in the past coming an excellent 17th last year out of 70 odd finishing teams. This year we went to a whole new level knocking a full 5 minutes off of last year's time.

Josh Guilmant kicked off with a stunner: 18:24 to hand over in 6th position. This got him into the fastest leg list in equal 14th place. Ross Skelton kept the pressure on, running a fantastic 18:41 taking us into the dream territory of second place. Inevitably the m– but not much, we were never out of the top ten. Robbie Fitzgibbon ran 19:38 for 9th place, Jake Alger ran 19:31 to maintain the position, Sam Wade ran 19:01 for eighth and finally Jon Pepper let fly with 18:37 and 7th place. Great race, great tactics.

Meanwhile we fielded an incomplete B team which, had it been complete would surely have kept them well in the mix. Jose Luceron kicked off in 20:26, Sean Parker-Harding ran 20:36, Sam Kitchen 21:45 and O40 vet Don Maclellan 22:13. They were 56/72 at that point.

Great day at the races everyone.

Full results

fields.title: Best out of three

fields.content:
Best out of three

Charlotte Matthews competed the British Triathlon Under 20's Festival held at Nottingham on Fr, organised by British Triathlon.

Charlotte was competing in the youth event and expected to be challenged by the strength of the other competitors having raced against some in London and Nottingham earlier in the year. She finished 29th out of 35 competitors in a time of 36:32 and was pleased with her performance. A slow swim meant she missed the two strong packs on the cycle course but she d.
Split times: 400m swim 6:49 T1 0:53 10km Bike 18:40 T2 :36 2.5km Run 9:34

http://www.britishtriathlon.org/major-events/u20_festival/2014_results

For Charlotte this was her third race out of a possible five over the season in the British Youth Female Super Series. She finished the season 33rd overall and will be looking forward to improving her performance next year.

http://www.britishtriathlon.org/take-part/events/youth-and-junior-series#2014%20Results%20and%20Ranking

On Saturday 6th September Charlotte took part in the Crowborough Triathlon (Youth), a highly competitive race as the 4 leading girls in the South East battled for a chance for a win in the last triathlon of the SE series (2 Aquathlons remaining). Charlotte finished in 2nd place in the girls race with an overall time of 00:31:21
Splits: 300m Swim 6:04 5.4km (grass) Bike 17:59 2km Run 07:18

http://www.hedgehogtri.co.uk/web/k/results.html

Charlotte then competed in the Medway Aquathlon (youth) on Saturday 13th September. She was determined to try to secure a win here without having the bike discipline in the mix.
