fields.title: Glorious at Goodwood
fields.summary: There were medals galore as Phoenix Athletes dominated at the Sussex Cross-Country Relay Championships at Goodwood, Saturday 27th September, with the dry conditions allowing for some fast times.

fields.content:
Glorious Goodwood

There were medals galore as Phoenix Athletes dominated at the Sussex Cross-Country relay championships at Goodwood, Saturday 27th September with the dry conditions allowing for some fast times.

The senior men's race saw gold & bronze for the A & B teams respectively. Although close at times, as Phoenix B finished lap 1 in front, Bill White, Jon Peper, Josh Guilman & Ross Skelton took the gold with the phoenix B team of Patrick Acaye, Tobias Bremer, Kris Everett & Sean Parker-Harding finishing in bronze. Jon Peper contributed to the success by running the fastest lap time in 11:46.


The V40 men saw a further gold as Don McCellan, Austen Hunter, Andy Bone & Paul Wishart finished in 58:51. A mix up with the medals unfortunately means they wait to receive theirs!


U17 Men Ollie Johnson, Toby Lewes, Archie Davis completed the men's hat trick with a further gold medal.


Gold wasn't the only colour, with the V60 men's team of Colin Simpson, Andrew Haig & Malcolm Kemp finishing in second positioni.


Running for the V50 men, Mike Townley Malcolm Hughes Lance Bellers & Nigel Herron finished in bronze position as dErica Martin, Kate Gorman & Kathryn Harnett, running for the senior women.

It was great to see such a good Phoenix turn out with the U13 Boys & Girls & U15 Girls also being well represented. Well done to Siarise McGuiness, Eloise Nichol, Maia Hardman, Rachel Berry, Connie Jankowski, Alex Brothwell, Charlie Cloke, Joel Luscombe, Eimhin Wellings, Arthur Haines, Zach Elbourne, Dylan Cutler, James Henderson, Ned Howes, Chloe Watson, Holly Luscombe, Charlotte Matthews.

Detailed results
http://www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results

Pictures are of the Senior Phoenix Men's A & B teams, U17 Men, O60 men& Senior Women as well as the U13 and U15 girls and boys who turned out in force.The O40 picture courtesy of Messrs Bone and Photoshop.

fields.title: Sweet Sixteen
fields.summary: The National 6 stage road relay champs at Sutton Park on 4 October is the biggest and most competitive race of  the season with only the very best teams in the county invited to run.  Phoenix again showed their .

fields.content:
National Champs road relays is the biggest and most competitive race of the season with only the very best teams in the county invited to run. We managed a very good 16th not quite matching the 14th of last year but given a very late injury to Ross this was a good team performance and shows that we are still by far the stand out team in Sussex. Thank to Patrick for stepping in last minute to fill the spot, and for all the guys who really put themselves on the line for a top performance.

Ben Tickner showed his , which normally leads to being selected for England in a international meet.

The team were led off by Ben Tickner who finished just 5 seconds behind the leading team in 17:17.

Josh Guilmant was next and he took the lead in a mad moment but settled down to run a more realistic 18:12 bringing the team into sixth place.

Third leg runner Patrick Acaye, despite a heavy race programme recently, put in a creditable 19:22 for seventeenth place.

Next up, Jake Alger who held on to 17th by running 18:47 leaving Jon Pepper to claw back an incredible three places by running 18:00 dead.

Robbie Fitzgibbon was last man up and with a run of 19:10 steered us to that splend.

A special mention should be made of Malcolm Hughes who stepped in at the very last moment as team driver.

fields.title: Erica (and Nigel and Toby) for the Euros
fields.summary: Well done to Erica Martin, Nigel Heron and Toby Lewes for qualifying for the 2015 European Duathlon Championships.

fields.content:
Erica (and Tony and Nigel) for the Euros!

Well done to Erica Martin for qualifying for the 2015 European Duathlon Championships at Althorp Duathlon on Saturday 18th October.

A duathlon takes a run, bike, run format, with Althorp's distances covering a 5.9km run, 22km cycle and 5.9km. Erica came a very respectable fourth in last year's European Championships, but is no doubt chasing a podium this year.


Erica, Toby Lewes & Nigel Herron raced in their respective categories, with Erica finishing first to qualify for the Champs. Toby finished first in his age category and 13th male finisher overall & Nigel finished 10th.

Erica has qualified for the GB team for the European. Toby & Nigel wait to see if they have qualified....STOP PRESS 31 Oct: It has been confirmed that Nigel and Toby have qualified with a rolldown place in the European Champs. Well done guys.

Congratulations to Almi Nerurkar on winning the U15 girls race at the prestigious Mike Sully Cross Country in Bristol last weekend.

fields.title: Well done Phoenix
fields.summary: The club awards party took place on Saturday 22 November at the Park View Pub. The atmosphere was great but was tinged with a little sadness as Paul Collicutt undertook the presentation for the last time as Chairman.

fields.content:
As you can see from Lance Bellers' excellent photographs, the atmosphere was exciting and excitable as the recipients came up one by one to receive their awards from chairman Paul. Congratulations to him, Andy Bone and their team for a highly enjoyable evening. Not forgetting Richard Moult, club social secretary for organising the venue and the scrumptious buffet.

Paul has been chairman now for eleven years and will be standing down in March so there was a poignancy in the knowledge that this would be his last presentation. Bruce Warren gave a stirring speech of thanks to him at the close of preceedings.

fields.title: Grand Prix winners
fields.summary: The final results have just been published for the Sussex Grand Prix Road Racing series 2014. Phoenix were less than prominant in the club results but two of our vet runners kept the flag flying in the indiv.

fields.content:
The final results have just been published for the Sussex Grand Prix Road Racing series 2014. This is a series of 20 key races in the county run throughout the year and including our own 10K race.

Points are awarded to clubs and to indiv. First qualifying runner in scores 500 and next 499 and so on. There are separate men and women's competitions and an overall club award.

A decade ago we were winning this overall cup but seem to have drifted down to m. Winners this year were Haywards Heath Harriers. We came 11th in the overall results (male), 15th overall (women), 10th vet men and 15th vet women.

We were slightly more successful in the indivTerry Avey achieving third place in the V5 category and Andrew Haig first place in the V6. Andrew was a mighty 210 points ahead of his nearest rival and has now won his age group for nine consecutive years. "I guess I'm going to have to try and complete the set next year' he says but 'It gets more and more difficult with younger guys coming into the age group'.

The 2015 race series begins with the Chichester 10K on February 8.

Further information and full results

fields.title: Force required to take forth win
fields.summary: Jon Pepper faced not only gruelling conditions but fierce opposition from Phoenix team mate Ben Tickner to take his fourth consecutive victory in the Sussex Cross Country Championships at Bexhill.

fields.content:
Force required to take fourth win


Jon Pepper faced not only gruelling conditions but fierce opposition from Phoenix team mate Ben Tickner to take his fourth consecutive victory in the Sussex Cross Country Championships, Bexhill. This places him 4th in the all time standing - ahead of Steve Ovett and Tim Hutchings.


Jon & Ben led from the start and despite the very slippery conditions, following a day of stormy weather, managing to hold their places. It took to the fourth lap before Jon pulled the lead, winning by just 3 seconds. They were followed by the Sam Wade (7th) and Josh Guilmant (8th) to claim first place in the league for the Phoenix Men's A team.


Congratulations to Almi Nerurkar for her win in the U15 girls' race. Although a favourite to win she finished in , 58 seconds ahead of the field.
U20 men victor Billy White also deserves a mention, finishing first in 32:57.

For full results of all the Phoenix members / teams see: www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results

fields.title: Phoenix Athletes show their class on UK stage
fields.summary: UPDATE........Young Phoenix Athletes had an awesome weekend competing in events around the country, ensuring their UK rankings.

fields.content:
Phoenix Athletes show their

Young Phoenix Athletes had an awesome weekend competing in events around the country, ensuring their UK rankings.

Finn Bigg ran a pb of 51.06 400m to win in the New Year's Open at Cardiff. This ranks him 2 in UK U20s category.

In the South of England U15/U17 indoor champs., Marina Re continued her reign finishing 5th in the U17 Long Jump.

Further success was seen in the 800m with Maia Hardman finishing 3rd in the heat with a PB of 2.27.98 and fith in the final with another PB of 2.27.60. This now ranks Maia 9th in the UK.

Louisa Saunders picked up a fantastic Bronze medal in the 300m U 15 girls finishing second in the heat in 44.73 only to beat this in the final, finishing 3rd with a PB of 43.81.This ranks her 5th in the UK.

Coach Roy Hayward says: "There was a strong field in this event. Well done to all those who took part - a fantastic achievement."

More results

fields.title: Record breaker
fields.summary: Congratulations to Archie Davis who won his BMC race in Sheffield and broke the UK indoor U17 1500m record.

fields.content:
Record breaker

Congratulations to Archie Davis who won his BMC race in Sheffield and broke the UK indoor U17 1500m record.

Finishing in a storming 3:56:82, Archie beat the record by over a second.

Coached by Phoenix's Jon Bigg, Archie is the 3rd Phoenix athlete to hold a UK 1500m record following in the esteemed footsteps of Steve Ovett (senior record) and Br(U 17).

fields.title: Multisport Championship Events 2015
fields.summary: The events comprising Brighton Phoenix Club Championship 2015 have just been announced. Contenders might want to note 01/03, 19/04, 14/06, 08/08 and 27/09 in their brand new diaries.

fields.content:
Brighton Phoenix Multi Sport Championships 2015

We hold an annual club multi-sport championship for our pa. In this you will be awarded points according to where you are placed in any of the five designated races in comparison to your fellow club members. Only your three highest places count toward the final score. There is a trophy for the highest placed male and highest placed female and this will be presented at our annual awards night.

You do not need to do all five events but obviously the more of the events you do the more chance you have of improving your best three score. Some events fill up quickly so enter soon to avo.

In the event of two or more members attaining the same score the trophy will be awarded to the person that placed highest in the open results of their three events.

To qualify you must have pa.

We will provbrightonphoenixmedia@gmail.com as that will ensure your result goes on our results page.

Any questions please ask Liz Hall.

This year's championship events are:-

1st March: The Frosty Aquathlon is an 800m pool swim and 10K run. Entry is £25 for BTF members and £28 for non-BTF. It takes place in Littlehampton. More details are at http://www.tuff-fitty.co.uk/home.php

19th April: Haywards Heath Sprint Triathlon is 384m pool swim / 25k bike / 5k run. Entry is £42. It takes place from the Dolphin Leisure Centre in Haywards Heath. More details at http://www.hedgehogtri.co.uk/2015/HayHeath.html

14th June: M(Sprint) is 4k pool swim / 25k bike / 5k run. Entry is £35 for BTF members £38 for non-BTF. It takes place at the Triangle Leisure Centre in Burgess Hill. More details at http://www.m.com/the-m.aspx

8th August: Bewl Triathlon Standard Distance is 1.5k swim (open water) / 40k bike / 10k run. Entry is £55 for BTF members and £59 for non-BTF. It takes place at Bewl Water Country Park. More details at http://www.bewltriathlon.co.uk/standard.html

27th September: Bexhill Lions Duathlon / 40k bike / 10k run. Entry is £32 if you enter before 1st April, after which prices increase. It takes place by the De La Warr Pavilion at Bexhill-on-Sea. More details at http://www.bexhill-triathlon.co.uk/index.html

Happy racing Liz Hall 14 January 2015

fields.title: Medalling Masters
fields.summary: If you haven't seen the results yet, there were deeds of daring do from all the teams at the Masters' XC Champs last Saturday. Good to see a complete women's team out too.

fields.content:
If you haven't seen the results yet, there were deeds of daring do from all the teams at the Masters' XC Champs last Saturday. Good to see a complete women's team out too. The course at Lancing was sopping wet and positively lethal on the steeper descents.

O60 men came a close third (bronze) in an amazingly competitive race. Special mention should be made of Paul Whelpton who ran a blinder taking indiv. Colin Simpson (running an astonishing four minutes plus faster than last year!) and Andrew Haig were the other scorers with Malcolm Kemp in sturdy support.

The O50 men's race proved to be a very tight one as well with just two points separating the top three team positions. Bruce Warren picked himself up after falling (twice) to lead the Phoenix team home in sixth with Nigel Herron close behind in eighth and the third scorer Lance Bellers in twelfth. We had to settle for bronze but an exciting race all the same. Phil Grabsky, Jon Wright and Malcolm Hughes ran well to complete our second scoring team.

The O40 men went into this race looking to sneak a bronze medal given the known strengths of Brighton and Lewes in this age category. However some dogged performances on the day pushed us into silver medal position only 2 points behind the leading Brighton team and 5pts ahead of Lewes in 3rd. New vet Dave Carter led the team home in 4th place followed by Donald Maclellan in 5th who fought well to overhaul a Lewes runner on the final descent. Matt Greenall had an outstanding performance to finish in 10th and Austen Hunter, who only dec, was the 4th scorer in a very credible 17th. Tom Sanderson, Jim Whitelegg, Andrew Neighbour and Ro Harrington made up our second scoring quartet and finished 5th in the team standings. Well done all.

There was a complete O35 women's team led out by a resergent Deb Friis finishing in 36th place with Kathryn Harnett not far behind. The team was completed by Natalie Davis who ran strongly in, as we understand it, her first ever cross-country race. The team was fourth of the four scoring teams but well in the mix.

Check the details here

fields.title: Ben finds stamina at Stanmer
fields.summary: Saturday 24th January and Stanmer Park was alive with thousands of runners and their supporters who descended for the SEAA South of England Cross Country Championships.

fields.content:
Ben finds stamina at Stanmer

Saturday 24th January and Stanmer Park was alive with thousands of runners and their supporters who descended for the SEAA South of England Cross Country Championships.

In what turned out to be beautiful conditions, this stunning course h(thanks to the previous evening's downpour). The tip of the day being ‘pace yourself'!

Well done to both our U13 Teams who, for many, ran in their biggest race to date both in status and number of competitors - a huge field of 227. The U13 girls team finished 29th and the Boys 10th out of 34 teams, and second only to Lewes out of the Sussex teams, finally beating our big rivals (and friends) Brighton and Hove. All the young athletes put in 100% effort & all the Parents who came to support. It's worth noting how close the field was with the Phoenix boys finishing within a minute or 2 of the winner.

Further congratulations goes to Almi Nerurkar for finishing a storming 6th in the U15 girls. A fantastic result in a competitive field, placing the U15 girls team 25th.

Also running for Phoenix were U17 Girls, U20 Girls & Boys & the senior women's team (who finished 25th out of 51 teams).

The senior men's race was always going to be a hotly contested race with Phoenix athletes Jon Pepper and Ben Tickner up against each other again. Jon Pepper led for most of the 15km race but it was Ben's sprint finish, and no doubt determination to not be pipped at the post again, that catapulted him over the line in first position with Jon finishing third. With only 4 seconds between winner and fourth place and Ugandan Olympian Paskar Owor also in the mix, the race was riveting stuff to watch unfold.

Finally, a big THANK YOU to Bruce Warren and his team of Phoenix marshals who helped the race run smoothly & safely. Bruce has been liaising with SEAA and was at Stanmer from 8.45 to 5pm - thank you!!

Photographers: Lance Bellers, Stephen Hardman, Dav, Gareth Wellings

fields.title: Charlie Grice makes it the double
fields.summary: Charlie Grice ensured his place in the European Indoor Championships in Prague with a conf.

fields.content:
Charlie Grice makes it the double

Charlie Grice ensured his place in the European Indoor Championships in Prague with a conf.

Charlie qualified by leading from the start in his heat to finish in 4:04:58, but then bested his own performance in the final. Storming to the front in the final lap, Charlie won gold in 3:49:79 making him double British Champion

Spencer Thomas, running in the 800m, chose the perfect time to pull not one but two Pbs out of the bag - besting the new Pb he set in his heat with another in the final to finish 5th in 1:50:89.

Well done also to Robbie Fitzgibbon (15th in 3000m) & Sophie Mansfield (3rd in the 800m heat) for their strong performances on this national stage.

Full Results

http://www.thepowerof10.info/results/results.aspx?meeting&pagenum=1

fields.title: Fun in the Country
fields.summary: Saturday 14th February saw the final race in the Cross Country League...

fields.content:
Saturday 14th February saw the final race in the Cross Country League.

Held at Lancing, as the Bexhill course hadn't recovered from the last onslaught, indiv& slippery course.

Ollie Johnson (U17 men, pictured below) won silver medal in the overall league standing with a 2nd at Lancing and Plumpton and 3rd at the first visit to Lancing.

The U15 girls showed the rest how it's done with 2 medals in the overall league standing: Charlotte Mathews took the bronze showing she is as talented at the cross country as she is triathlon. Almi Nerurkar (U15 girls) topped off a sensational cross country season finishing 1st. Almi has finished 1st in all 3 races giving her a gold medal in the overall league standing...she really couldn't have done more!

Not to be outdone, Lucas Nerurkar finished first in the U11 boys race and the U13 boys took silver in the league.

The women had another complete team running with Erica Martin finishing a respectable 9th. Good to see Lizzy Miles back and in very good form despite a few months off with an injury. Mixed results for the ladies in the league standing, owing to age groups being mixed to complete teams during the season but we're definitely top of division 2 for the Seniors!

As for the Men's teams...... Paul Whelpton (V60) completed a hat trick finishing 1st in the all 3 races. The Vet Men's team finished 3rd in the overall standings, with the Senior A & B Teams 4th in the first & second divisions.

It's also been brought to our attention that the Vet Men (v40, v50, v60 and overall O40) have medals in every county cross country event this season (relays, championships and league)....way to go guys!

Results: http://www.sussexathletics.org.uk/results.php#455

Racing photos by Matt Greenall

fields.content:
Best ever result at the Nationals


Parliament Hill was the setting for the National Cross Country Championships on Saturday, 21 February.

8 Phoenix athletes ran the 12km course in a field of 2000. Ben Tickner, fresh from his Southern Champion win, led the Phoenix charge finishing fifth, the best Phoenix senior result to date. This record was previous held by Jon Pepper who came 7th last year. Jon Pepper finished this year in 28th with Ross Skelton 48th in what is being called his break through run. Josh Guilmant, James McCarthy, Donald Macellan, Patrick Acaye & Paul Wier completed the team (pictured)

The team finished 9th overall, their best ever result, and it is understood that was achieved with half the team missing through injury.

fields.content:
Phoenix medals sweep


Phoenix athletes leave with a sweep of medals and a British record at the England Young Athletics Indoor Championships at Sheffield.


In the U17 200m, Toby Harris stormed to the line to take the gold medal with a new British indoor record of 21:46. Having already won bronze in the 60m, with a time of 6.93, Toby was in a .


Spencer Thomas had a tighter finish but just as good result finishing first in 1:52:24 in the U17 800m.

In the U20 1500m Robbie Fitzgibbon stormed to silver in day 1 of the championships.


Archie Davis finished a very respectable silver in the U20 800m with quite a margin between him and bronze.

Well done to Finley Bigg for finishing second in the semi final & Sophie Mansfield for comming first in her heat.

http://www.englandathletics.org/england-athletics-news/records-fall-on-day-2-of-the-england-athletics-age-group-champs

fields.title: XC: Best ever results...
fields.summary: Congratulations to Almi Nerurkar and Ben Tickner for their brilliant 8th positions in the National Inter-counties XC championships.

fields.content:
Cross Country - best ever results!

Congratulations to Almi Nerurkar and Ben Tickner for their brilliant 8th positions in the National Inter-counties XC championships.

Almi, competing in the U15 Girls race and Ben, running for the Senior men finished their phenomenal seasons on an international stage.

Adding to Ben's finish the scores from Jon Pepper (22nd), Ryan Driscoll (58th), Max Dumbrell (100th), James Baker (105th) & Josh Guilmant (106th) mean the senior men's team finish in 7th place - their best ever score.

INTERNATIONAL SUNDAY!

Spencer Thomas and Archie Davis both ran for England at the Welsh Athletics International Indoor Championships in Cardiff. Donning their first international vests, they d, club & country proud with a 1, 2 finish in the U20 800m.

http://welshresults.athletics-uk.org/Web_Directory/2015%20WA%20Indoor%20International%20Results.pdf


Meanwhile in Prague..... Charlie Grice got closer to the medals in the Senior International Indoor Championships. In his closest position to date, he came 5th in the 1500m final at the European Indoor champs. His time was a new Phoenix indoor record & yet another Pb on an international stage.

http://www.european-athletics.org/competitions/european-athletics-indoor-championships/2015/athletics/event/mens-1500m/phase=atm015100/index.html?v=20150308153704&intcmp

fields.title: Paul Bids Farewell as Chairman
fields.summary: Paul Collicutt will be standing down as Chairman of Phoenix at the AGM on Wednesday 11th March after an exceptional eleven years in the driving seat. See Paul's farewell card.

fields.content:
It has truly been one of the greatest honours of my life to have been Chairman of our great club Brighton Phoenix for the past eleven years.

During that time I think everyone at the club has worked very hard to make it a better club for all our members. The performance levels have improved across the board and this is due to tireless dedicated work by coaches, team managers and parents not to mention the commitment from our athletes themselves over all our disciplines. When I became Chairman I honestly believed we could raise our game but I never expected all the World Multisports Champions we got, nor d(one at a sprint event to boot) and win three National titles in the same season as we achieved our highest ever team and indiv! I d.

I would like to thank all the Board Members, Coaches, Team Managers, Parents, Newsletter and Website Teams and Volunteers who have worked with me over the last eleven years. The Club AGM is this Wednesday at Withdean Stadium at 7.30pm. I hope to see as many of you as can attend. I am proposing Mike Townley as the next Chairman. I know he will bring his expertise with the International Paralympic Committee to the position of Chairman and I cannot be happier that he has agreed to stand. I love this club and I just know that Mike is precisely the right man to be the new Chairman.

Best Wishes to One and All

Paul Collicutt
Chairman (until Wednesday evening) of the Awesome Brighton Phoenix

See Paul's farewell card here

fields.title: Musical Chairs at the AGM
fields.summary: The club AGM on 11 March was packed out with those wanting to thank Paul at his final appearance as chairman but also to welcome Mike Townley as the incumbent.

fields.content:
The club AGM on 11 March was packed out with those wanting to thank Paul at his final appearance as chairman but also to welcome Mike Townley as the incumbent.

Other club business was swiftly dealt with all of the committee happy to stand for reelection. We were waiting for the main event and it turned into a multimedia spectacular. OK it was one sl!

First off was Paul who had put together a sl. There were quite a few of the man himself only with lots of hair. Who knew? It is generally agreed that in his eleven years of tenure Paul has revived the fortunes of the club in no uncertain terms. Take a look at the heartfelt messages in the booklet presented to him at the end of the evening. Keep a hankie handy though! The good news is that Paul will continue as a highly-regarded coach.

Mike Townley, has been an active member of Phoenix for seven years. Apart from being a fine distance runner, he is a sports lawyer much in demand for international organising committees including Olympic. Unlike Paul, he isn't a coach but his knowledge of how sports organisations work is second to none. Unable to get back from Germany for the AGM, he sent a v. If you haven't yet met Mike, he will be running for the over 50 men at the Sussex Road Relays on Easter Saturday. Come and say hello.

See Paul's card here

fields.title: Erica takes on Europe!
fields.summary: 26th April saw our very own Erica Martin take on the 2015 European Duathlon, held in Alcobendas, Spain.

fields.content:
Erica takes on Europe!

26th April saw our very own Erica Martin take on the the 2015 European Duathlon, held in Alcobendas, Spain. Here is her account of the race....

"When I found out the race was in Spain my first thought was that it would be warm and sunny. Sadly this wasn't the case and it was raining heavily on the morning of the race. Luckily this stopped just as the race began.
The first 5km run was undulating but a good route and I felt strong. The bike route was also very undulating, with a lot of long, gradual climbs and fast descents. There were a lot of roundabouts which were slightly hairy at times due to the amount of water on the roads.
The final run took place on the same course as the first but was only one lap of 2.5km this time so was over with very quickly.

I was very pleased with how the race went and although would have liked to have in a higher position overall I was 2nd from GB which should hopefully qualify me for next year's race."

Erica is being modest...take a look at her times...!

Time Run T1 Bike T2 Run
01:10:05 00:18:14 00:01:42 00:39:54 00:01:42 00:08:33

A more experienced Phoenix girls team saw a gutsy win by Eloise Nichol in the A string 1000m in 3.32.4 and another first for Rachel Berry in the B string in 3.43.9. Both with a great cross country season behind them.

In the Boys 1000m Alex Brothwell ran a sol.21.5 and it was also a clear win for Milly Dickinson in the Girls 600m.
Phoenix girls were impressive in the sprints in particular Phoebe Thoms who dominated the 150m from the gun with a winning time of 21.8 as well as also winning the long jump with a 4.30m leap. In the 75m hurdles it was A and B string wins for Tegan Corder in 14.0 and Rachel Berry in 16.8.

fields.content:

Archie Davis (16) has opened the season very well, starting with an 800m last Wednesday at the Phoenix BMC. Archie ran 1.52.4, a 2.5 second PB, moving him above Steve Ovett into 3rd place in the Sussex all time fastest U17 800m, behind Charlie Grice and Johan Boakes. That time also places him 2nd in the UK U17 rankings.

On Saturday Archie raced the Stretford British Milers Club Grand Prix 1500m and clocked 3.51.81 in windy conditions. This gets him ins.53. The competition is to be held in Samoa later this summer. That time also places him in the top 20 all time UK fastest U17's.

Archie is now going after the World Youth Qualification time of 3.51.0 in his next 1500m in Sports City Manchester in two weeks time.


Spencer Thomas (17) qualified to run for GB U20 in Loughborough this weekend, his first GB international vest. He raced well, coming 2nd to a Senior England International with a PB of 1.49.61, his first time under the 1.50 barrier. He now has his sights on the European U20 qualification time (1.49.0). Spencer is ranked no.1 U20 800m in the UK


Robbie Fitzgibbon (19) also represented GB U20 in Loughborough. He ran a 3.48 to come 4th and is currently ranked 3rd in the UK U20 1500m. Robbie is also gunning for the European U20 1500m qualification.

fields.title: Ups & Downs
fields.summary: Despite being in its 29th year, the South Downs Way Relay, held on Saturday 8th June, proved to be its usual gruelling but absolutely amazing, fun filled day!

fields.content:
Ups & Downs

Despite being in its 29th year, the South Downs Way Relay, held on Saturday 8th June, proved to be its usual gruelling but absolutely amazing, fun filled day!

Teams of 6 run a total of eighteen demanding, hilly legs to cover the 100 miles of the South Downs Way between Beachy Head and Winchester. Four teams, along with their drivers, flew the flag for Phoenix. A record number of 67 teams ran this year. With start times staggered depending on predicted times, results are split into different race categories.

Vets report

The Vets were conf, and their predicted time would have had them win fairly comfortably in most of the last years. The main aim was to go and execute the plan.

The strong team consisted of Donald Maclellan, Tom Sanderson, Jon Pike, Matt Greenall, Dave Carter & Dave Powell . A huge thanks to John Marinko who drove.

Donald Maclellan gave us an early lead on the difficult Seven Sisters Leg 1, and from then on Basingstoke, Lewes and Phoenix swopped around the top 3 places, with very strong runs on Leg 4 (Dave Powell), Leg 5 (Dave Carter) and Leg 7 (Donald again) putting us into second. However from this point on, Lewes and Basingstoke found an extra gear and had a very entertaining race which Lewes finally won clocking in the low 10:50s. Although we realised the medals were getting out of our reach, our team continued to run very well, finishing in 11:07 a ten minute club vets record over this longer version of the relay course, three minutes quicker than our most optimistic estimate for the day. We also broke 7 club leg records - three for Dave Powell and two each for Dave Carter and Matt Greenall. Dave Carter's 55:17 on Leg 17 took three minutes off the previous vets best and may stand for some time unless he has another go in 2016.

Women's report
Despite the very early set off (leaving Withdean at 4.45am) the sole Phoenix Women's team had a spritely start with Erica Martin taking second place in the first leg. Erica stayed true to form all day, completing the most miles for the team (19.4miles).

Lizzy Miles kept up the lead in leg 2 finishing some 4 minutes ahead of her predicted time. It is definitely worth mentioning Lizzy ran her final leg (leg 13) 6 minutes faster than predicted.

In leg 3 Caz Garrat, in her second ever relay, stormed in first place. Caz beat her predicted times in her next 2 legs.

We were over taken by 2 very quick men's teams in leg 4 but Deb Friis kept us first in the women's race. She kept up the pace in legs 10 & 16. If memory serves me right, Debs ran her first relay 10years ago.

In Leg 5, ran by Kathryn Harnett, we were over taken by the Arena 80 Women's team, despite Kathryn running 2:15 over her predicted time.

We were still in the medals following leg 6 ran by Liz Hall, Team Captain extraordinaire, in 2 minutes over her predicted time. Unfortunately we were unable to hold onto this as the day progressed. Liz won the unofficial award for being closest to her predicted times over all the legs, so she does win the prize of being captain of the Women's team next year. Congratulations, Liz!

The final team member was Hildi Mitchell who's navigational skills, time keeping & expert driving need to go on her CV!

Senior Teams

A Team:

Driver: Ro Harrington

Runners: James Miles; Tobias Bremer; Jose Luceron; Alex Bonzi; Paul Lawrence; Ray Matthews.

The Senior As were lucky to field a team as a late injury led to a search for a last minute replacement; thanks to Ray for stepped up the evening before ensuring the team were able to run.

B Team:

Driver: Sue Hudson

Runners: Malcolm Kemp; Jon Wright; Phil Grabsky; Andrew Neighbour; Colin Simpson; Paul Whelpton

The Senior Bs were left with a desperate last minute search for an experienced driver when their driver was rendered unable to drive. A massive thank you to Sue Hudson for stepping in & warm wishes to their original driver.

fields.title: 2 swim 4 life
fields.summary: Read about Hildi Mitchell's 24 mile in 24 hour swim...it's not for the faint hearted!!

fields.content:
2 Swim 4 Life

Ok I d't manage 24 miles, but, hang on, I SWAM 15 MILES! The training had gone well, no injuries, and just a couple of weeks out with a bad cold early in the year. I really enjoyed finding my swimming mojo again, and plan to keep on focussing on improving my times over some shorter distances. I think coach Brian is pleased with the efforts I've been putting in in the pool, and there is plenty to build on.

Me and official 'swim buddy', Pete, travelled up straight from school and put up our tent at Guildford l(rather later than ) with some other swimmers. A group of ladies (the marvellous merma), who were a team, let us join their table in a busy restaurant, but another soloist on our table managed to put the fear into me by announcing it made ironmans look easy (I'll now say that it depends on the ironman - I've done 6 and some were easier and some were not). Anyway, I managed to only let that wake me up in the night twice with palpitations and woke before my alarm at 5 ready to go.

We got to the l. Gradually others arrived and we went in to register. There was some milling about and my friend Clare arrived to support. I think supporting is at least a two person job, and Clare and Pete managed to establish a good early routine.

The first mile felt horrible. I was worried about being the slowest in my lane (which I was) and I was unprepared for how much chop there was out in the m, 50m pool with a breeze and all the other swimmers around. I was also dreadfully nervous and that impacted badly on my rhythm. The second mile felt much better. The routine was: get in at the top of the hour, swim 32 lengths, get out, wrap in 'dry robe', change into dry cossie, put on warm clothes, then sit down and rest before heading back to the pool to strip off the clothes, put the robe back on and wait for the top of the hour to start again.


After 5 miles the swimming was going well and I was enjoying it. I was fairly consistent in my times and wasn't too cold. Then my family and Alison from work arrived and I felt very supported but at the same time very aware of a weight of expectation. Pete and Jon were worrying that I hadn't eaten enough and were trying to get me to eat more. However, eating was making me feel nauseous and dizzy which was then making me anxious. A couple of trips to the loo seemed to stabilise my stomach as I switched to carb drink, gels and shot blocks. My k. I swam thorough a mile where I felt dizzy and worried whether I was in fact getting too cold but things improved and when my coach Brian, and his wife Lesley and daughter Teresa came I had a good few miles with support at both ends of the pool, although in between I d't stray too far from the loos as my stomach was a bit upset still.

I got to 11 miles and then apparently my lips started to look a bit blue, and I was getting a shakes a bit in between swims. We were told the water was 22.5, but another swimmer reckoned he measured it at 19. It was certainly warmer than when my club mates d't a walk in the park, weather wise. I opted to put on a wetsuit which was nice and warming but which d. The miles clocked up, the sun went down, the k, and then my friend Cat arrived, replacing Brian, Lesley and Teresa.

There was something very nice about swimming in the dark. The atmosphere changed and the l. Although I d't make it back to our tent, we d! A few people had ordered pizza and it was quite tempting! I swam on through the rain. Jon went to get a few hours sleep in the tent and Cat and Pete stood in the rain counting lengths. Pete was trying to encourage me by telling me my times but I'm afra. (Which I told him - sorry Pete!)

I got through half way which was a milestone especially cons'd felt at mile 6. In my head I wanted to get to 16. My shoulders were now telling me I probably wouldn't finish 24. The first few strokes of every mile were hard but I settled into it. The pain eased sometimes but was getting worse through each swim. I focussed just on the next mile.

At some point in mile 15 it just became impossible to turn my left arm over. Each turn at the end of a length pushed pain through my shoulder and I could no longer turn my hand over to look at my watch. I tried breast stroke (almost impossible in a wetsuit!) with the most puny little arm strokes! I had another couple of goes at crawl. I tried swimming one armed. Each time I tried to move my left arm I winced in pain. Lisa from work had arrived and I was so pleased to see her but I knew I was doing my last mile. I kicked the last 400m to complete mile 15. I certainly wasn't going to leave a mile dangling!

Pete and Cat tried to persuade me to carry on but when I got into the hot tub to see if warmth on my shoulder would release it, it was clear that I couldn't move enough. I toyed with the . I love kicking, but I would have had to do it with my arms by my s! There were some other swimmers, including some teams, in the hot tub and they supported my decision to stop. At that point there was no telling if I had done some serous damage.

Cat took me back to the hotel and helped me change, and then took me home. Jon and Pete cleared up and packed the car. I hope they weren't too disappointed. I haven't asked because I don't want to think about it. There was absolute agony in my left shoulder the following day but the physio thinks I haven't torn anything and that I will make a full recovery. When he asked what I'd been up to and I told him, he sa, 'Fifteen miles! Yes that's a long way!' But he also sa... That's for later discussion!
In the meantime there is the small matter of 9 'owed' miles. I plan to swim them (on the hour, every hour) at Club La Santa in August. Hopefully I can do a bit more awareness and fund raising for the charity place2be as well (https://www.justgiving.com/Hildi-Mitchell1/) as prov. Although I wasn't able to complete my challenge, keeping that charitable work in my head while training really helped me get the miles in. 15 miles really is quite a long way to swim and I should be pleased with that.

(You certainly should, Hildi!)

fields.title: Black Cap Handicap
fields.summary: Our club Blackcap Handicap is an annual event undertaken in the spirit of competitive fun. The course totals five miles of downland r, around the trig point and back

fields.content:
Our club Blackcap Handicap is an annual event undertaken in the spirit of competitive fun. The course totals five miles of downland r, around the trig point and back. The runners are set off at handicapped intervals from 19:00 hours based on their estimated time and the estimated time of the handicapper (whose decision is final!). The . The club awards are for the first pa Phoenix member across the line and fastest Phoenix male and Phoenix female overall.

The best weather we’ve ever had saw a field of 29 runners and five volunteers gather on the Downs. (A good turnout by the flies too, many of whom were stuck to the runners by the end of the evening!) We were pleased to have five family and friends join us for the fun of it. Our time keepers (without whom this event cannot take place) Sue Hudson and Erica Martin d. Kathryn Harnett cycled out to the trig point to make sure everyone passed around it properly and Jon Wright was photographer for the night. Liz Hall.

The first runner home was former member Jake Elliott who also recorded the fastest time on the night of 30:26 but as a non-member Jake doesn’t count in the trophies but due recognition must be given for a good run from someone that’s away at uni and “not doing much running at the moment”!!! So his dad, a fully pa, Daren Elliott is the handicap winner this year. I think Daren has got the better of the handicapper once before.

Our club fastest man was announced as Donald McClellan on the night and so he is but the correction is that there were in fact joint fastest men because both Donald and Tobias Bremer recorded 30:38. Tobias I’m sorry I denied you that moment of glory on the night but the hug you got from Donald must have made up for it!

Our club fastest female was without doubt Lizzy Miles in 35:36 having set a blistering pace from the outset that had some of the men on the start line behind her raising an eyebrow and muttering a bit.

After all that excitement many of us descended the steeper s. Thanks to all who turned out and engaged in the true fun spirit, it was a good night. The trophies will be awarded at our club awards evening later in the year.

Full results

fields.title: Youth Commonwealth Selection

The season gets better and better for two of Phoenix's promising youth athletes. Congratulations toArchie DavisandToby Harrieswho have both been selected to represent England at the 2015 Commonwealth Youth Games in Samoa.

Archie will run in the1500mwhile Toby has been picked for the200mat the prestigious event - which runs between September 5th to 12th - andis open to athletes aged 16 and 17 years (athletes born 1998 and 1999).

England's Team Leader Scott Grace sa“We have worked with Commonwealth Games England to select the best possible team for Samoa. I would like to congratulate each athlete who has been selected and who will now be working with their coaches to achieve strong results in the Games.

“It is important to England Athletics to have successful indiv. I know each athlete who is part of the team will benefit greatly from this experience and wish them every success in Samoa.”

fields.summary: A Phoenix runner has won the Phoenix 10k for the second year running. Congratulations to Phoenix's Finn McNally who kept the win in the family!

fields.content:
Phoenix race, Phoenix winner


Wednesday July 15th saw the annual Phoenix 10k race. Now in its fourth year, this is a flat course starting at Hove Lawns, out against the wind to Carrot's corner, then back.

Attracting nearly 600 runners, this year's calm conditions allowed for some fast times, with Phoenix's Finn McNally taking the lead on the home straight to finish in 31:01.

Congratulations to all the Phoenix runners who took part (but where were the women?!) & a happy 70th birthday to Andrew Haig who finished his 69th year off in !

The atmosphere from the crowd & army of marshals ensured the event went well - thank you to all!

(Finn & Andrew pictured)

fields.title: Question? Was this last weekend one of the most important weekends ever in the history of our club?
fields.summary:
Answer....yes it was!
Archie Davis, Spencer Thomas, Robbie Fitzgibbon, Charlie Grice, and Toby Harries took Phoenix to a new level this weekend.

fields.content:
In Glasgow Archie Davis came second over 800m in the Schools international running for England Schools.
At the European Junior Championships our two athletes representing GB both ran with courage and determination. Spencer Thomas just missed out on a place in the 800m final after winning his heat and coming 3rd in his semi final. In both his races he ran intelligently and courageously leading into the last 200m.
Robbie Fitzgibbon had to run his second fastest ever 1500m to make the final as a fastest loser and then he decisively and with such courage took up the racing from a way out and nearly won the final. In the end he came 5th just a second off gold which is the best position ever in these championships by a Phoenix athlete. Steve Ovett won the 800m back when he was a member of Brighton and Hove but Robbie's placing was better than the current Uk Champion Charlie Grice ran and also better than World Junior silver medallist Johan Boakes and former UK champ and a world age group record breaker Br.....not bad Mr Fitzgibbon sir!
Meanwhile across the world in Colombia Toby Harries made it through a heat and a semi at the World Youth Championships to carry the GB vest home in 6th place in the 200m final and to become the only Sussex athlete (at whatever age group) to run under 21 seconds for the distance......so club and county records for Toby from all age groups U17 to Seniors....despite what it may say on the Sussex website!
And back in Europe Charlie Grice ran a new 1500m pb in Holland which was also a qualifying mark for this years World Championships and next years Olympic Games! No club record though Charlie!
So bearing in mind how young all these athletes are I'll just ask that question again...Was this last weekend one of the most important weekends ever in the history of our club?

Answer....yes it was!......SO FAR

Hats off to the Fantastic Phoenix Five!

fields.title: Championship Charlie
fields.summary: At the age of just 21 Charlie Grice made his first but undoubtedly not his last World Championship final in Beijing, on August 30th 2015.

fields.content:
At the age of just 21 Charlie Grice made his first but undoubtedly not his last World Championship final. Charlie lined with the slowest PB of the 12 finalists but still managed to finish 9th. He was in contention with 200m left and it is surely just a matter of time before he closes down on the leaders.

So lets look at some more stats... Charlie was just 2 seconds off winning the race, came ahead of the current Olympic silver medalist and was just one place behind the current World Championship silver medallist. Charlie was also not just the only Brit in the final but also the only European. His 9th place is the best by a British man in a 1500m Worlds final since 2007 when Andy Baddely also came 9th.

In the final there were 6 men with faster PBs than Seb Coe and another 2 more faster than Steve Ovett. Coe and Ovett were once the great gods of UK m. When Steve Cram was 19 he came 8th in the Olympic 1500m final. When Steve Ovett was 20 he came 5th in the Olympic 800m final but got knocked out in the semi finals of the 1500m. When Seb Coe was 21 he came 3rd in the European 800m championships.

Our Charlie is right where he needs to be right now...onwards and upwards!

Here's Athletic Weekly's take.

Results here.

6:30 group coached by Roy- meet as normal at 6:30 but please liaise with Roy
6:45 group coached by Sue/Andy/Bruce- will meet as normal at 6:45
6:45 group coached by Malcolm- will meet as normal at 6:45 but please liaise with Malcolm

Facilities:Hove RFC who use the Rec have kindly agreed that we can share use of the park and also use their toilet clubhouse/bar facilities but NOT the changing room. Please remember that we are guests and respect these facilities.

Payment:The normal entry fee for Withdean is for entry to the track facility and does not go to the club. Whilst at The Rec we are asking that all athletes bring a £1 coin to put in a bucket prov.

Weather:We will be there, whatever the weather but please be aware that it is an open park with no cover. At the moment it is still warm but evenings are starting to get chilly. Please ensure children are appropriately dressed.

Activities:We are limited as to what we can do in the park and activities will be predominantly running based.

Health and Safety:Unlike Withdean, the park is an open environment and we therefore have to undertake additional precautions, please note the following:
&m We are sharing the park with Hove RFC please be aware of what they are doing and do not go on the pitches/areas that they are using and please co-operate with them at all times.
&m The park is used by the public, please be aware of this particularly if running on the paths, it is up to athletes to go around other users, please be aware of dogs and small children.
&m We will require all children in the 5:45 group to register at the start of the session.
&m We have a record from our membership list of contact phone numbers, which we will have with us, please inform us if you have changed your number.
&m All children in the 5:45 group will be prov.
&m Children will be asked to stay within a controlled area at all times.
&m We can use the Hove RC toilet but we will only let children in the 5:45 group use this facility if accompanied by a coach or parent. Because of this please try and ensure your children use the toilet before they arrive.
&m Please ensure children have a drink of water with them.
&m Please inform us of any illnesses or injuries your children may have that you cons.
&m Please ensure children are wearing clothes suitable for the weather, please check with your coach if it is ok to use spikes.

We hope to be back at Withdean on 7th of October, we will inform you when we know.
PHOENIX COACHES

fields.title: Donald in the French Mountains
fields.summary: Donald Maclellan went to the French Massif Central to tackle some serious mountains.

fields.content:
Donald Maclellanwent to the French Massif Central to tackle some serious mountains. After a week of training he ran in an open 12k race organised alongs(run over 34k and 60k!). The 12k Trails du Sancywas a mountain race with a straight ascent and descent, taking in 550 metres of climbing (and back down again), reaching an altitude of 1540 metres. The race set out from Le Mont Doré, a popular ski resort in winter. Donald sat in around 12th place for most of the climb but if you've ever seen him running down hills you won't be surprised to know that on the steep technical descent, he clawed his way to 7th overall, missing out on an age category win by just 5 seconds. "A thoroughly enjoyable race in fine weather".

Full Results

fields.title: Hever Castle Triathlon
fields.summary: One of our young athletes, Charlotte Matthews, has competed this year in the British Series and tried to get a place for next year in the Elite squad...

fields.content:
One of our young athletes, Charlotte Matthews, has competed this year in the British Series and tried to get a place for next year in the Elite squad. She has faced very stiff competition and just been pipped to the post which is a big disappointment for her. Nevertheless she is still working hard. Charlotte is 15.
She competed in the Senior Super Sprint at Hever Castle on Saturday 26th (adult event).
Shefinished asthe Senior 3rd female! Was third out of the swim and thatjust shows her how tough the British series competition is as it is her swim speed that she has struggled with (a relative term).
Charlotte's Mum, Jude also competed in this event and finished 8th in V50 category. Jude says "although we were in the same [start] wave I saw nothing of her once we got into the freezing lake".
Charlotteloved the course and was pleased to end the season on a bit of a high where she has done well as a child in previous years.
Details on the results page.

fields.title: Four Ton Tom
fields.summary: What do you do when you've already conquered the 100 mile distance? If you're Tom Farsyou dec.

fields.content:
What do you do when you've already conquered the 100 mile distance? If you're Tom Farsyou dec.

We asked Tom tell it like it was:

"I’d trained for one or two marathons a year for about 10 years and felt that I needed a change. I dec‘The Year of Going Big’.

Long story short, I signed up to do all four of Centurion Running’s 100-mile races. Finishing each of them earns you a very stylish belt buckle which is emblazoned with “Finisher” if you complete within the 28-30 hour cut-off or “One day” if you dip under 24-hours. If you finish all four 100s within a calendar year, you get an enormous additional “Grand Slam” buckle that looks like it should be able to self-transform into a Tardis.

The Centurion 100s are along the Thames Path in early April, the South Downs Way in m, the North Downs Way in early August, and a combination of the Thames Path and The R. The first three each earn you 4 UTMB points and are Western States Qualifiers. The final one bags you 3 UTMB points.

Centurion Running (who also organise four 50 mile events) rely very heavily on an army of volunteers and there is a waiting list to join them. That’s how good Centurion are. They care deeply about runners, staff, volunteers, supporters, the public, and the local environment - and it shows. Routes are wonderfully marked and markings are removed as soon as humanly possible after races. Amazingly stocked a– 11 mile intervals along every route. I have seen runners stop m’ litter. Everyone is treated with admiration and respect. Support is simply unstinting. Many people’s stories are truly astonishing. A lot of emotion gets expressed. Needless to say, runners and volunteers come back year after year.

If you can run a marathon (and nearly anyone can), then you could run a 100.
Running your first 100 is satisfying and brings obvious bragging rights. “Have I run a marathon? Well, as it happens…” Running four 100s in 7-months is a really interesting challenge, as much about coping between events as within them. And beyond stoking smugness, you get enough metal to start your own scrap yard."

Tom ran 23:43:18 See full results

fields.title: Mud, mud.... glorious mud
fields.summary: The County Championships at Bexhill on saturday 9th saw Phoenix teams achieve medals in the U13 boys (bronze), U13 girls (silver) and the Senior men (silver). Congratulations to Finn McNally, who won the senior race by over two minutes.

fields.content:
Mud, mud....glorious mud!

It would have been good to see more Phoenix white vests getting splattered in mud in the Sussex County x-Country Championships at Bexhill, especially in the junior races where we have a large membership but not many attending races. However all those that tuned up d.


The U11's started the proceedings, first in for Phoenix was Sam Checkley having a great run to finish in third place, followed in by William Muzio and Sasha Denny, with Sasha showing great determination in still finishing despite losing her shoe to the thick mud on several occasions.


Next up were the U13 girls with Eloise Nicoll matching Sam Checkley's bronze medal, Eloise was neck and neck with the winner from Bodyworks for the whole race and just lost out in the sprint finish with the Hastings runner coming with a late surge just to beat Eloise to second place. Eloise was closely followed by Alice Wright in 4th place, then Emily Muzio 15th , Ciara Muzio 16th and Rachel Berry 22nd. The team took silver medals, just 2 points behind Hastings who won gold.


The U13 Phoenix boys were led home by Alex Brothwell with a fine 6th place, followed by Ben Cooke(14th), Joe Checkley 22nd, Ned Howes 25th and Eddie Harrison 43rd. The team took bronze medals, beating 4th placed Brighton by only 1 point, which shows that fighting for every place can bring reward.


Almi Nerurkar was the third Phoenix runner to win an indiv, Almi was followed in by Holly Luscombe who had another good run to finish 8th.


The Phoenix U15 boys were led home by Joe Luscombe who finished in 15th place, followed by Fenton Bingham(21st), Zach Elbourne 26th and Asher Dolton Martin in 39th.


There was only one Phoenix athlete in each of the U17 races, Charlotte Matthews had a good run finishing in 10th place in the U17 women, with A.


Although starting with the senior men, the U20men ran a shorter distance and Billy White had a good run and finished in second place to win the silver medal.
There were indiv's race with Finn McNally winning his first County senior x-country title, beating fellow Phoenix runner Jon Pepper into second place. Finns winning margin was the largest in the races history. They were followed in by Patrick Acye(14th) Jose Luceron(18th), Dave Carter(21st) and James Miles(38th) who completed the Phoenix team who won the silver medals, beaten to gold by 2 points. James was closely followed in by Paul Wishart(39TH), Paul Wear(53rd) and Andrew Haig(87th).

The Phoenix women were led home by Erica Martin in 12th, closely followed by Bobby Searle(13th) then Hannah Carey(25th) , Deb Friis 39th and Hildi Mitchell(49th) with the team finishing in 5th place.

Thank you so much to Bruce Warren for this report

(Pictured: Finn running to glory)

http://www.sussexathletics.org.uk/results.php

fields.title: Gold for Maia
fields.summary: Whilst many Phoenix athletes were wading in the mud at Bexhill some young Phoenix athletes chose to keep their feet dry and compete in the South of England U15/17 Indoor Athletics Championships.

fields.content:
Gold for Maia

Whilst many Phoenix athletes were wading in the mud at Bexhill some young Phoenix athletes chose to keep their feet dry and compete in the South of England U15/17 Indoor Athletics Championships.

There was a gold medal and first SEAA title for Maia Hardman in the U15 girls 800m. Maia went to the front after 200m and pulled away from the field winning comfortably in 2:23.61.

Charlie Warren and Louisa Saunders competed in their first year in the U17 age group. In the U17 men's 800m Charlie Warren achieved a new pb of 2:12.86. Louisa Saunders had a busy two days reaching the semi finals of both the U17 women's 400m (61.16) and 200m (27.29).

Well done to all & a thank you to Bruce Warren for this report!

(Pictured is Maia & her gold medal)

fields.title: Phoenix Masters
fields.summary: Following a revised course due to the mud, the Sussex Masters at Lancing took place on Saturday 23rd January, with a silver & bronze for the o60 and o40 Men's teams.

fields.content:
Phoenix Masters


Following a revised course due to the mud, the Sussex Masters at Lancing took place on Saturday 23rd January.

For over 35s only the Masters holds 3 races; women's race (over 35, 45, 55) of 4 miles, Men over 50 & 60 (5 miles) & Men over 40 (6 miles).


The Phoenix o60 Men showed the field who were the Masters with Paul Whelpton holding on to his indiv, winning in 34:49. Although the team lost the title to Chichester this year they finished a respectable second. The o50 men finished fifth in their title chase. The race saw Nigel Herron (o50) finish first of the Phoenix runners followed by Paul Whelpton (o60), Phil Hampshire (o50), John Marenko (o50), Phil Grabsky (o50), Andrew Haig (o60), Malcolm Kemp (o60), Ro Harrington (o50), Colin Simpson (o60) and Rik Taub (o60).


The o40 Men took bronze with Donald Maclellan, Matt Greenall, Paul Wishart, Tom Sanderson, and Andrew Neighbour finishing in that order.


The women had 2 teams in the running for the o35 & o45 categories. The race saw Anita Jones (o35) own it finishing a flying first out of the Phoenix women followed by Kathryn Harnett (o35), Louise Gregory (045), Hildi Mtchell (o35), Liz Hall(o45) and Jude Mathews (o45). All the Phoenix women took pr. The o35 team finished 7th in the title.

http://www.sussexathletics.org.uk/results.php#499

fields.title: All go at Turbo
fields.summary: It's all go for the new Turbo training sessions....

fields.content:
All go at Turbo

Tuesday 2nd February saw the second of the new Turbo sessions. For those of you who haven't experienced it, Turbo is placing your bike on a turbo to completing a gruelling interval sessions to improve stamina, strength and cadence. It is great way of cross training that pushes you whilst allowing you to work at your own ability.


And for those who haven't had enough, watch the training page for information on the strength and conditioning session with the legendary Dan Stepney of Bigg performance. These sessions will aim ‘do as they say on the tin' to work to strengthen and condition your whole body to reduce, hopefully eliminate, injury.


The sessions are open to anyone.


Comments from those who have attended so far speak for themselves, but it was agreed we should have been interviewed before the session!!
"I feel good now it's over" "My legs feel like jelly" "I'll feel the benefit tomorrow!"

fields.title: UK record breaker
fields.summary: Breaking news....Archie Davis is the fastest ever 17year old in the UK over 800 metres!

fields.content:
UK record breaker!

The BMC Open at Lee Valley on 3rd February saw Spencer Thomas storm to first place in 1:49:52 with Archie Davis finishing third in 1:49:74.

At just 17 years old this places Archie as the fastest ever 17year old in the UK at that distance by over 1 second.

He is now placed 5th over all (U20 indoor) whilst Spencer, who is only 18 years old himself, is placed 4th.

Definitely ones to watch!

http://www.thepowerof10.info/results/results.aspx?meeting&event=800&venue=Lee+Valley&date=3-Feb-16

Pictured: Archie (Phoenix vest) & Spencer

fields.title: Fastest 17 Year old
fields.summary: Archie Davis followed up his record breaking run at Lee Valley with a 1500m PB at the Ireland Athletics Games in Athlone ensuring more records....

fields.content:
Fastest 17 year old in the UK

Archie Davis followed up his record breaking run at Lee Valley with a 1500m PB at the Ireland Athletics Games in Athlone ensuring more records....

Finishing in 3.48.63, a close second, Archie led from the front for most of the way until the last 200m when an Irish runner called Joe Warne pipped him at the post.

This now puts Archie fastest U20 Indoors in Europe this year, 3rd fastest in the world and places him fastest 17 year old ever in the UK.


As the 8th fastest U20 indoors runner ever in the UK, Archie joins 2 other Phoenix athletes as Charlie Grice is placed 10th with 3:48:82 and Robbie Fitzgibbon 3rd with 3:47:19.

Results:

http://www.thepowerof10.info/results/results.aspx?meeting&event=1500&venue=Athlone%2c+IRL&date=7-Feb-16


http://www.athleticsirelandenterprises.com/results_07022016/event016h01.html

Pictured: Archie in Ireland.

Thanks to Joel K, Archie's coach, for pictures & info

fields.title: Phoenix at the SGP awards
fields.summary: It fell to a men's vet team and one junior to uphold the honour of  Brighton Phoenix at the annual Sussex Grand Prix awards on Wednesday 10  February.

fields.content:
It fell to a men's vet team and one junior to uphold the honour of Brighton Phoenix at the annual Sussex Grand Prix awards on Wednesday 10 February.

Phil Grabsky, Lance Bellers, Nigel Herron, Paul Whelpton and Andrew Haig (average age 56) had completed their eight races during 2015 and performed well enough to achieve second place in the male vet team competition. In fact they were an agonising six points away from first place – that went to Wadhurst Runners.

That wasn't the end of it though – as you can see from the photographs, our table was groaning with awards (and empty glasses) by the end of proceedings. Paul Whelpton was first placed V5 male and Andrew Haig was first V6 male. Andrew has won his age group now for ten consecutive years. Nigel Herron it was, though, who carried off most gongs. Apart from the team medal he was also 12th in the overall men's placings and was third in the fiercely fought MV3 category.

The winner of the junior male category was Will Russell. Those of you who know Will knowl how richly deserved this is. Will is one of the most committed and regular competitors in the club.

Well done all!

Pix by Lance


Sussex Grand Prix 2016

The partial success this year has given us a taste for more – maybe we can even challenge for the top club award (something we achieved over several seasons a dozen or more years ago). To do this we need runners from each section of the club – juniors, seniors and vets both male and female to commit to running eight of seventeen races over the course of the year.

This is how it works:

You can find a list of this year's races together with results and rules at the SGP site http://www.sussexgrandprix.co.uk/ When entering, as a member of one of the twenty three competing clubs you will automatically entered for the competition. Remember to put in the correct club reference 'Brighton Phoenix' and your date of birth.

The first male or female SGP runner to finish a race scores 500 points, the next 499 and so on. You can run as many of the seventeen races as you like but your best eight scores will be taken into cons. These must include two 10M+ races to optimise your score. If you can't manage eight then whatever score you have managed will figure in the results.

Points are awarded for men overall, women overall, senior teams (10 to count), vet teams (5 to count) and then the overall club competition. There are also awards for best juniors (U20) and those who have run the most races.

The whole thing can give a real focus to your running year especially since the SGP website features incremental results so that you can see exactly where you are placed in relation to the competition.

Phoenix's SGP representative is Lance Bellers and he is going to be making great efforts to boost our input into this amazing competition. Ideally we need more women, more seniors and indeed more vets. If Lance comes your way or you bump into any other of the SGP regulars, have a chat, find out what it's all about. It might give a real lift to your running year.

fields.title: Another UK Champ
fields.summary: Congratulations to Toby Harries, Spencer Thomas, Maia Hardman and Finley Bigg for their successes at the England Athletics Indoor championships

fields.content:
Another UK Champ

Congratulations to Toby Harries, Spencer Thomas, Maia Hardman and Finley Bigg for their successes at the England Athletics Indoor championships.

Congratulations to Toby Harris for winning the England Athletics U20 indoor champion at 200metres. At just 17 years of age, Toby won all his heats and finished with a season's best to clinch the title. As well as being the quickest U20 time this year, his 21.26 is the third fastest time in all age groups in 2016.

Silver successes in the 800 metres were seen with Spencer Thomas finishing second in the U20 category and Maia Hardman in the U15. Maia ran a new personal best in 2:18:96 to win silver, and is now ranked a rather respectable 3rd in her age group in the country this year. Hats off to Spencer who is ranked 1st in the UK U20 at 800m this year. Fin, who finished 2nd in the U20 800m heat and 4th in the final, is now ranked 8th in the UK at that distance this year.

http://www.powerof10.info/results/results.aspx?meeting&event=200&date=14-Feb-16

fields.title: Cross country league round-up
fields.summary: The Cross Country season came to a close with the final Sussex Cross Country League race at Hickstead on Saturday.

fields.content:
The Cross Country season came to a close with the final Sussex Cross Country League race at Hickstead on Saturday.

Phoenix returned with an array of indiv....

The Phoenix females managed a consistent turn out throughout the four races; the U13 & U15 Girls teams finished in silver and bronze positions respectively with Alice Wright taking indivAlmi Nerurkar silver (U15 girls). The Senior Women, however, won the second division earning them a promotion to the first.


Not to be outshone, The Senior Men came first in the race, leaving them 5th overall in the League. The Veteran men won bronze with three well deserved indivDave Carter clinched the silver in the over 40 category whilst gold went to Paul Whelpton (over 60s) and Andrew Haig (over 70s). All 3 have showed consistent performances throughout the season and this is the second year Paul has won the title.

fields.title: Naomi Sprints to gold
fields.summary: Over the weekend of the 20th and 21st February 10 young Phoenix athletes went to the Sussex indoor champs at the Dav, including a gold for Naomi Owolabi.

fields.content:
Naomi sprints to gold


Over the weekend of the 20th and 21st February 10 young Phoenix athletes went to the Sussex indoor champs at the Dav.

A special well done goes to Naomi Owolabi who won the gold in the u15 60 m sprint in a PB of 8.09. Naomi, who achieved the English Schools' entry standard last weekend at Lee Valley with a throw of 10.89, is also competing in the Shot Put at Sutton* - nice work!!

*Naomi took gold in the shot with a county indoor record of 11.48 – another step towards English Schools. Go Naomi!

We had some fantastic performances in the U13 long jump; well done to Beatrix Dalley who just missed out on a medal coming 4th with a jump of 4.30m. Also of note is Renee Bassin, who finished a brilliant 6th with a PB of 3.35, and Amelie Novy (9th) with a PB jump of 3.16. Renee and Amelie have not jumped in a competition before. In the u15 Long jump Ella Hodge jumped 4.16m a new personal best.
