fields.title: Great Day at the races for Phoenix
fields.summary: Two golds (Toby and Charlie) and a silver (Spencer) at the British indoor championships in Sheffield backed up by others from Jon Bigg's storming coaching group made the British Indoor Champs an event to remember.

fields.content:
In the words of the commentator on the coverage of the British Indoor Championships in Sheffield "Brighton Phoenix have had a very good day here". He was referring partly to our medal winners but also to the strength in depth of our team. Indeed they had won the team competition.

Charlie Grice was defending the 1500M title he won last year and was the event favourite. He d't disappoint. Taking it out with two laps to go, he ran a perfectly judged race to win the final in (for him) the modest time of 3:46.50. It was great too to see Robbie Fitzgibbon make the final and achieve an excellent fourth spot (3:48.62). Archie Davis will be disappointed with his fifth place in the previous day's heats running almost eight seconds slower than his season's best and failing to meet the final.

We had three athletes in the 800M all running in separate heats with the finalists selected on time. Finley Biggran first coming second in 1:53.82, Then Dan Stepney, third in 1:51.46 and finally Spencer Thomas, second in 1:51.34. Spencer it was who made the final, running 1:51.35 and making it into silver medal position.

Then there was Toby. Toby Harries, just 17 years old and now British indoor 200M champion. He had won his heat in a 21:22 PB, the semi final in an improved 21:12 and then stormed around the difficult outer outer lane on the last bend to overhaul the pack in a thrilling finish. Time 21:13. Great stuff Toby.

What have all these athletes got in common? They are part of Jon Bigg's coaching group. A proud day for them and a proud day for Jon as well – congratulations.

You can find the results at

http://www.britishathletics.org.uk/results/20160227_sheffield/timetable/index/index.html

fields.title: More for Maia!
fields.summary: Well done to Maia Hardman for a great win on Saturday 26th in the Independent Schools Association Cross Country Finals

fields.content:
More for Maia!

Well done to Maia Hardman for a great win on Saturday 26th in the Independent Schools Association Cross Country Finals at Prince Thorpe College, Rugby. Entry for this race requires area qualification so standards are high. Maia ran well to win by 7 seconds in the Girls Year 9/10 Race.

fields.title: Punching within their weight
fields.summary: Golds, silvers and a bronze were to be had at the 8th Puncheur on 28th February.

fields.content:
Punching within their wieght


The Puncheur is a local cycling challenge that encourages the cyclists to keep up a steady pace over a staggering 65miles of short climbs and long, flat drags. Finishing with the gruelling 1700m climb up to Ditchling Beacon, this is as much about pacing yourself as it is speed and endurance. Finishing in under 4 hours for men & 4 hours 20 for women wins you a gold. Ins.5 hours (men) and 4hours 50 (women) places you silver. Finishing within 5 hours (men) and 5 hours 20 (women) gives you bronze. You don't have to finish within these times to take part.


Helmets off then to the 8 brave Phoenix cyclists who took on this event and finished within the gold, silver and bronze times;


Gold: John Marinko, Bob Novis, Andy bone, Glenn Church.
Silver: Jon Wright, Mike Townley, Geoff Pike.
Bronze: Jon Pike.

Full results: http://results.sport.co.uk/home/event.html?event&mobile=false

fields.title: Represented
fields.summary: This year was the 26th year of the Brighton Half Marathon, one of the largest running events in Sussex, and Phoenix made sure it was well represented.

fields.content:
Represented

This year was the 26th year of the Brighton Half Marathon, one of the largest running events in Sussex. Starting on Maderia Drive, the race takes you along the cliffs by Ovingdean before turning to head out to Hove Lagoon and back.
This flat course allows for some fast times...wind permitting!

With a massive 29 Phoenix athletes running and a total of 11 PBs we made sure the race was well represented.

Of special mention this year is Darryl Hards who goes from strength to strength with a new PB of 1:09:28, finishing 6th overall. New Pbs were also seen for Jose Luceron (13th senior man), Tom Sanderson, Paul Lawrence, Matt Greenall & Richard Thompson. Nice work to Malcolm Kemp who finished 8th in the Men's O60 group.

Congratlations to Bobby Searle for finishing 4th senior women with a new PB of 01:24:25, and Hannah Carery (18th Senior women), Gill Checkely and Georgia Flowers for their new PBs.

http://www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results

fields.title: Miles of success
fields.summary: It was a fantastic turn out by Phoenix's young runners on Sunday for the Brighton Half Marathon Youth Races.

fields.content:
Miles of success


It was a fantastic turn out by Phoenix's young runners on Sunday for the Brighton Half Marathon Youth Races.


By far the biggest team of competitors across the age groups, we were fortunate to pick up many trophies over these mile long races.

Phoenix took first and second places in the 15-17 Girls; Anna Berry led with Charlotte Mathews behind her for most of the race however in the closing stages Charlotte timed her sprint finish to take the 1st spot with Anna just behind in 2nd.


Further first places were seen with Holly Luscombe (13-14 Girls in 5.50); Alex Brothwell (11-12 Boys in 5.41) and Milly Dickinson (joint first in the 11-12 Girls with 6.02).


Well done to everyone who ran!

See our results page for full results http://www.brightonphoenix.org.uk/results


Because club names are missing in the results we may not have spotted some of you. Just email the web team and we'll update this report and the results.

Thanks to Jacqui Swift & Jude Mathews for this report

fields.title: Charlie makes the team
fields.summary: After his gold medal winning performance at the British Indoor Champs/qualifiers at Sheffield last weekend Charlie Grice has been selected to run the 1500M for GB at the World indoor Champs at Portland, Oregon 17-20 March.

fields.content:
After his gold medal winning performance at the British Indoor Champs/qualifiers at Sheffield last weekend Charlie Grice has been selected to run the 1500M for Great Britain at the World indoor Champs at Portland, Oregon 17-20 March.

Our own Toby Harries who also won gold at Sheffield in the 200M, unfortunately he d't meet the qualifying time for the Worlds but at age 17 we're conf's all to come for Toby.

Other Sussex athletes in the GB team are Lee Emanuel (3000M) and Adelle Tracy (800M)

You can check the Portland timetable at http://portland2016.com/ and British team selection at http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/world-indoor-portland-2016-british-team


GO CHARLIE!

fields.title: Bobby dazzler!
fields.summary: Congratulations to Bobby Searle on her first County vest!

fields.content:
Bobby dazzler

Congratulations to Bobby Searle on her first County vest!

On the strength of her Sussex Cross Country League performances Bobby was selected to be part of the team of 6 women representing Sussex in the inter-county championships in Birmingham. Bobby says the race was tough as it started out fast with a steep hill. She was very glad to have finished and not let the team down!

We are still waiting for results but do not think the Sussex Team are in the running as not all the runners finished.

Pictured are the Sussex Women's Team, Bobby is on the left.

fields.title: Cosmic at Cosmeston
fields.summary: Erica Martin took on the Cosmeston Duathlon (near Cardiff) on March 20th and came second!

fields.content:
Cosmic at Cosmeston

Erica Martin took on the Cosmeston Duathlon (near Cardiff) on March 20th and came second!


Erica reports the first run took place over trails and around lakes in Cosmeston Country Park. "I was pleased to lead after this as have only been running properly for a couple of weeks after 5 weeks off (with injury)". The bike section was a couple of laps out and back before returning to the park for a 2.5km second run.

Erica now has her sights on the European Duathlon Championships.....

Results are at http://www.cardifftri.net/

fields.title: Phoenix out in force
fields.summary: From the two hundred teams who entered the Sussex Road Relays at Christ's hospital on Saturday 10th April, Phoenix came home with a medal haul, including their 6th successive senior men's victory and a return to force for the Phoenix females.

fields.content:
Phoenix out in force

From the two hundred teams who entered the Sussex Road Relays at Christ's hospital on Saturday 10th April, Phoenix came home with a medal haul, including their 6th successive senior men's victory and a return to force for the Phoenix females.


Splitting their lead runners between the A and B teams, the Senior men dominated their race. The B team of Max Pickard, Jon Pepper, James Miles, Dan Thomas, Sean Parker-Harding and Josh Guilmant lead for the first 2 legs. The A team of Jose Luceron, Bill White, Ross Skelton, Patrick Acaye, James MacCarthy and Robbie Fitzgibbon d. One of the most exciting finishes saw Josh sprint for silver in the last 100m.


The indestructible O60 men's team of Malcolm Kemp, Terry Avey and Paul Whelpton won another gold for Phoenix. Paul took over the last leg a good minute behind the leader, only to storm in first by a good distance and run the fastest lap.


Well done also to the O40 men's team of Steve Groves, Steve Selby, Matt Greenall and Paul Wishart and O50 men teams Nigel Herron, Mike Townley & Ray Mathews for their bronze medals.


Maintaining their form, the Phoenix U15 girls team Maia Hardman, Naomi Fonteyn and Saorise Mcguiness brought home another gold whilst the U13 girls (Milly Dickinson, Alice Wright and Eloise Nicoll) took bronze. Maia continues her fantstic form, running the fastest lap in 6:02.

Well done to Liz Hall, Louise Gregory and Lesley Fairbairn in what looks like a silver medal in the O50 women's race after at first being mistaken for an O40 team such was their speed! (official confirmation pending...)

It is good to report there were four (yes, four!) women's teams entered covering the Senior, O40 and O50 races. This is a return to strength for the Phoenix females who have been dwindling in numbers in previous races.


Well done to all those who took part.

fields.title: Erica in Europe
fields.summary: Erica tells the story of her European Championships race (Sprint Duathlon):

fields.content:
Erica tells the story of her European Championships race (Sprint Duathlon):

"The race was held at Wunderland theme park which was quite interesting but worked really well. Both the run and bike courses were extremely flat. The first run started off very quickly. I went off slightly more steadily and felt strong passing people throughout.

The bike course took us out of the theme park on closed road and was quite exposed which meant it was pretty windy. A few people passed me but I managed to hold a reasonable pace. Being only 2.5km I dec. I finished strongly and was pleased to come 5th in a strong age group. This should have qualified me for next years event."

fields.title: Marathon Weekends
fields.summary: With 2 of the biggest marathon weekends completed, Phoenix says a huge well done to those who took part.

fields.content:
Marathon weekends

With 2 of the biggest marathon weekends completed, Phoenix says a huge well done to those who took part.


The Brighton Marathon, held April 16th and 10km, saw over 10,000 finishers with some 2,500 running the 10km. It is now in Europe's top 12 largest marathons. The Mini Mile races cover a distance of (yes, you've guessed it) 1mile. Held the day before the marathon, they are for 7-17 year olds and see over 2000 young people take part.


The iconic London marathon, now in its 35th year, is one of World Marathon Majors. It has nearly 40,000 runners.


Not only taking part but achieving new times in these events is huge news! Well done then to Darryl Hards, Jose Luceron Munoz, Alex Cruttenden, Tom Sanderson, James Rae, Matt Greenall, Richard Thompson and Gill Checkley for their pbs in London and to Paul Lawrence, Paul Whelpton, Jim Whitelegg, Tom Holborn, Glenn Church, Phil Grabsky and Dan Harris for pbs in Brighton.


10k pbs were seen for Ross Skelton (who finished 5th overall), Max Pickard and Steve Selby whilst in the Mini Miles Maia Hardman and Almi Nerurkar took 1st and 2nd in the girls under 18 race and Milly Dickinson finished 2nd in the Girls 11/12 race.


Check out the Phoenix results page for results of all those who ran....

fields.title: Phil grabs a Pb!
fields.summary: Phil Grabsky recalls his journey to achieve a new Pb at the Brighton marathon.....

fields.content:
Phil grabs a Pb!

Phil Grabsky recalls his journey to achieve a new Pb at the Brighton marathon.

Sunday 17th April. It's just past 9.15am and I am walking slowly towards the start line at this year’s Brighton marathon. Others look nervous, some deep in concentration. I’m among the many smiling; I’m just, as they say, happy to be here.

Seven years ago, on my 45th birthday, I ran my first ever half marathon. I was on hol.1 miles from home – and I’d see if I could manage it back. I d. Athletics was not really for me: it was something others d, like Polo or Lawn Bowls. Then my daughter started running at Withdean for Phoenix. I'd always done a lot of sport - especially Sunday football – so rather than just sitting there waiting I ran round the track trying not to get in the way of those scary athletes. Then I started noticing some runners with waistlines like mine, speeds like mine, even running .

I knew Paul through a mutual friend: 'er, Paul, can anyone join?' Yes, hop on the Phoenix bus and enjoy the r, he more or less replied. I’ve written before (on his retirement from heading up the club) of my gratitude to him that he was not only personally encouraging but had created a club of members who were - and are - equally so. All of a sudden I found myself running with county champions, record holders and even national representatives. And not once d. It's been all smiles and warm welcomes. I started doing 10kms then halfs and then in 2013 thought I'd try the big one - the marathon. I'd day-dreamed that maybe one day - in New York, Prague or Rome - somewhere exotic - I'd maybe try it just once. But a friend d. I was persuaded.

I have a flexible but heavy workload but I d. I was thrilled when I crossed the line in 3 hours 58 minutes and 57 seconds. I ran straight up the stairs to my friend’s car and was driven to Wembley to see an FA cup semi-final. I felt great and barely tired. I had the bug. I went again the following year hoping for 3-45. I’d earlier that year run a pb half of 1 hour 35’ and I had heard about doubling it and adding twenty minutess to get your marathon time. Was 3 hours 30’ really realistic? Surely not.

On the day in 2014 I went for 3 hours 45’. It wasn’t pretty. I was so slow out of Preston Park, and then endlessly trying to catch up lost time. The second half was just a slog, getting slower and slower. I crossed the line in 3 hrs 53’ and I d't feel so great that time….. But nevertheless I signed up once again. I was now time-motivated…I wanted that 3 hours 45’ . But things d't go well: work prevented proper training but worse followed in February 2016 when I foolishly came straight off a plane to a wintry Monday lunchtime run and damaged my Achilles. I won't bore you with the details but it stopped me running in March and made me defer the marathon. I'd started running the Sussex Grand Prix and I made it through ten races but always in some discomfort. Both achilles and now calves simply would not repair. And this was where I was in October 2015, a couple of weeks before I was due to start marathon training. I was sure I’d have to postpone again.

Then I had a bit of luck. I'd been getting physio that had predominantly meant acupuncture on my legs. It helped enough to allow me to run in the Grand Prix races (which I really enjoyed) but there was no overall improvement. Then my physio left Brighton. I asked around and was recommended a fellow Phoenix runner who was also a physio: Tobias Bremer. Almost the first thing I sa. Just concentrate on physio and rest. Nonsense, he replied - that is the complete opposite of what is needed. You need to strengthen your achilles to repair them. Thus I found myself emailing Andy Bone for a marathon ‘plan’ – a 20-week schedule of runs that one is expected to try to do.

Andy’s plan arrived by email. What?? 42 miles in the first week? I’ve never run 42 miles in a week ever! Yes, welcome to Andy Bone’s multicoloured training plan. Long runs, tempo runs, speedwork, steady … Week 1 I managed 19 miles, week 2 I managed another 19. I was going to have to up my game but my achilles and calves were not up to it. Right, I sa, Christmas has to be make or break. Week three and I got to 37 miles out of 46. Then, even while ski-ing, I managed 22 out of 45… and I was really enjoying it. I could feel my lower legs getting stronger. Running on snow certainly helped. Over New Year’s I hit a milestone: my first ever 50+ miles in a week. I tried to make every session – I tried to complete something: I can be guilty of not seeing things through but I was determined. I kept saying to myself to organize work around the running not the more normal other way around. Needless to say I started to understand why we have a number of freelance designers in the club. They work as hard as anyone, I’m sure, but they – like me – can vary their schedules.

I kept at it – 37, 47, 35 miles. But then after a wet, cold 20 mile run with Phoenix buddies on a Saturday morning I got the worst cold I can remember. I couldn’t shift it for two weeks. It hit me just when I had early mornings, long flights, long days – and I got worse and worse. I certainly couldn’t run. Half way through came the Brighton half. I was keen to run it as I felt sure, with all these miles run, I could break my 1 hour 35 pb. I felt OK at the start line but nothing went well. I had music with me – that failed after a kilometer. I had snuck into the sub 1 hour 30’ corral at the start – that was a mistake as they all disappeared from the off… And then I d’t notice any extra strength in my legs at all. It was just hard work. I pushed as hard as I could – but I was outs. I started to wonder if all the effort and early morning/evening runs were going to have any effect by April 17th. People sa’d had – I wasn’t so sure.

I redoubled my efforts. I couldn’t run the Hastings Half as I’d planned as my cold had come back. But then I got back on track: 34 miles, 36 miles, 53 miles. In total over the 20 weeks I’d done six 20-milers (and up to that point I’d only done one plus the two marathons in my entire life). What I wasn’t doing enough of though was the speed work or any real gym work (“on your core” as they say). And I certainly found it all but impossible to run at pace on those long runs. Andy had set me a plan to try to achieve 3-30 that he felt I was capable of or should aim for at least. That meant a pace of 5’/km or 8’/mile. That was too fast for me – I managed one session of ten miles but only because it was with some of the great runners I run with at the weekend – and I was determined to stay with them at my marathon pace (their warm-up pace!) all the way to Worthing. I d, slow run back.

But I had already won the race as far as I was concerned as finally my achilles problem was fading. A year with an injury is a long time - I hated the ache every time I went down stairs. Yet it was repairing. Even a twenty mile run up and down the South Downs Way was relatively easy now. The weekend before the marathon I ran at Christ’s Hospital in the road relays. I had no ’d do – and I hadn’t been training for short fast runs – but I was pleased to run 3km in well under 12 minutes. (My real ambition in life is a sub-20’ 5km…). A few days later – after a wonderful week eating pasta every day – and I was at the start line.

We’re off! Well not really…it takes ten minutes to actually reach the start line…and then we’re off. Pace yourself, Tobias had sa. Try to do every mile at the same pace…which actually was something over 8’ miles – as my realistic aim wasn’t 3 hours 30’ but to knock 8 minutes off my pb and break 3 hours 45’. I later learnt I had the slowest start of any 45-54 year old. My first mile was 8’51. Some in Phoenix would have run two miles in that time! But that’s what I love about Phoenix: it’s a broad church. Gradually I upped the speed – and then actually started to restrict my pace. Soon though I felt so comfortable at just under 8’ miles that I dec. And there was no-one more surprised than me that 20 miles later I was still running at just over a 3 hours 30’ pace… with absolutely no twinge or ache from achilles or calves. Twenty miles under my belt and it had gone well. I absolutely loved the crowds, the views, the weather – and, above all, family, friends and fellow Phoenix runners (both running and watching) cheering me on.

It was about now I turned into Basin Road. There was a bit of headwind and it was here my thighs started getting tired. It was here that maybe the lack of gym work (and other sports which I’d all but stopped due to lack of time) showed. Gradually my thighs – especially just above the knees – started to complain and edge towards cramp. I had to grit my teeth now and try to concentrate on keeping my back straight and arms moving close to my body. I actually like that run out to the Power Station so I kept telling myself that I was enjoying myself but it was only half true. I would have loved to have felt comfortable all the way back to the pier but that d’t quite happen. My pace dropped but not disasterously…and I knew now I was going to get pb unless I cramped (which I’ve never done in any race thankfully). I knocked myself out with a little sprint in the end – which to me felt quick and on the v– and crossed the line on 3 hours 35 minutes and 32 seconds. It wouldn’t have looked like it at that moment but I could not have been happier. Cheers Phoenix.


But that's only one s(http://uk.virginmoneygiving.com/fundraiser-web/fundraiser/showFundraiserProfilePage.action?userUrl=PhilGrabsky) - our company Seventh Art will match-fund what you have so generously given which means...wait for it...we are nearly at £3000! I can't tell you how fabulous this is - not only can we see the existing two teachers through training but now can look at supporting more.

fields.title: Charlie's new Mile PB

fields.content:
Charlie Grice has been in action in the Diamond League event (Prefontaine Classic) in Eugene USA 27th/28th May.

Charlie won the b (National) mile improving his PB by a whopping two seconds to record a time of 3:52.64. In club terms he has now passed Mark Rowland 3:52.9 mile to move 2nd on our all time list. He sits behind Ovett's 3:48 mile which is our club record and was the world record....for just one day only!

After his race he was world number 1 at the mile for just half an hour or so until the main (Bowerman) mile raced. He is, however, ranked 4th in the world over the mile after the weekend.

With the Olympics looming, his timing couldn't be better.

fields.title: What went on up the Downs (Part 1)
fields.summary: As the summer solstice arrives, another South Downs Relay has passed! Read on for what went on up the Downs... Part 1: Phoenix Fox

fields.content:
What went on up the Downs

As the summer solstice arrives, another South Downs relay has passed! Read on for what went on up the Downs...


Phoenix Fox
The women this year started with 8 who wanted to run the relay. With 6 places it seemed to be a case of all training and waiting to see who was still fit to run by June. However, as the time approached all 8 were literally still in the running. Luckily (for us) because of the issues with the men's teams being short of a runner Anita Jones bravely stepped up to join the phoenix B team whilst Deb Fris kindly volunteered to be reserve runner and so the Women's team was agreed: Liz Hall(Captain and savant in time predictions), Erica Martin, Caz Garrat, Hannah Carey, Bobby Searle and Kathryn Harnett with Hildi Mitchell kindly offering her driving skills.


There is such an air of unpredictability about this race that adds to the excitement and this year d't disappoint; the day started with a sighting of a fox with a beer can in its mouth, saw about 200 cows bring leg 11 to a temporary stand still and ended with a nonchalant, white stallion trying to race the runners (see picture below for photographic ev). And had it not been for Hildi's patience and driving skills the leg 10 to 11 handover would have been missed due to the bottleneck of buses trying to leave Springhead Hill.


As for the running; Erica led the women in leg 1 handing the baton to Bobby for leg 2, preceded by Liz, Hannah, Kathryn and Caz. As the race progressed we knew we had been overtaken by Arena 80 but it was hard to know where our position in the overall race was so our goal became not letting the Phoenix B team overtake us! By leg 7 we were seeing the B team arrive as were departing and even had the pleasure of giving B team-mate Richard a lift to ensure he met his handover (hope he's not too scarred!) but happily they never caught us.

As far as club records go, Erica beat her previous record on leg 1(a) and Hannah beat the long held record on leg 10, previously held by Gemma Sharp from the Team of 2002. Well done to Bobby and Hannah for completing their first relays and for Caz for running the relay only 6 days after posting a brilliant time in the 32 mile Weald Challenge. Although we d't beat any other indiv, as a team we smashed our previous best over this course by 5 minutes and 33 seconds to finish in a time of 13:33:55 and an overall position of 7th. T

he women's team should feel very proud of this achievement. Here's to next year.....

Kathryn

fields.title: What went on up the Downs (Part 2)
fields.summary: And as the summer solstice arrives, another South Downs relay has passed! Read on for what went on up the Downs...Part 2: Best disqualified A team

fields.content:
Best disqualified A team


Getting 6 men together to form an A team was something of a challenge this year but thanks to cooperation from Malcolm and the B team and some juggling by Matt Greenall who himself had to pull out, 6 guys made the start line for a 9am Kick off at Beachy Head expertly transported by our driver Louise.
James Miles spearheaded the team from leg one and in-spite of the competitive line up and a minor navigational error at the end of the 7 sisters he held his own to get the team going.
Next up was Alex Bonzi who was a late replacement and d. Alex was followed by Jim Whitelegg on leg 3 who also kindly joined the team as a late replacement.
As we waited for Jim's arrival at the end of Leg 3 it had become apparent that James was struggling to weight bear on his foot after twisting an ankle on Leg 1 and it was increasingly looking that he may have to pull out. Jim came in to pass the batten onto SDWR debutant Mark Cossey for leg 4 and we headed for the start of leg 5 deep in discussion as to whether we should call it a day after the first 6 legs or carry on as a 5. In any event we still had 2 legs to run and potential records to be taken so Jose Luceron took the batten from Mark at the start of Leg 5 with that very goal in mind.
So it was onto Ditchling Beacon for what was potentially our last leg of the day and, as per tradition, a band of Our Supporters from the Phoenix family were there to prov.
Jose, swiftly arrived at the Beacon having successfully taken the senior record for his leg and Donald Maclellan set off for saddlescombe on Leg 6 not knowing whether this was to be it for the day. Buoyed by a good run on Leg 6 where he broke the Vet's record, Donald, was keen to continue and after a vote at saddlescombe it was unanimous that we would carry on as 5 runners but no longer in the official race. We left a disappointed James at Saddlescombe in the safe care of Liz, his physio wife and continued on our way.
We had earlier thought our race was over and in official terms it was but the situation engendered a new dynamic. We were now running free, racing across the Downs with wild abandon no longer truly bound by officialdom. We had become like Caballo Blanco!
By legs 15 we were now back in the thick of the runners and as fate may have it we caught up with the Phoenix B team at legs 16/17 and the pre race banter of overtaking them on leg 18 was becoming a real possibility. Our Spanish Missile, Jose, d's leaving Donald a bit less to do in catching Anita on the last leg which he duly d, breaking another Vet record!
Our decision to continue racing without a full team brought a mixture of bewilderment and appreciation from teams we ran with. We had initially thought it crazy ourselves but when you remove the tension it seems you really can run free!

Thanks you Donald for this report

fields.title: What went on up the Downs (Part 3)
fields.summary: And as the summer solstice arrives, another South Downs relay has passed! Read on for what went on up the Downs...Part 3: Silver Bs

fields.content:
Silver Bs

After weeks of changes to the team, we finally put together five men and one women (Anita Jones) who only had 2 weeks to recce the legs she was allocated, the worst being leg 18 which meant a trip to Winchester and back.

The team met at Withdean Car Park at 5.00am and proceeded to Beachy Head picking up our driver Sue Hudson and Anita in Denton on the way for our 6.30am start.

First off was Pete Goodman, a first timer to this event who had recced this difficult leg over the Seven Sisters several times before the day. He was followed by Jon Wright from Exceat to Bo Peep, Malcolm Kemp from there to Itford Farm, Richard Thompson (also a first timer) to Newmarket on the A27, Andrew Neighbour to Ditchling Beacon and Anita to Saddlescombe Farm, This was the order for the rest of the day with everyone finishing close to their projected target times. On route we kept on meeting up with the women's team at the various change over points and this towards the end of the day developed in to a competition to see who was going to be the fastest of the two teams.

To cap a truly great day we were totally surprised when they announced we had won the B team Silver medals as we d't start with any other B teams, so had no .

This is a great and challenging event to participate in not only as a team but also as an indiv. It is always amazing after doing the first leg how quickly the time goes before you are out on the second and then the third.

Thank you Malcolm for this report.

fields.content:
Legs 11 at the Blackcap Handicap!

Thursday 9th June saw Phoenix runners meet at Ditchling Beacon to run to Blackcap and back. Runners give their predicted 10k times and are then set off at different times with the aim of finishing roughly together.


Despite the fact most runners began by saying they wanted to take it easy, they ended up running hard, spurred on to try and catch the runners in front whilst trying not to be overtaken by those chasing.


On what was a glorious evening, here's to Hildi Mitchell for keeping the pack at bay and finishing first, to Caz Garrat, the fastest Phoenix female, and Paul Weir fastest male. As this is a Club event trophies are awarded to pa's award night.


We were glad to welcome two non-members who whilst non-scoring ran well and joined in the fun.


Thanks also to Liz for using her savant time prediction skills to organise the race, Sue and Kathryn for time keeping, Hildi for the spread sheet, Malcolm for manning the trig point & taking photos, Jose for photos, Alex for coming out ‘top dog' in a dog attack (he barked back and sent the dog away yelping, tail between its legs!) and Nigel - legs 11!

fields.title: Tri-ing times

fields.content:
Tri-ing times


The M sees the start of the hotly contested Phoenix Multisport Championship....


We had five members take part in the MMalcolm Hughes, Mark Walker, Emma Wrightman, Liz Halland Izzy Anderson. This is the first of our five events that qualify for the Club Multisport Champs this year.

This is a very well organised and friendly event, over an easy flat course. It's a shame the weather wasn't as bright and cheery as after setting up in transition the drizzly rain began. By the time we finished it was several degrees colder and raining properly. Thankfully there was no wind!

Well done to Malcolm and Emma for their age group wins and to Izzy for completing her first triathlon; she d, even saying she had enjoyed it, so we should see more of her on the Tri scene going forward - well done Izzy!

fields.title: Bourne to run!
fields.summary: First in her age group at the Eastbourne Triathlon, Erica Martin gives her account of the race....

fields.content:
Bourne to run!

First in her age group at the Eastbourne Triathlon, Erica Martin gives her account of the race....


"It was an interesting race as it was the first time I'd done a sea swim in a race. The current was very strong but surprisingly I felt ok despite not feeling like I was making any progress most of the time!


The bike went out on an undulating loop around Beachy Head. The return route was a very enjoyable downhill followed by a nice flat loop along the seafront.

The run took us up to the top of (similar to the start of the Beachy Head Marathon) which was pretty tough. The second half was all brought us back down the hill to finish along the seafront.


I think some of my timings were wrong as for some reason my chip d't register the run or the bike splits. I gave them my bike time and they made up my run time which was much SLOWER than I actually got (they took it off my T2 time- I would never be that quick) so my actual times were as follows:

Swim - 12:51
T1 - 3:55
Bike - 55:42
T2 - 1:10
Run - 21:54
Overall - 1:35:34


This was a great race, well organised, challenging and local. I would definitely recommend it for the future."


http://www.eastbournetriathlon.com/results/

fields.title: Weakest Link and Drink!
fields.summary: Stormy conditions added to the already electric atmosphere of the Weakest Link competition on Wednesday 22nd June......

fields.content:
Weakest Link and drink!

Despite the stormy conditions, there was a good turn-out for the Weakest link races and proceeding weakest drink social on Wednesday 22nd June.


Congratulations to the Phoenix women of Cristina Lawrence; Georgia Flowers; Erica Martin; Kate Gorman, for a 3rd consecutive win in this race - maybe assisted to run faster by the fork lightening?!

The men also took a win - thanks Donald for this account;

Our team comprised of Tobias Bremer, Matt Greenall, James Rae and me (Donald Maclellan in that run order. After 2 legs we were in a decent overall lead over 2nd team Brighton tri thanks to good running from Tobias and Matt. The lead was maintained by James and Donald and on the final leg and it appeared we were "home and dry" However Brighton tri had different . It was not apparent this was the case ( at least not me) but by the time we reached the zig zag ramp at the marina they were snapping at our heels like a pack of wolves! The race was truly on however the team motto of "we are Steve Ovett" meant there would only be one winner and as we took the 2nd last bend we stretched away from the "wolves" and all crossed the line with a comfortable margin. By this point the heavens had opened but then it came down in biblical proportions drenching us all. It cleared in time for us to gratefully accept our winning jog shop vouchers from Sam and his team before retreating to the pub for a celebratory drink!


Social Secretary, Zeina Clare adds ‘it was a good turn out for both the race and the social afterwards. Lots of drying off under hand driers in the toilets and people wandering around barefoot whilst draining shoes!!'

fields.title: Rio calling....
fields.summary: Charlie Grice secures his place in Rio by taking gold in the 1500 metre race at the British Athletics Championships in Birmingham, June 24th.

fields.content:
Rio Calling!

Charlie Grice secures his place in Rio by taking gold in the 1500 metre race at the British Athletics Championships in Birmingham, June 24th.


Competing against other Olympic hopefuls, Charlie took the victory in 3:43:11. This is his third consecutive win at this event and gives him the British indoor and outdoor championship titles....and a place in Rio!!

Phoenix was further represented by Robbie Fitzgibbon, who finished 4th in the 1500metre heat, and Finley Bigg, who finished 5th in the 800metre heat.

fields.title: Phoenix amphibians
fields.summary: Tuesday 28th June saw Phoenix take over Pells Pool at Lewes for a 2 hour coached swim session.

fields.content:
Phoenix amphibians


Tuesday 28th June saw Phoenix take over Pells Pool at Lewes for a 2 hour coached swim session.

The first of its kind this season, the session took place in response to the Multi Sports meeting (held in the winter) to think of ways to support the tri-athletes of the club whilst the Brighton College pool is under refurbishment.

As is the Phoenix way, athletes of all abilities and experience were included in the session that involved an hour of drills then an hour session. In our lane the drills such as swimming with your legs tied together to improve your posture in the water brought on the joke of drowning moths rather than the butterfly, but it was unanimously agreed how much we benefited from the session; not only were we pushed to swim harder but we were coached on how to achieve this.

There was also the opportunity to be filmed swimming to analyse your technique and the session ended with a staggered race - like an amphibian blackcap handicap! Hildi had even thoughtfully brought hot drinks to keep us warm.


Thank you so much to Hildi, Nigel and Jon who gave up their time to organise the sessions and prov.

fields.title: Bigg news
fields.summary: Congratulations to Finlay Bigg for becoming the 800M English schools champ!

fields.content:
Bigg news

Congratulations to Finlay Bigg for becoming the 800M English schools champ!
Competing at Graveshead, the English Schools championships is the fourth largest event in the world and ran by volunteer teachers. Competeters are selected from their performances at County championships.


It it, therefore, huge news that Finlay Bigg finished in gold in the 800metres (U20) in 1:51:17.


Well done to all the Phoenix athletes who have earned their places to compete: Louisa Sauders (300m u17 women), Maia Hardman (800m U15 women), Leo brewer (1500m U15 men)

fields.title: Phoenix: What a Mob!
fields.summary: The Phoenix Flashmob at Hove Park parkrun was a great success with over  thirty of us turning out. It wasn't just about numbers; there were two first  timers, five PBs and the age grade lead.

fields.content:
The Phoenix Flashmob at Hove Park parkrun was a great success with over thirty of us turning out. It wasn't just about numbers; there were two first timers, five PBs and the age grade lead.

The Flashmob was V64 vet Paul Whelpton's , fittingly, he it was who ran a cracking 18:58 to head the age-grading with 87.61%. He was delighted with the club's response with thirty+ members turning up dressed resplendently in club colours. It was especially pleasing to see so many young runners there.

They were prominant among the PBs with Madelaine Badzuzaman, Anna Berry, James Fontayne and Woody Rickwood chalking them up. They were joined by vet Malcolm Hughes who broke his PB having just completed a gruelling bike r.

It was good to see some Hove Park first timers as well: Imogen Read and Eddie Harrison.

Leading Phoenix male finisher was James Miles who came third ioverall n a time of 18:09. Leading female was Bobby Searle, second woman and 28th overall in a time of 20:24

The results can be seen HERE. One or two runners who were pacing others opted to avo.

Thanks to Lizzie Miles for the photos.

fields.title: Centenary Man
fields.summary: Hats off to Brian Friend who has just completed his 100th marathon. Raed for his account....

fields.content:
Centenary man

Brian Friend has just completed his 100th Marathon. Here's his account of reaching his centenary....


"I completed my 100th marathon on Saturday 23rd July doing the Lunar-tic marathon in Shoreham. It was somehow fitting that an odyssey that started way back in 1983 should reach this milestone right on my doorstep. It meant that friends and family came along and made the occasion even more special. On my journey there have been sub-3s and plus-4s but no dnf's fortunately. My pb is 2:44 and my pw is constantly being rewritten! I've accumulated a vast store of memorable moments and a small army of running friends that keep me royally entertained with their trials and tribulations.

There was no plan to go for the hundred until two years ago when I quit ultras with a dodgy knee. By that time I was running trail marathons with my dog Butch and he joined me for 19 of the 27 marathons still needed to bring up the ton.

I'm now surplus to requirements for the very talented Phoenix over 60s team, so I'm delighted to be heading into the twilight of my career just running with Butch whether it's training, parkrun, canicross or trail marathons.

Happy running everybody, go Phoenix!"

fields.title: Iron Phoenix
fields.summary: You might think that an Iron Phoenix might not be much to write home about, what with its dodgy power to weight ratio - but you would be wrong....

fields.content:
Iron Phoenix

You might think that an Iron Phoenix might not be much to write home about, what with its dodgy power to weight ratio - but you would be wrong.

In the last couple of weeks Phoenix athletes have turned in great performances across Europe

At Nottingham in the Outlaw:
Bob Novis takes the age group win - and the age course group record by a mere eleven minutes - at the Outlaw triathlon, finishing in 11:08
Debbie Evers comes home in 14:32 - a new PB - and another age group win

In Kent, at the Bastion:
Miles Dav takes seventh overall at the Bastion, sixth man, and and second in his age group in 11:55. The Bastion is a h's first iron-distance event.

At Maastricht in Ironman Netherlands:
Geoff Pike finishes Ironman Netherlands Maastricht in 11:45, rounding things off with a magnificent 3:57 marathon. Again, this is Geoff's debut at the distance.

At Poznan, in Poland at Challenge Poznan:
Glenn Church knocks a mere 46 minutes off his half-Ironman PB in 2015, to come home in 5:06.

Congratulations all round to the all rounders and to Jon pike for this report

fields.title: Update: CG is GB Olympic finalist!
fields.summary: After a disastrous opening round, reinstatement and then a well judged semi final, Charlie Grice qualified and ran for the Olympic 1500m final.

fields.content:
CG is GB Olympic finalist!

After a disastrous opening round, reinstatement and then a well judged semi final, Charlie Grice qualified for the Olympic 1500m final.

In his opening round heat, Charlie had looked to be safe for proceeding to the semis but was pushed to one s. It seemed he was out but a keen-eyed track judge had spotted all this and Charlie was reinstated.

In the early hours (for us) of Fr.

In the final, Charlie maintained 5th and 6th position for much of the final, only loosing places in the final 100metres. He finished a respectable 12th in a time of 3:51:73. Phoenix is proud to support this fantastic athlete: European, Commonwealth and World Champion and now Olympic finalist!

GO CHARLIE

http://powerof10.info/results/results.aspx?meeting&pagenum=1#1500

fields.title: Golds at the Southern Athletics
fields.summary: The Southern athletics championships were held over the weekend of 13th/14th August at Ashford, Kent and Phoenix athletes came away with 2 golds....

fields.content:
Golds at the Southern Athletics Championships

The Southern Athletics Championships were held over the weekend of 13th/14th August at Ashford, Kent and Phoenix athletes came away with 2 golds.

Renee Bassin took part in the long Jump with 8 others. She came a fantastic first with a jump of 4.34 to win gold and become the under 13 champion.

Maia Hardman, running the in girls 800m, ran her heat on Saturday to qualify for Sunday's final. She took the gold, winning in 2:17.52 earning her the title of under 15 girls' 800m champion.

Well done also to Charlie Warren for a new pb in the U17 boys 800m, finishing 7th overall, and Naomi Owolabi for finishing 5th in the U15 3k steeplechase and finishing 4th in the semi final in the 100m.

http://powerof10.info/results/results.aspx?meeting&pagenum=4

fields.title: Magnificent 7 at the Big W
fields.summary: There was a small but beautifully turned out entry at the Big W this year with just seven of us tackling the daunting three miler.

fields.content:
The "Big W" on the downs above Kingston is a three mile series of steep ups and downs in the shape of (you guessed it) a W. The very steepness makes it challenging to run up or down.

We run this as a club event most years and the format is as follows: each runner estimates their time and is then set off on a handicapped basis. Since the course is looped, each runner can dec.

Just seven of us accepted the challenge and six of us chose to run in one direction with just Andy Bone (perverse boy) dec. We think he knew something the rest of us d't though since he recorded by far the fastest time.

With a fifteen minute jog to and from the start, the event made a nice change from the usual Thursday run and we recommend it highly. Look out for next year's version.

Afterwards refreshment was taken at the Juggs Inn which served as race HQ.

Thanks to Andrew Neighbour for organising the run and to Richard Thompson for the photos.

Results

fields.title: Be your best....it might just be good enough!!
fields.summary: Congratulations to Anita Jones...second in the Vichy Ironman has earned her a qualification for the World Ironman Championships in Hawaii. Read on to hear how she d....

fields.content:
Be your BEST! ....It just might be good enough!!


"The thought of an Ironman always scared me. When I signed up for Ironman Vichy last year instead of a rush of excitement I felt fear and dread. It's huge, whichever which way you break it down it is just huge.


Almost two years ago I sa, courageous, funny, positive and optimistic friend, Sandra. I always sa. Well, this was it - an IRONMAN. I trained hard and dare I say it started to feel excited. I felt if I could show just a small amount of the strength that Sandra showed I would be just fine."


Taking part in Vichy, France, Athletes swim 3.8km in the Lake Allier, cycle 180km through the regions of Allier and Puy-de-dome and finish with a 42.2km run on the shores of Lac d-Allier. Offering 40 qualifying slots for the 2017 Ironman world championships in Kona, Hawaii there was everything to race for!


"On Sunday 28th August I proved to myself that with the right training, focus, commitment and belief anything really is possible. In fact I exceeded my expectations finishing 2nd in my age group with a time of 11:15:38. I now have to do it all again at the Ironman World Championships in Kona, Hawaii in October 2017! This time I am excited. As a triathlete there is no bigger honour than gaining a Kona slot.
Thanks also to my fantastic group of friends and all those who donated. I have nearly reached the £1000, 17% of the cost of Sandra's care for the Martlets."

Thank you Anita for this report


If you would like to donate there is still time:

https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/Sandra-D

Full results:
http://eu.ironman.com/triathlon/coverage/athletetracker.aspx?race=vichy&y=2016#axzz4IkgxXZDj

fields.title: Will Power!
fields.summary: On the 24 September Phoenix's Will Russell ran his 300th parkrun. He is, by for, the most prolific parkrunner in the club.

fields.content:
Will started as a twelve year old back in October 2009 and has been by far the most prolific Phoenix participant. Think about it – 300 park runs amounts to fifteen hundred kilometres of speed work and an average of 43 runs a year. Back in 2009 his first run was in 28:59 and he has been improving steadily ever since. His pb at Hove came only a few months ago when he ran an impressive 19:50.

He can be spotted at any of the local park runs and occasionally further afield. His pb on Hove Prom is 19:45 and at Preston Park 20:08

Will does not confine himself just to parkrun and last year was junior Sussex Grand Prix champion.

Great stuff Will

fields.title: Barnstorming Duo
fields.summary: It's the Paul and Andrew story again. Our in-form twosome won county gold in their respective categories at Barns Green Half Marathon which doubled as the Sussex Championships this year.

fields.content:
Phoenix are in firm contention this year for medals in the men's senior and men's vet team categories in the Sussex Grand Prix. The latest SGP race was Barns Green Half Marathon on 25 September which doubled as the Sussex Championships.

Throughout the campaign we've had two runners who regularly win age group honours and, again, on this occasion they rose to the challenge. Paul Whelpton won the M60–69 category in 1:28.03 an astonishing seven minutes ahead of his nearest rival. Andrew Haig won M70+ in 1:38.52 almost four minutes ahead of his nearest rival.

With two races to go it's fingers crossed for team honours.

Full results

Thanks to Phil Grabsky for the photos

fields.title: All good at Goodwood
fields.summary: The Cross Country season got off to a good start on Saturday October 1st at the Cross Country relays at Goodwood. Phoenix got no less than 17 teams out ranging from U13 to over 60 years.

fields.content:
All good at Goodwood

The Cross Country season got off to a good start on Saturday October 1st at the Cross Country relaysat Goodwood. Phoenix got no less than 17 teams out ranging from U13 to over 60 years.

Well done to the U17 women for winning their category with Almi Nerurkar running the fastest lap. Silvers were seen for the U15 girls and V40 and senior men. Bronze medals were won in the V45 women and mens' V50 and 60 teams whilst U15 boys and senior women were placed 4th with Erica Martin (senior woman) running a fastest lap.

The next race will also be at Goodwood, this time for the Sussex XC league.

We have done really well in these races over the past couple of years and it would be great if we cando it again thisseason. This is a good course so if you haven't run cross country before, or for a while, come along and try - it's not usually too muddy!

fields.title: What a flashy mob!
fields.summary: Over 40 Phoenix athletes, from all age groups, responded to the call for a flash mob at Preston Park parkrun on Saturday 29th October. We finished with lead runner, ten in the top twenty and 12 PBs.

fields.content:
Over 40 Phoenix athletes, from all age groups, responded to the call for a flash mob at Preston Park parkrun on Saturday 29th October. We finished with lead runner, ten in the top twenty and 12 PBs.

First home was Max Pickard in 15:37, a meaty minute and a half ahead of the second placed runner. Alex Cruttenden was 3rd, Jonny McCormack 4th, Ash Dorrington 6th and Paul Weir 7th.

There were PBs for Mekdes Berry, Madelaine Parmar, Anna Berry, Tim griffin, Richard Thompson, Steve Selby, Paul Whelpton, Nigel Herron, Tom Sanderson, Alex Bonzi, Matt Greenall and Ash Dorrington.

Results

What you may ask is the point of a flash mob? First of course is that it's great fun but it does raise the profile of the club and there was certainly a buzz around the event with quite a few fellow runners asking who? how? what?

And, of course, sunlight reflecting off of all those white vests looked pretty impressive.

Well done Paul Whelpton for organising.

What a mob you are!

Keep an eye out for the next one.

fields.title: Leagues ahead
fields.summary: The first race in the County Cross Country League, at Goodwood October 15th, saw Phoenix Leagues ahead with some good team and indiv.

fields.content:
Leagues ahead

The first race in the CountyCross County League, at Goodwood October 15th, saw Phoenix out in force - and with some good team and indiv, this force proved more than just numbers of athletes.

Phoenix had 9 womens teams in the U17, senior and Vets categories with teams for U11 and U15 Girls. The U15 girls achieved 2nd place whilst the Senior women are currently placed 1st in division 1 and 3rd in division 2.

fields.title: Five get frosty in Friston
fields.summary: Sunday 6th November saw five Phoenix athletes run the Adder Friston 10mile.

fields.content:
Five get frosty in Friston

Sunday 6th November saw five Phoenix athletes run the Adder Friston 10mile.


In what was a very frosty start, the run took in parts of Friston forest and incorporated some clever sudden turns to make sure the runners were paying attention. The race was beautiful with some lovely views of the surrounding valleys and vibrant colours of the trees that almost took away from the hills.


Phoenix relished in the surroundings, finishing a strong 1st and 2nd (well done A) with Erica Martin a close 5th (1st female) and Kathryn Harnett and a poorly Liz Hall& 24th (4th & 6th female).

http://www.multisport-management.co.uk/2016/Results/documents/MSM_FristonForestTrailRuns_20161105_v0.pdf

fields.title: Another fantastic Phoenix turnout
fields.summary: Another fantastic Phoenix turnout was seen at the Cross Country league, Lancing.

fields.content:
Another fantastic Phoenix turnout

Another fantastic phoenix turnout was seen at the Cross Country league, Lancing with 13 runners in the U11 races and overall 9 in the U13 girls and boys races.

In the U15 races well done to Alice Wright who finished a well placed second, in 16:53 to place the U15 girls A team second in the league.

Josh Eeles (U17) won his race, with a clear victory, to finish in 16.55, placing the U17 men's team 5th in division 1.

The Senior women continue their campaign with a win by Beth K ensuring them 2nd place in division 1 and 3rd in division 2 after two races. Phoenix women's Vets again got 2 teams out are now placed 7th whilst the U17 women are placed 3rd.
The senior men are currently placed 3rd and first in division 1 and 3 whilst the Vet men are 4th.

With 2 races remaining these results show there is potential to move further up the league across the age ranges. Your club needs you!

http://www.sussexathletics.net/sites/default/files/SussexXClgeLancing121116.xls

fields.title: Phoenix Awards Night
fields.summary: Saturday November 27th saw the glittering annual Phoenix awards, hosted by Chairman extraordinaire Mike Townsley with prizes awarded by the legendary Phil Savage and Olympic finalist Charlie Grice

fields.content:
Phoenix Awards

Phoenix had a lot to celebrate this year with its athletes competing at international, national and local levels. The night was a chance to celebrate star performances at elite and club level and to give recognition to members who support the club and it's athletes.

In many categories, other athletes were praised as choosing a winner proved hard.

Thanks especially to Chairman Mike, Vets Captain Paul, Social Secretary Zeina & Hildi for organising the night & making it the success it was.

And the award goes to.....

BURCHELL AWARD BOYS
EDDIE HARRISON for his enthusiasm for running shown by his regular attendance at training and cross-country, road and track races throughout the year - and always with a good attitude and smile on his face.

BURCHELL AWARD GIRLS
JESS POWELL trains regularly and works hard, shown in her results this year; high jump 1.35; 6th in the Sussex combined Championships (achieving several pbs in the events) and is now ranked U13 49th in the country.

SPORTSHALL BOY / GIRL
FELIX SUTTON for winning all his events over the Sports Hall season and RACHEL BERRY and MEKDES BERRY who both had a brilliant season coming fist or second in all their events.

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U11 BOY
WILLIAM MUZIO; taking the trophy for the second year running, he trains regularly and has competed far more on the track and x-country than any other junior member.

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U11 GIRL
AMELIA KORTENS; trains regularly and works hard achieving 1.25 in the high jump and 3.73 in the long jump in the U13 age group.

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U13 BOY
JOE CHECKLEY has competed very regularly and was 5th in the 800m County championship and also ran for Sussex in the cross-country,

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U13 GIRL
RENEE BASSIN is the County long jump silver medallist, South of England gold medallist, ranked 52nd in country (on 24/8/16) and 7th at the Sussex combined Champs achieving several pbs. In the U13 long jump she started the year jumping 3.35 now reaches 4.50.

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U15 BOY
LEO BREWER reached the English schools and always displays a very positive attitude and is supportive to all other team members. He is currently ranked 56th in the UK at 1500m and qualified for the England School Champs.

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U15 GIRL
MAIA HARDMAN has earned big pbs this year. Ranked 10 in the uk at 800m and 5th in the mile, she also came 2nd in the England U15 indoor champs at 800m, 1st in the SEAA champs indoor and outdoor events and 6th at English schools. She is Sussex County and Schools champion, 1500m - Sussex champion, ISA 1500m and cross-country champion. Phew!

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U17 BOY
JOSH EELES - joined the club this summer and is now the best performing U17 athlete, steadily improving at 800m from 2.05 to 1.55.5, ranking him 12th in the UK. In the 1500m he's gone from running 4.19 to 3.59 in one season, ranking Josh 11th in the UK, 7th in SEAA champs and he is also Sussex champ.

CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR U17 GIRL
LOUISA SAUNDERS: Although in the bottom year of her age group, she is ranked 23 in the UK at 300m and 20th at 400m, is Sussex Schools Champion at 300m and 2nd in Sussex County. She is also Schools champs at 200m and qualified for the English Schools Champs.

More to follow......

fields.title: Phoenix Awards Night (part 2)
fields.summary: Phoenix had so much to celebrate this year it took two reports....

fields.content:
Phoenix awards night: (U20 +)

Phoenix had so much to celebrate this year It took two reports!

And the award goes to....

U20 CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR MEN
ARCHIE DAVIS: Archie has shown huge improvements over both 1500m and 800m culminating in selection, at just 17years old, for the British Athletics U20 team at the World Junior Championships, Poland. He is currently one of the most promising juniors in the UK and amongst the top 20 in the world over 1500m too. Archie's PB of 3.43.81 this year made him the 5th fastest 17 year old of all time in the UK, alongs. He is also fastest 17-year-old of all time in UK over 800m indoor. In the U20 rankings he is ranked 1st UK indoor 1500m, 2nd outdoor 1500m, 2nd 800m indoor and 9th 800m outdoor with a pb of 1:49.74.

U20 CLUB ATHLETE OF THE YEAR WOMEN
TARA BAGE: although she d. Her half marathon debut of 89:40 ranked her 6th U20 in uk.

BEST PERFORMANCE T&F MALE
CHARLIE GRICE: for competing in the Olympic final in Rio with a pb of 3.33 in the 1500m. He is 10th in the UK 1500m and 23rd in the 800m.

BEST PERFORMANCE T&F FEMALE
MAIA HARDMAN for gold in the Southern 800m indoors and silver in the national 800m indoor Champs.

BEST PERFORMANCE XC/ROAD MALE
FINN MCNALLY has run a 29:46 10k and 65:59 half marathon. He was Sussex Cross-country champion, finishing 15th.

BEST PERFORMANCE XC/ROAD FEMALE
BOBBY SEARLE Bobby's 38:52 10k and 84:25 half marathon got her chosen to run for Sussex in the Cross-country.

OUTSTANDING TEAM
SENIOR MEN for finishing 1st & 2nd in the Christ's Hospital County Road Relays - this has never been done before.

TOUGH OF THE TRACK
BILLY WHITE Steeplechase in 9.20, Bronze English Champs U20 - need we say more?

SHIELD FOR COMMITMENT AND ENTHUSIASM
PHIL SAVAGE Phil is at the track every Wednesday coaching two sessions and always trying to enthuse his groups of young athletes.

VOLUNTEERS AWARD
ERICA MARTIN has been Women's captain for 10 years and has also undertaken the thankless tasks of registering the athletes on the England Athletics Registration.

BRUCE FAULKNER AWARD
ANDY PUMPHREY for his record in world event ultras.

BEST NEWCOMER
DANIEL STIDDER Dan joined early in the spring and has added a really professional attitude and commitment level that has rubbed off on the U17 boys group. He has also run a number of big PBs this season.

COACH OF THE YEAR
JOEL KIDGER for coaching Archie Davis to be the fastest U17 over 800 & 1500 metres and supporting him to get to the World U20 Championships.

VETERANS AWARDS
O40 MEN
YDAVE CARTER: 2nd in the Cross-country league and champs and pivotal in our team bronzes for both.

O50 MEN
TIM WOODMAN for his outstanding international performances.

O60 MEN
PAUL WHELPTON has had many V60 awards over the season, on road and country and at county level, beating all V50s in some races. He boasts County V60 wins in the Crosse county League and Champs, 10K and Half Marathon Champs, is Sussex Grand Prix age group winner with four races to spare and has a Marathon pb of 3:08. Wow!

O35 WOMEN
GILL CHECKLEY for her consistent performance.

O50 WOMEN
LIZ HALLIDAY for sol.

MULTISPORT AWARDS
MULTISPORT AWARD MALE
MILES DAVIDSON was 7th in his first Ironman in 11:40 on a tough course plus a good performance at Brighton Tri.
MULTISPORT AWARD FEMALE

fields.title: League wide open
fields.summary: The Sussex Cross Country League saw the 3rd of its 4 races on Saturday December 3rd. Held this time at Stanmer Park, the league table continues to be w.

fields.content:
League w

The Sussex Cross Country League saw the 3rd of its 4 races on Saturday December 3rd. Held this time at Stanmer Park, the league table continues to be w.

Of note are the Senior men who are currently leading their group having taken the lead from Brighton & Hove who have won this for the last 10 years. It was very good to see a resurgence in the Phoenix women who got a record number of runners out, with 2 teams in the Vets league and 6 teams in division 1 & 2 and 1 in U17.

Team standings so far:

U11 girls: well done to 5th place Annalise Brown.
U11 boys: nice team work with 6th, 7th, 8th position (William Muzio, Ben Burnett, James Fonteyn)

U13 girls have the B team 5th & A team 6th whilst the boys are placed 7th & 18th.
U15 girls saw Alice Wright finish 3rd to place them 2nd & 7th in the league whilst Leo Brewer finished 4th. U15 boys are placed 5th & 15th in the league.
U17 women are placed 3rd whilst the U17 men are 7th.
Senior women are currently 3rd in division 1 and have 5 teams in division 2.
Senior men: Robbie Fitzgibbon was pipped at the post to finish second helping to place the team 1st in division 1. They have 1st, 2nd and 4th positions in division 3.
Vet women are placed 7th & 16th and Vet men 3rd, 7th & 11th.

Next & final race: Saturday 11th February, Hickstead Showground.

Thank you Emma (Eddie's mum) & Miss Sorensen (Mona's daughter) for your pictures!

fields.title: 5...6...7...GO!
fields.summary: Last race of the Sussex Grand Prix races saw 3 age category wins.

fields.content:
5...6...7...Go!

The last race of the Sussex Grand Prix season was held at Crowborough, November 27th. As this was the day after the Phoenix awards, those who ran had to ensure they were well behaved the night before!

Especially well done then to the 3 age category firsts of Nigel Herron (V50 - 39:26), Paul Whelpton (V60 - 41:21) and Andrew Haig (V70 - 46:31).

Pictured are the presentations by Mara Yamauchi, the British long-distance track and road runner. She currently holds the second fastest marathon time by a British woman, second only to world-record holder, Paula Radcliffe.

http://www.brightonphoenix.co.uk/results

As we await the final results for the season it looks like Phoenix are in contention for a haul of medals including Senior and Vet teams and indiv.

fields.title: Sussex Grand Phoenix
fields.summary: Provisional results for the Sussex Grand Prix indicate a medal haul of 25 medals for Phoenix.....

fields.content:
Sussex Grand Phoenix

Provisional results for the Sussex Grand Prix indicate a medal haul of 25 medals for Phoenix. Although not confirmed until after Christmas some careful number crunching by Paul Whelpton has revealed the following......

FULL (provisional!) list of medals:
Senior Team Gold:Will, Malcolm, Andrew H, Andy N, Phil , Steve, Paul Weir, Paul Wh, Tobias, Nigel
Vet Team Silver: Paul Wh, Nigel, Phil, Steve, Andy N

Indiv
Overall (medals for top 20) Paul Weir (7th) Tobias (10th) Paul Wh (15th) Nigel (20th)

V3 Nigel (3rd) V5 Paul Wh (1st) V6 Malcolm (2nd) V7 Andrew H (1st)
Izzy A (overall 13th, Senior 2nd)

Report

Despite losing three key runners, including captain Lance Bellers, to injury in the course of the season, Phoenix still d, so what is the key to the success? Paul Whelpton gives us his thoughts;
- in Senior competition is strength in depth, you need ten runners to score well over the whole season, we overhauled second placed Haywards Heath despite them having some very good runners including three who were well ahead of all of our team in the indiv.
- we had one of the oldest teams in the Senior Mens competition - seven of our scoring ten were Vets including three over 60s.
- our oldest runner V70 Andrew Haig clocked up 11 races and won his age category by a country mile despite undergoing foot surgery m
- towards the end of the season injuries and other problems left us relying on the bare minimum of ten runners for the last few races
- 19-year old Will Russell ran spectacularly well over the last five races, ending the season by knocking three minutes off his previous year's time in the final race of the season - the Crowborough 10k

So what about next year? Well, Lance Bellers will stay Phoenix rep for the overall series but we will also have two new Senior reps in Paul Weir for the Senior men and Izzy Anderson for the Senior Women. We have made some progress this year in the seniors but would love to build on that in 2017, particularly the women who were only missing in quantity not quality this year.

What do athletes need to do? Phoenix need as many male and female runners as possible to help the team (and potentially win themselves a medal) by planning well ahead and clocking up an effective number of races next year - which means at least 8 races including at least two long ones (10 miles or more). Please feel free to speak to Lance, Paul, Izzy, Paul or anyone else who took part if you have any questions about how to go about it, advice on indiv.

Happy running!

Thank you Paul & Lance for your info for this report

fields.title: Awards 2017
fields.summary: We are building up early for Awards Night 2017 and in the new year we will be posting on the website a list of all the club awards and trophies along with the criteria the Board use to judge who should win in each case.

fields.content: We are building up early for Awards Night 2017 and in the new year we will be posting on the website a list of all the club awards and trophies along with the criteria the Board use to judge who should win in each case. Awards Night is a celebration for all members of the club and a chance for us to get together and show our appreciation towards all committed members of the club; no one should feel they are not in the running for an award simply because they are not the quickest in their age category, dedication and other factors also come into play for most of the awards. The Board are aware that there has been a lack of clarity over what you need to do to win a 'gong' and we hope this will help people understand what is required and create healthy competition within each category. We are also reviewing all aspects of the organisation of Awards Night so feel free to submit any compliments, criticisms and suggestions! Contact: paul@paulwhelpton.plus.com

fields.title: Cross Country Update
fields.summary: The conditions at Bexhill for the Sussex x-country championships, on Saturday 6th January, were the best they have been for some years; normally ankle deep in mud, this year the ground was firm with no wind allowing for some star Phoenix performances.&

fields.content:
Cross Country update

The conditions at Bexhill for the Sussex x-country championships were the best they have been for some years; normally ankle deep in mud this year the ground was firm with no wind. The races started with the girls U11's with the Phoenix only runner Mekdes Berry finishing in a good 9th place. The U11 boys followed with both William Muzio matching Mekdes in finishing in 9th and Matthew Noakes just behind him in 14th place.


In the U13 girls unfortunately Emily Muzio was tripped in the mass start but d. Her sister Ciara was the first Phoenix runner home, going one better than Mekdses and William to finish in 8th place with Taya Gilbert completing the team finishing in 38th place.


It was the U13 Boys that prov. He was followed by Joe Checkley in 18th, Sam Checkley in 24th, Cassius Hebden in 34th and Eddie Harrison in 37th.


The U15 girls prov. Alice was followed by Rachell Berry in 10th, Mia Edwards in 15th and Madelaine Parmar in 23rd, with the team securing the first team medal of the day for Phoenix with bronze.


The first indiv. Unfortunately the only other Phoenix competitor Zach Ebden had to retire after turning his ankle but well done to Zach for making the effort to go to Bexhill.


Phoenix were now on a roll and in the next race the U17 girls prov. The team were led home by Almi Nerurkar who like Leo controlled the race from the start. Almi waited a little longer than Leo before breaking away from the leading group, which included Naomi Fonteyn who just missed out on the bronze medal in the run to the line but had a fine run to finish 4th. Connie Jankowski completed the gold medal team finishing in 13th place. Unfortunately Anna Berry and Holly Luscombe were unable to finish the race but should be commended for starting the race.


There were no Phoenix starters in the U17 boys race, which is the first time for many years. Given the numbers of juniors at training at Phoenix every week, the turn out for the county's most important x-country race was disappointing, hopefully next year this can be rectified. However this should not distract from those who made the trip to Bexhill and who all tried their best and should be commended.


It was a case of men before ladies with the senior men's race being next. The senior men's race also included the U20 men's race, with the U20's running 3 of the 4 laps run by the senior men. At the end of these 3 laps it was Dan St, leading the other U20 runners from start to finish. Billy White moved through strongly on the last lap to take the U20 silver medal. Meanwhile at the front of the field in the senior race Jon Pepper broke away from the leading group to win the 4th indiv, this was Jon's 5th senior title. In the race for the other medals Max Dumbrell was having a good run but just missed out in a three-way sprint to the line to finish in 4th place. Despite many Phoenix athletes being absent those present all ran well with Patrick Acaye 16th, Darryl Hards 20th, Sean Parker Harding 37th and Donald Maclellan 38th completing the Phoenix team that finished with the bronze medal. Next home for Phoenix were Alex Cruttenden 45th, Jonny McCormack 47th, Paul Weir 49th, Ash Dorrington 54th Austen Hunter 63rd.


It was the ladies who finished the days racing. As with the men the U20's ran with the seniors but unlike the men the U20 women ran the same distance as the seniors making it difficult to work out positions. Tara Bage who has been running well dec's she was fighting it out at the front of the field with the top 10 seniors. Unfortunately, Tara faded towards the end of the race and was just beaten into silver medal position in the u20 race but still had a fine race finishing 12th overall and should be commended for her bravery. Just behind Tara was the first senior Erica Martin who finished in 15th and d. Erica was followed by Carroline Garrett 43rd, Isobel Anderson 50th, Sarah Russell 61st and Lucinda Ganpatsingh 65th.
Well done all those who ran.

Let's see more Phoenix white vests competing in the last x-country league race at Hickstead on 11th February.

Thanks to Bruce for this report

fields.title: Master Class
fields.summary: The Sussex Cross Country Masters, held this year at Lancing, saw some good indiv.

fields.content:
Master Class

The Sussex Cross Country Masters, held this year at Lancing, saw some good indiv.


Held on a brisk Saturday afternoon, Phoenix saw no fewer than 30 runners enter the hilly course. Starting at the allotments, the course involved a steady climb before curving up through a wooded area, passing some beautiful frost patches, to finish in a steep down hill sprint. All the races included a few laps of this course so the key was to not over cook the first hill!


First off were the 050 and 60 men. Completing a 5 mile course it was Paul Whelpton who deserves a mention for finishing 2nd 060, 8th overall in a storming 33.34. The 050 men came 5th in the team standings and 4th and 7th for the 060.
The Phoenix women continued their resurgence with 8 runners taking on the 4 mile course and the 035 team finishing in 6th position.
The 040 men rounded up the day, tuning a 6 mille course. Dave Carter was the fastest Phoenix man, finishing 7th overall. They took 3rd and 8th in the team standings.

Thanks to Erica and Andrew for the photography

fields.title: Daniel and Finn win and win
fields.summary: Daniel St and Finn McNally scored impressive victories in their respective races over the weekend of 4/5 February

fields.content:
First up was Daniel St running in the U19 boys event at the South East Schools cross country champs at Brands Hatch on Saturday. Already county schools champion, Daniel was always ahead of a highly competetive field, winning by a convincing 15 second margin over the second athlete. Other Phoenix athletes were putting in good perfomances as you can see on the results page

On the Sunday it was Finn McNally's turn. Despite a new course starting at the Goodwood Aerodrome (not universally appreciated) and a long delay before the gun was fired leaving athletes shivering in the cold, Finn ran a cool commanding race. He finished looking fresh as a daisy a good 70M ahead of his nearest rival. His time? A remarkable 30:46. Well done both

fields.title: League round up
fields.summary: The last in the Cross Country League saw athletes battle weather and poor conditions before even starting the race!

fields.content:
League round up

The last in the Cross Country League saw athletes battle weather and poor conditions before even starting the race!

The recent wet weather rendered the course un-runable but thanks to the work of the league officials, who made last minute changes to the course, the races went ahead. Proper winter conditions added to the excitement of the day as the first races started in snow (albeit flakes!).

Phoenix saw athletes in all 7 races and it was again the females that shone;
Well done to Madeleine Badruzaman and Ella Kaps for their 3rd & 4th respectively in the U11 girls race, Clara Muzio for finishing 4th in the U13 girls and Alice Wright who came 3rd U15 girls. Furthermore, Alice won the silver indiv.
In the women's race we saw Tara Bage finish 1st U20 in the race and overall in the league. Naomi Fonteyn 2nd U17 in the race and 3rd in the league and Connie Jankowski 5th U17. The Phoenix women's A team finished bronze in division 1 in their first year since promotion.
The men's race saw Billy White finish 1 st U20 and Dave Carter 8th Vet. The Phoenix men's A team also took bronze in division 1 whilst Phoenix B & C finished 1st and 2nd respectively in division 3 (giving them promotion to division 2). Well done to the Vets who finished 4th, just 3 points off 3rd position. In the indiv(U20) & Paul Whelpton (V60) & bronze for Dave Carter (V40).

These medals were hard won as the competition as always was fierce plus turnout was a bit low for this final race. We hope those who d!

fields.title: CLUB AWARDS 2017
fields.summary: We plan to hold our 2017 Awards Night at the usual time towards the end of the year, in late November or early December, to review and celebrate the period from September 2016 to August 2017 inclusive.

fields.content:
We plan to hold our 2017 Awards Night at the usual time towards the end of the year, in late November or early December, to review and celebrate the period from September 2016 to August 2017 inclusive. As we are a thriving club with a large membership it is of course always going to be impossible to make enough indiv. This makes decisions about awards very difficult for our Coaches - who make most of the nominations - and the Board members, who make the final decisions. Here as promised is a full list of all current awards together with the criteria taken into account for each of them.

Best Performance Awards

Track and Field Male & Female, Cross/Country/Road Male & Female, Outstanding Achievement (Multisport), Outstanding Team

The sole criterion for these awards is outstanding achievement in absolute terms - with suitable adjustment for age and gender.

Specific Event Awards

Tri Club Champions Male & Female, Blackcap Handicap

These of course are based on finishing positions in the relevant events.

Other Awards

Junior Awards (Burchell, Sportshall, U11, U13, U15, U17), U20 Awards, Tough Of The Track, Commitment and Enthusiasm Shield, Volunteer's Award, Bruce Faulkner Award, Best Newcomer, Coach Of The Year, Vet Awards (Male O40, O50, O60, Female O35, O50, O60), Multisport Male & Female, Chair's Award, and new Team Commitment Award

For all of these awards the following range of criteria is taken into account - with appropriate adjustment for specialist awards such as the Coach and Volunteer awards:

Team spirit/support given to other club members; volunteering record; improvement on personal best performances (with age-graded adjustment so older members are still in with a shout!); effort put into training and racing; lack of previous club awards; length of club membership; outstanding performance in absolute terms.

Needless to say the aim is that all club members have a realistic chance of gaining an award prov! For instance we already have a lot of members staking strong bfor 2017 team awards:

Under 11 Boys XC Team: best turnout of any of our teams in the Sussex Cross Country League;

Women's XC Team: bronze medallists in Sussex Cross Country League in their first year after promotion to Division 1;

Men's Sussex Grand Prix Team: winners of the SGP Men's Trophy for the first time.

Awards are not the be all and end all of why we run of course, but who doesn't like a bit of recognition, so best of luck to all!
